Review: Wow, how to even describe this movie?Deadpool was ceasessly introduced into the MCU. Sure, you might want to get accquited with a few MCU films first to understand what's going on, but the movie does a good enough job explaining the stakes.What you really should do homework for is the sheer amount of cameos from Fox's library of Marvel movies, from Fantastic Four to Elektra. This movie is an unbashed celebration of the history of these movies as well as the 2000's cultural milestones.And, of course, you get your sassy pansexual fourth wall demolisher and your heroic muscle man.I cannot recommend this movie enough.

Review: Sporting more cameos than a bad mobile game advert (although Pedro Pascal doesn't show up here), 'Deadpool And Wolverine (2024)' is one of the most meta movies I can think of. Frankly, it's meta to the point that it doesn't actually exist... or, at least, it feels that way. It's the equivalent of the TVA-created limbo so much of its plot takes place in: a barren, out-of-time wasteland with no discernible features other than the remnants of long-forgotten Marvel movies/ universes. It exploits its audience's nostalgia, ostensibly acting as an ode to the Fox-era of Marvel but actually just parading around the carcasses of films that only the most loyal fans remember at all, let alone fondly. You don't even have to be all that cynical to see that its various cameos and callbacks are incredibly hollow, bereft of any real narrative significance. These things are designed to be recognised, rather than admired. The joy they evoke - which I'm not immune to, by the way - fades incredibly quickly because of this, and they lose even more power when they're inevitably robbed of the element of surprise (either by the inherently one-time nature of that element or, far more bafflingly, by Marvel's marketing department themselves).By assembling itself out of only the most memorable parts of previous movies' corpses, the picture lacks any real identity of its own. Its meta elements aren't used to comment on... well, anything really. It doesn't acknowledge it's a movie so it can say anything about filmmaking, nor about the relationship between audiences and the media they consume; it doesn't point out its place in Marvel's incredibly complex multiverse to do anything other than poke fun at the very things it indulges in, while also feeling just a smidge smug. Despite its vaguely satirical elements, it's all seems a little bit self-satisfied, and it panders to its audience in a way that's sort of off-putting. It takes things fans have loved about even Marvel's least successful efforts, and the running jokes they've created about said efforts, and transforms them into a shamelessly corporate currency that can be exchanged for cold hard cash. That this film has made so much money only further suggests that audiences don't care about story if they're bombarded by things they've seen before, which will in turn cause Disney to learn the wrong lessons and cram more cameos into their now-middling franchise instead of actually putting genuine effort into the stories of its individual entries.Of course, the less pessimistic version of all this is that Marvel is simply giving its fans what they want. Whether or not it's blatantly motivated by money instead of artistic merit, it's making people happy and that's all that matters. When it comes down to it, there's a lot of truth to that. However, you can please people while still telling a compelling story. I don't think we should accept a sub-par product simply because it scratches the same itch as well-written fan-fiction. To be fair, though, the picture isn't bad. Its flaws are far more relevant in retrospect, even though there's always something that stops you from becoming fully immersed in the experience. In the moment, the flick is fairy fun. It's oddly paced, sure, but it has plenty of diverting set-pieces and unashamedly colourful sets and costumes. The action is often exciting, although it doesn't make as much use of the eponymous characters' healing abilities as I'd like. It's generally fast-paced and filled with nice little moments that showcase the skills of the characters involved. Some of the larger battle scenes are a bit hard to follow because they're really busy and quite unfocused, but even these are peppered with those aforementioned satisfying character moments. The best fight, and highlight of the overall affair, is one set in a car that sees Deadpool and Wolverine tear each other up in a confined space (the utilisation of the environment in this scene is a deciding factor in its superiority over the bouts set on an entirely flat plane). The affair isn't as funny as either of its predecessors, but there are several amusing moments and a generally light tone that keeps you in fairly good spirits throughout. Annoyingly, a lot of the jokes amount to Deadpool simply saying something that the audience understands but nobody else in the scene does, resulting moments in which the characters stand around and wait for him to finish his schtick (or, at most, tell him to shut up). Furthermore, a lot of the humour - including plenty of the visual gags - relies on information only the most die hard fans will possess. Even the best cameos (which, for me, were the ones I didn't know were coming) sort of just happen and then disappear, fairly regularly being dismissed as a form of shock comedy.Although I spoke earlier about how the film has nothing going on beneath its surface, it does try to evoke some pathos from the (very basic) arcs of its two titular characters. The problem is that we've already seen both of them go through almost the exact same emotional journey, and one of those was in 'Logan (2017)' which is so much better than this on every conceivable level that it's almost embarrassing. The most saccharine moments try to cash in on an emotional connection that the picture simply hasn't taken the time to establish, so they end up feeling really false. There's very little emotionality here, despite some commendable work from the lead actors, and the earnestness of the affair is actually somewhat jarring; it doesn't gel with the typically sardonic tone you expect from Deadpool. Still, it's worth hammering home just how good Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are here. This is definitely Reynolds' best character, and it's always a treat to see Jackman (doubly so when he's donning his iconic claws). They do exactly what they need to, making a fairly convincing double act in the process. I just wish they actually got something to sink their teeth into, that their much-awaited team-up wasn't also a multiverse movie concerned more with mining IP than building a narrative of its own. Without them, though, there's no way this would even get made, let alone be as good as it is. The supporting players all do well with what they're given, it's just that they aren't given all that much.Ultimately, the movie is generally fairly fun but undeniably rather empty. It mostly makes good use of its R rating (it's a visceral treat to see its characters tear their enemies - and each other - apart and cuss them out while they do it), even if it doesn't exactly tell a mature tale. There's a sense that it isn't really anything, other than a collection of moments designed to make you point at the screen and say "I remember that!", but it also works well enough as light entertainment that I won't begrudge anyone who says they truly enjoy it. Heck, I even enjoy it (even if it doesn't seem like it). I just don't know how much. It's tempting to say that it's all set up for something later down the line, but it isn't even that really. It's just this bizarre artefact that encapsulates where the movie industry is at the moment, an uncertain time where studio heads seem to be as chronically online as their franchises' most passionate fans and continue to pander in an effort to make more money. As soulless as it may be (despite the genuine care put into it by many of its creators), it is entertaining fluff with some energetic action and a couple of solid (if rather one-note) lead performances. It's good, but it's by no means great. I wish it did more with its premise.

Review: This movie is just wall to wall fun. It has all the hallmarks of a movie made by people who enjoy their craft and want you to enjoy their work.I genuinely get the sense that everyone involved had a blast making this movie and I loved it.Cameos galore, Easter eggs, dripping with meta commentary and fourth wall shattering.Beyond all that, it serves as a pretty decent superhero movie and it must be said that this might just be peak wolverine.Logan was awesome but here I think we got our best wolverine ever.There's some nicely shot action, lots of gore, plenty of ridiculous kills and the movie made me laugh out loud more than many movies have done.I absolutely loved seeing Tyler mane's sabertooth, Wesley snipes playing blade again and a whole litany of original cast members from previous marvel work.It's an absolute riot.

Review: Hmmm. Bit torn on what I thought of this or what rating I should give it.If I am reviewing this with a traditional movie structure in mind, it is a complete fail. It has no real story, no real structure, scenes move from one scene to the next without much continuity or reason and uses these things knowingly.However, this is deadpool and I decided my feelings on the movie should be with that in mind.It is funny. At times really funny. It looks amazing. I'm not a fan of fight scenes usually but these are fantastically choreographed and are really entertaining. Bringing wolverine in, makes no sense and yet paradoxically makes loads of sense, it completely makes the movie and Jackman plays it perfectly.If you go into this wanting to critique it as a movie as the observer did, it's rubbish. If you accept it's a deadpool movie, yeah it's decent, not as good as the first one by a long shot and most probably not even the second but it is a lot of fun and it's entertaining, though I'm not sure it's going to warrant a second viewing.

Review: The Wolverine popcorn bucket was actually better than the movie..So, where do I start? Ah, yes, with the barrage of jokes that are aging faster than Wolverine's hairline. The MCU - sometimes they hit it out of the park, and sometimes, well, they serve up a big ol' dud. Their version of Deadpool? Yeah, that didn't tickle my funny bone. It felt like an endless parade of flashy explosions and cameos, with actual storytelling taking a backseat. Coherent narrative? What's that? But hey, I'm clearly the odd one out here. It made $200 million in just two days and got an A on Cinemascore. Guess I'll just sit here in my minority corner with my bottle of Jack Daniel's.

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine offers a most-refreshing tone to the Marvel Cinematic Universe, crippled after offering a series of quality-questionable, at best, projects that represent a meager attempt at living up to the Avengers Endgame legacy. Nevertheless, this last delivery from the Disney-owned studio is well-aware of all the above, and it does a notable job at dealing with the rampant crisis Marvel faces. While it is true Deadpool and Wolverine manifests a colossal fan-service, worrisome in any other context, it is precisely what the average audience needed the most; a movie that encompasses thrilling action sequences salted with alright humour and a rewarding, yet basic, plot, served as an R-Rated dish reinforced with hefty Disney budget. Undeniably, Deadpool and Wolverine is not a piece of high-end cinema, but only a sublime Super Hero film that ultimately reminds its audience of days gone when the same genre could draw millions into theaters.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine brings back two of the most popular Marvel characters in the titular roles. Ryan Reynolds returns as Deadpool having last appeared in Deadpool 2 (2018) and Hugh Jackman returns as Wolverine having bid farewell to his iconic character in Logan (2017). It was fantastic to see both actors return again. The movie was well worth the hype and it was a great experience from start to finish with plenty of non stop humour and action. A lot of question marks and concerns were going to be raised about the third Deadpool movie after Disney's takeover of 20th Century Fox but there's nothing to worry about at all. There's a lot of crude jokes and blood and gore which Deadpool is well known for.Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) is enjoying making the best of a normal life until he finds himself being thrust back into the action by Mr Paradox (Matthew Macfayden) after being told his current universe is under threat of being wiped out from existence. After reluctantly agreeing to stop the threat, Deadpool also finds himself reluctantly enlisting the help of Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) from another universe who is even more reluctant to join forces with the motormouthed hero. Both Deadpool and Wolverine find them forming an antagonistic alliance to face off against Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin) who is the evil twin of the beloved Charles Xavier aka Professor X.There is going to be no spoilers here, otherwise it will spoil things. Deadpool & Wolverine was great from start to finish. So many laughs, non stop action, lots of jokes and Easter eggs, and Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman made a great on screen duo. It was great to see them back. Deadpool & Wolverine is another great hit in the Marvel series. All fans of Marvel, Deadpool and Wolverine will really enjoy themselves. Have a great time watching the movie, and this is another hit for 2024.8/10.

Review: Greetings from Lithuania."Deadpool & Wolverine" (2024) felt like that third part in the series when creators run out of ideas, so they just threw everything in movie to make it work. It does work enough so I could mildly recommend it but for those looking for a good movie with Wolverine in it - just rewatch Logan instead because this film is pure fan fiction.The many cameos were actually good and I really enjoyed them all. There are plenty jokes that lands, yet plenty that felt flat. Acting was... well I mean what acting? Not much required here. And it's the plot and script that felt draggy and uninspired in this film - it's kinda been there done that and it drags.Overall - plenty of good cameos, some good laughs and action scenes that do work and it's a nice film to recommend it.

Review: Yesterday I went to the theaters to see Deadpool & Wolverine starring Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman and directed by Shawn Levy. In this third installment of the Deadpool series we see Wade (Reynolds) being gifted the opportunity to realize his dreams of becoming one of the Avengers but at the expense of seeing his world destroyed. In true Deadpool fashion, he decides instead to enlist Wolverine to help him save his world and everyone in it. I thoroughly enjoyed the first 2 films and was very excited to see this so I purposely avoided trailers and plot details as best I could.This movie is non-stop fun from the very beginning. It features numerous cameos and countless easter eggs referencing basically every Marvel movie ever made. The chemistry between Jackman and Reynolds is brilliant, and the fight scenes are incredible. The story lacks a little at times but overall, they do a good job of bringing the point home. This movie is pure entertainment and can be best described as the best kind of nerd porn. I absolutely loved it and recommend seeing it while it is still in theaters.

I wish the TVA would just go away. I will say this is the best Marvel movie in a long time. I'm not sure this is going to save the marvel universe but it is a step in the right direction.There were some interesting implications from everything that took place.

Review: TLDR: It's pretty good. Not mind altering or moving but fun escapism.The Good: Hugh Jackman as Wolverine and all the surprises.The Bad: Deadpool gets to be a bit much but, like that's his thing so you get what you order by buying the ticket.I will watch all the Marvel movies. They have my number and I know it. I like to unplug from the news and embrace the escapism. We all need escapism from time to time.The title of this movie says it all. If you have seen the Deadpool movies or the X-Men series and Wolverine spinoff this one is for you. I would guess you don't need to have seen all the movies in all the series to have fun with this one but I'm so deep in the cult it's tough to say.The writing was a little weak and formulaic but it was a comic book action movie that makes fun of its self while trying to say something about needing purpose and recognizing what drives purpose.Hugh Jackman as Wolverine was so fun to see again. He nails the role so well and they wrote his character best.If somehow you missed the spoilers, the twists and turns and cameos are fun.Deadpool's madness is more noticeable as he enters the MCU. It was fun to see the merc with the mouth go on another adventure. He really pushes buttons in this one but that's who the character is.I would have liked to have seen a little more screen time for some of the auxiliary characters in this movie.

Review: This review was made a few days after watching the movie and in all honesty, it was amazing which is expected from a "Deadpool" movie after the first two.I was excited as to how they will introduce the story of brining back wolverine and it was done nicely enough to not think too much about it, finally seeing deadpool and wolverine on the big screen together is crazy, the chemistry between ryan reynolds and hugh jackman was perfect, as well as finally and officially making deadpool join the MCU which could save it from the continuous downfall it is having for the past few years with some exceptions.This movie is definitely a comedy but some drama scenes including logan, hugh jackman did a great job although some characters were under utilized which would've increased the emotions involved within those scenes.The villain was below average and I would've liked more taking into consideration what we know of the villain.Everytime we watch a deadpool movie, we get barraged with easter eggs, references and a lot of breaking the 4th wall jokes which are the best part of the movie as a whole, if you're into the marvel universe and not just that but also following the social issues involving entertainment industries and much more, you'll find the movie more enjoyable and the jokes way funnier, the more you know the more you'll have fun is what i'll name this experience.Amazing and unexpected guest cameos as well.It is a definitely a must watch.

Only haters will give this less than a 9. We've all been waiting for this way too long. Not only does this movie provide well, but it set up the rest of Marvel to move Forward again. Between the Avengers and X-men world to the Deadpool franchise being stronger than ever, this is a must see. I thought that the abundance of trailers was going to spoil the movie but you will see that there is just too much great content. If there's a movie to see, this is it.

Review: Deadpool arrives with a blast of comedy, action, drama and pure heart that lives up to the hype. It's also a surprisingly nostalgic movie, a love letter and fond farewell to all those Marvel linked movies that preceded the MCU. A reminder that past movies did have the magic to captivate us long before RDJ was ever cast as Iron Man.We can't predict what the MCU will bring, or if it will survive the depths it has sank into post-Endgame, but Deadpool & Wolverine are a throwback to subtle CGI, fantastically choreographed fight scenes/stuntwork, and epic storytelling.You will watch it dozens of times.

Review: I have seen Deadpool and Wolverine a total of three times in the past week. Somehow I still want to watch it over and over. I find something new to love every time I watch it again. The humor is some of the best movie humor I have seen in a very long time. The jokes are actually laughable and some of them are quite unbelievable and my jaw was on the floor. The music was practically perfect in every way. It made some of the scenes so unforgettable that I can perfectly in-vision them in my head when I hear the songs. Deadpool and Wolverine was so worth the wait and I cannot wait to see where the story goes next!

Review: I know this probably isn't a popular opinion but i was left rather disappointed after seeing this.For starters, i like Ryan Reynolds as an actor but I'm pretty tired of his scripts with some sort of gag or joke every few lines. I get that it's inkeeping with the character but it would help if the majority of those were funny but they rarely are & it just feels so forced. Again, I'm not against comedic moments or jokes & it did make me laugh a few times, it's just that i laughed far, far less than it really wanted or expected me to.To be honest, the best moments of the film were either it's few serious moments courtesy of Hugh & his great acting or the large scale fight scenes that were done well. I was also pleasantly surprised with Emma Corrin.The film is very much Deadpool & Wolverine in that it mostly forgets about all the other characters that played a big part in the previous films, leaving it to feel pretty disjointed from them.Overall, the film felt mostly forgettable & essentially, it was just another throwaway story set in the overused & underutilised multiverse.

Review: I think the film is good and very unique, especially for the actor Deadpool who makes me feel a very pleasant vibe. The chemistry between Deadpool and Wolfrine is also quite good, where Deadpool is very talkative and Wolfrine is very angry.As a Marvel fan, I quite enjoyed this film, starting from the soundtrack which was very cool and suited Deadpool. Really a very entertaining fan service film. However, my advice for those of you who are not Marvel fans is to watch the film series before Deadpool, the Logan film, and the Loki series. As well as understanding Fox's dispute with Disney because you will understand 70% of the jokes in this film if you have done what I mentioned.Because if you don't, you definitely won't understand the jokes and the storyline will make you confused. However, in my opinion, the soundtrack and action photography are the best and can be enjoyed by everyoneIt's really a very fun, unique and fresh film with wild ideas.

Review: In all honesty I came into this movie expecting huge things. I'm a major fan of the other 2 deadpools with a pretty much perfect blend of comedy story and action. However in this one I didn't feel that blend as much. LOTS of the jokes were funny don't get me wrong but it almost felt they were doing too much sometimes or just unnecessarily, almost like thor love and thunder. The action I'll be honest I liked a lot,all the fight sequences were epic and were one of the highlights of the film. But my biggest disappointment was the story. Don't get me wrong in no way am I saying the story was bad but just kinda messy. Ik it's supposed to be a multiverse movie and everything but I felt like it became too diatached from what mad the other deadpools great. But in no way am I saying this movie is rubbish. It was both funny and enjoyable and I loved all the cameos and wolverine in this. I just wish they'd had kept some more themes of the other deadpools. In no work is this movie a six but nor a seven. It's good but nothing really more.

Review: It felt like watching an episode of Friends, funny at times and forgotten a second after it ended. I was very disappointed, the group that made the film aimed as low as possible, we will make you laugh with shallow jokes and not invest a second in emotion, plot depth, character development, we will also bring some characters from decades ago that will make you feel nostalgic, in short tricks of laziness and disdain for the audience. It's really sad to me that the audience buys this deception. Just like it was with Spider-Man - there is no way home, it worked for them, it worked for them even now. For me it was the reminder that the fun of the early years of MCU will unfortunately not return.

Review: Directed & Co-Written by Shawn Levy, the movie follows Wade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) seeks to lead a quiet life away from his past as Deadpool. However, everything takes an unexpected turn when the TVA takes him to help them save the timeline. He then recruits the Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), the only person he hopes that could help.It seems evident that the introduction of X-Men/Mutants into the MCU was planned in the context of the multiverse concept for the next saga. Even though I like the idea, I can't help but think that Marvel's decision to bring back a character with a definitive ending might be seen as a desperate move. However, given that the multiverse and variants will be central themes for phase four to six, I have no doubt that they will manage to make it work somehow. Considering the mixed reception of the current and last phases, I was afraid they would botch this up again. Thankfully, I was wrong.Deadpool & Wolverine is far from perfect, but it does provide a theater experience that people have missed since Spider-Man: No Way Home. However, if you start to think deeply about where the movie fit in the Fox timeline after the events in Days of Future Past and some pretty significant plot holes (I hope you don't), the movie starts to fall apart. I don't think those would be a big problem though. I see it as merely a continuation problem in the script because this movie is supposed to be a standalone one. Besides, it's actually a great redemption arc story for the characters. Deadpool finally gets to be the hero he always wanted to be, while Wolverine, who has let his entire kind down, has the opportunity to save countless others.After watching all the previous X-Men movies, it's finally safe to say that Hugh Jackman delivered the best performance as the beloved character he portrayed for 24 years. That one scene really stood out, and it was great to finally see him in the iconic suit. Ryan Reynolds did a great job as the Merc with a Mouth, but I feel like he wasn't quite at the same level as in Deadpool 2.All in all, Deadpool & Wolverine is like a prayer that people have been praying for years, and when it's finally here, it just feels like home.

Review: I know, i know...I'm gonna see all the hate for rating this an 8, but hey, it ain't Oppenheimer after all.Love Jackman, and often like Reynolds. Enjoyed the first Deadpool, did not enjoy the second.This film succeeds because instead of parading around new, obscure superheroes, and trying desperately to advance a feminist orientation, it plays what started the whole metaverse to begin with: classic superhero dudes creating mayhem and wisecracking through and through.I'm over the Ryan Reynolds shtick for the most part. It sometimes lands, but often blurs the other tones necessary to sustain a two hour movie.Lots of cameos, lots of callbacks.So, highly recommend, unless your prior favorite movie was Mary Poppins or Bring It On.

Review: Good movie .Here's a 600-word movie review that covers Deadpool (2016) and Logan (2017), focusing on their impact on the superhero genre and the performances of Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman as Wolverine.Movie Review: Deadpool (2016) and Logan (2017)The superhero genre has seen its fair share of evolution over the years, with movies ranging from light-hearted escapades to darker, more introspective tales. Deadpool (2016) and Logan (2017) stand out as two films that pushed the boundaries of what superhero movies could be, each in its own unique way. While Deadpool brought a fresh and irreverent take to the genre, Logan delivered a gritty, emotional farewell to one of its most iconic characters.Deadpool: A Game-Changer in Superhero ComedyDirected by Tim Miller and starring Ryan Reynolds as the titular character, Deadpool was a breath of fresh air in a genre that was beginning to feel formulaic. The film's success was largely due to its willingness to break the fourth wall, its R-rated humor, and its self-awareness. Ryan Reynolds, who had been attached to the character of Deadpool for years, finally got the chance to do justice to the "Merc with a Mouth," and he delivered in spades.Reynolds' performance is the heart and soul of Deadpool. He effortlessly blends sarcasm, wit, and vulnerability, making Deadpool one of the most memorable characters in the superhero pantheon. The film's plot is relatively straightforward, focusing on Wade Wilson's quest for revenge after being subjected to a rogue experiment that leaves him with accelerated healing powers but a disfigured appearance. What sets Deadpool apart, however, is its tone. The film revels in its irreverence, poking fun at superhero tropes, the X-Men franchise, and even Reynolds' own career missteps.The film's action sequences are as kinetic as they are humorous, with Deadpool's acrobatics and swordplay providing a visual treat. But it's the script, co-written by Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick, that truly shines. The dialogue is sharp, filled with quips and pop culture references that land more often than not. Deadpool doesn't take itself too seriously, and that's precisely what makes it so enjoyable. It's a film that embraces the absurdity of its premise and runs with it, resulting in a wildly entertaining ride that redefined what a superhero movie could be.Logan: A Heart-Wrenching FarewellIn stark contrast to Deadpool's irreverence, Logan (2017) is a somber, emotionally charged film that serves as a fitting conclusion to Hugh Jackman's 17-year tenure as Wolverine. Directed by James Mangold, Logan is set in a dystopian future where mutants are nearly extinct, and an aging Logan is struggling with the weight of his past. The film's tone is grim, reflective, and deeply human, offering a raw and unflinching look at the toll that years of violence have taken on the once-indestructible Wolverine.Hugh Jackman delivers a career-defining performance as Logan, portraying the character with a depth and vulnerability that had only been hinted at in previous films. His portrayal of a weary, broken man who is forced to confront his own mortality is both powerful and heartbreaking. Patrick Stewart is equally compelling as Charles Xavier, whose once-great mind is deteriorating due to a neurodegenerative disease. The relationship between Logan and Xavier forms the emotional core of the film, and their scenes together are some of the most poignant in the superhero genre.Logan eschews the typical superhero formula in favor of a more grounded, character-driven narrative. The film's violence is brutal and unrelenting, serving as a stark reminder of the consequences of a life spent fighting. But amidst the bloodshed, Logan is ultimately a story about redemption and the search for peace. The introduction of Laura, a young mutant with powers similar to Logan's, adds another layer to the film's exploration of legacy and the passing of the torch.

Review: It's a good movie. But not one of those I'll be able to watch 5 times a year like the others.Fantastic ending to deadpool, even tho I hope there will be more. A slight different style than the first two - tho I can't really put my finger on what they had that this one was missing.The fight scenes were amazing as always. The references to other movies, real life individuals + the cameos gave the movie an extra spark! It broke the forth wall a bit too much, but at the same time; it's deadpool, so it was expected.The sensitivity and emotions in this movie gave another feel to both deadpool and wolverine that I have missed in earlier movies.Overall it's a great movie, something nice to watch on a slow and tired Sunday.

Review: When the very first scene of the movie has Deadpool digging out Wolverine's decomposing corpse from "Logan" and using it to fight a bunch of NPCs, you know you're in for something irreverent and fun. And fun, of which the movie has plenty. It's true that over the years, people have grown accustomed to Ryan Reynolds' style of humor, which since the popularity of the first "Deadpool" movie, has followed him around into every other movie he makes. But there's always something special when Ryan delivers the same obnoxious 'c*ck-and-b*lls' jokes wearing that loveable red suit.What convinced us all to go to the cinemas and check this movie out after the years of being sick of superhero movies however, is not Deadpool in and of itself, but the addition of Hugh Jackman's Wolverine to the mix. It's a character so beloved and one we can almost never picture anyone else in, and this movie is further proof as to why. It's a pairing that we knew would always work out well, and unsurprisingly it does. It's the banter between Deadpool and Logan that makes this movie as fun and enjoyable as it is, and credit to both actors whose chemistry was the best thing about this movie.All that being said, we're once again back to the inevitable Marvel problem of having a paper thin script which has the now banal world ending stakes it always has. It's something that has been overplayed so much that it even makes a Deadpool movie somewhat tedious. It's a Deadpool movie, so sure you're about to expect some silliness sprinkled around, but where you don't want to see it is in the blueprint of the script. And unfortunately, that's where it is, with the laziness and the lethargy of Marvel's writing department sticking around like a sore thumb.It's a movie full of banter and cameos and while that makes for an amazing theater-going experience, it's not enough to warrant longevity. The cameos are surprising, but only the first time you watch it, and that probably makes this movie the weakest of the three Deadpool movies. All criticism aside though, it's a movie worth checking out for sure while the hype is still on, because it's not going to be as fun once it's out on digital, when everyone knows what surprises to expect.

Review: I'm a huge fan of the Wolverine films and like Hugh Jackman as an actor and person. That's the only reason I decided to watch this, as I've always found Ryan Reynolds a bit meh and was not into the Deadpool films.It's always struck me that Ryan thinks he's 100 times funnier than he actually is and that is super-amplified here. I didn't laugh once at any of his quips. They're non-stop and don't contain an ounce of wit. It just gets really tedious and annoying especially in that sarcastic, smug voice.But at least beneath the stupid jokes in the previous Deadpool films, particularly the first, there is an actual dramatic plot that is interesting to watch. This was a complete mess. The initial idea sounded interesting in the beginning but it failed to deliver on the story it promised.It's a weird mish-mash of other ideas already done over and over. I'd already been bored out of my head with the time variance plot in Loki, which they've used here as a means of getting hold of a multiverse Wolverine. There's a scene with 100 various Deadpools which we've already seen in Spiderman. And as others have said, it draws massively on other films from X-men, Marvel and other franchises to make up it's story because there's nothing to the plot. The dramatic element is drawn from your reaction to relevant moments from those films. There's not one original concept. And the fact that it's drawing on so much ultimately results in it not knowing what it's really trying to do. Thus, what ends up being the focus are the jokes, gore, fight scenes, cameos and special effects.The cameos didn't bring anything to the film. Jennifer Garner, Wesley Snipes and Dafne Keen played their roles well, but it didn't go anywhere or do anything. Weirdly Chris Evans seemed to be playing Cap rather than Johnny Storm?! And why on earth was Channing Tatum, Gambit?! And "Cavillrine" was just stupid.I like gory fight scenes, that didn't bother me, I was bothered by the fact that it's pointless and boring to watch because there isn't anything at stake. Deadpool and Wolverine constantly fighting throughout got incredibly tiring; I expected this film to be about the two of them grudgingly working together towards a mutual cause, whilst annoying the crap out of each other, the only time they actually did team up was at the end.About the only saving grace was the female villain who played Charles Xavier's sister; she was brilliant but it was wasted talent.Although I'd lowered my expectations accordingly with it being a film led by Deadpool, it managed to be worse than that bar. It's just a real damn shame that Hugh Jackman reprised a brilliant, iconic character for this rubbish. He at least, delivered, as you'd expect him to, but it was for nothing.I'm not the type to 1-star something to make up for all the high ratings on a film that is clearly awful, but I was sorely tempted with this. 3 for Hugh and the villain.

Review: Simply awesomeoe movie, A complete package of Action and comedy. Marvel Reloaded."Deadpool & Wolverine," the latest blockbuster superhero film, is an exhilarating, action-packed rollercoaster that masterfully blends humor, high-octane action, and deep character moments. Directed by [Director's Name], this film offers a fresh take on the beloved characters, Deadpool and Wolverine, who have captivated audiences for years.From the opening scene, the film establishes its tone: irreverent, witty, and explosively dynamic. The plot kicks off with Deadpool, portrayed with trademark charisma by Ryan Reynolds, and Wolverine, brought to life once again by Hugh Jackman, finding themselves in an unlikely team-up. The premise revolves around a complex conspiracy involving a shadowy organization that threatens global security, forcing these two unlikely heroes into an uneasy alliance.The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman is palpable and arguably one of the film's strongest assets. Reynolds' Deadpool is a masterclass in comedic timing and fourth-wall-breaking brilliance. His humor is relentless and often absurd, creating a constant stream of laughs that never feels forced. Meanwhile, Jackman's Wolverine is as brooding and intense as ever, but this film allows him to explore a more vulnerable side. The dynamic between Deadpool's relentless jokiness and Wolverine's gruff seriousness leads to some of the film's most memorable moments, with their banter providing a perfect counterpoint to the high stakes of their mission.The film's screenplay is sharp and engaging, with clever dialogue and a well-paced plot that keeps the audience invested from start to finish. The writers strike a delicate balance between humor and action, ensuring that neither element overshadows the other. The story is driven by strong character motivations, and the interactions between Deadpool and Wolverine offer both comedic relief and emotional depth. This character development adds layers to the typical superhero narrative, making the film not just an action spectacle but a story about two characters finding common ground despite their differences.Visually, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a feast for the eyes. The action sequences are expertly choreographed and executed with a flair that showcases the unique abilities of both heroes. From Wolverine's berserker rages to Deadpool's acrobatic combat style, the fight scenes are thrilling and inventive. The special effects are top-notch, creating visually stunning set pieces that enhance the story rather than distract from it. The film's color palette and cinematography further contribute to its overall vibrant and energetic aesthetic.The supporting cast also deserves commendation. The film introduces several new characters who add depth to the story, each bringing their own unique flair to the narrative. The antagonists are well-developed, providing a credible threat that challenges both Deadpool and Wolverine. Their motivations are clear and compelling, making the stakes feel real and immediate.Musically, the soundtrack complements the film's tone perfectly. The score is dynamic and exciting, enhancing the emotional and action-packed moments. The use of popular music tracks is both nostalgic and fitting, adding an extra layer of engagement for viewers."Deadpool & Wolverine" is not just a superhero film; it's a celebration of the genre's potential to entertain and provoke thought. It excels in blending humor with heart, action with introspection, and spectacle with substance. The film reaffirms Deadpool's place as a comedic anti-hero and Wolverine's status as a complex, brooding warrior. Together, they make for a formidable and entertaining duo.In conclusion, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a triumph of superhero cinema, offering a perfect mix of humor, action, and character-driven storytelling. It's a must-see for fans of the genre and newcomers alike, promising an unforgettable experience that showcases the best of both characters. The film not only lives up to its hype but exceeds it, making it a standout entry in the superhero genre.

Review: If ever there was a critic proof movie, then "Deadpool and Wolverine" surely is it. A fourth wall breaking, in-joking, buddy comedy, which bizarrely serves as a romantic finale to both the good and the terrible of defunct Fox/Marvel world.The Time Variance Authority remove Wade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) from his timeline and offer him a place on Earth-616, as Wilson's timeline has been slowly dying since the death of its "anchor being" Logan (Hugh Jackman). Using his Deadpool superhero persona, Wilson decides to save his timeline by recruiting another Logan to take his place, eventually securing a drunken failed version of him. Mr Paradox (Matthew MacFadyen) a TVA middle manager, is tired of slowly watching timelines die though and instead plans to use a device to speed up the process.It unquestionably is a case of style over substance, a rapid scattershot cavalcade of sex jokes, swearwords, references, and cameos. Occasionally, I do think that Reynolds takes the character into the realm of annoying, but I would say the majority of the time he's just about threading the needle. Jackman gets to play the straight man (in every sense) alongside the motormouth Wilson. Their fight scenes are fun, and for the most part look reasonably good, save for some dodgy CGI in the multi-Deadpool battle.Talking about the cameos is a bit too close to spoiler territory, so I'll pull away from that, but it's interesting that it finds a way to include movies that were never even made in the film. I made a special effort to avoid spoilers as much as I could going in, so some of the reveals were truly delightful to me. I would say that perhaps this offered Marvel a chance to put an end to the multiverse saga, that seems to be floundering under the weight of disgraced actors and a general sense that nothing happening in these films has consequence, if you can always pull another version of a character from the multiverse to replace the one you lost. However, the comiccon announcement seems to suggest they're embracing, rather than shying away from that.Its' a thinner and more inconsequential plot than I would have hoped for, but it's a fun ride whilst you're on it. Will Deadpool get to exist in the wider MCU now, we'll have to wait and see?

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine is the third film in the trilogy. The first 2 films were quite successful, garnering excellent box office and good ratings from the audience. Many people remember them because of: rather vulgar and black humor, breaking the fourth wall, unexpected fanservice, excessive cruelty and of course the magnificent Ryan Reynolds. The third part in this regard does not lag behind its predecessors, I will say more - to some extent it surpassed them. And although the film is very different from the first two, it still has a similar structure, but of course there are differences, and in some moments colossal. Perhaps it was thanks to them that the third part was remembered much more vividly, but of course you should not forget that this time the film is not only about Deadpool, but also about Wolverine, which attracts all the eyes of the audience. Hugh Jackman is as beautiful as ever in the image of Wolverine, giving out another great performance. We have been waiting for his return for more than 7 years, and for good reason, because the character came out quite interesting. It was a pleasure to follow his relationship with the main character, and the cherry on the cake was his backstory. On top of everything else, I was pleased with the canonical costume and that legendary mask, it is clear that the films were shot with a soul, wanting to give fans the very multiverse of madness that everyone had dreamed of for so long. Perfectly matched music, slow mo action, the return of old characters and the insane appearance of other unexpected (sometimes insane) cameos are the soul of this film, and the warm and touching ending warms the heart. The film fully met my expectations and gave me a lot of positive emotions, which means that it works, of course it has disadvantages, but for me personally, the main disadvantage was not the greatest timing, and the rest is no longer important.

Review: To say that the MCU has been in a slow decline would be an understatement. MCU fans have been calling out for a 'Marvel Messiah' to rescue the falling franchise. In comes Deadpool & Wolverine.The whole movie lives up to its hype and did not disappoint one bit. From unhinged dark humour comedies to some interesting cameo's.One can say thank to Kevin Fiegie for listening to Marvel fans ! But we should also thank Fox for their own services and aid in providing all access to their marvel characters! (Sony please take note).Now to summarise. Yes, I would highly recommend seeing the movie. In someway and possibly arguably the best top 3 MCU film, if not number one but I'll let you decide that !

Thankfully Borat didn't make a cameo appearance.

Review: The long wait is over. And we finally have the 3rd installment of Deadpool but this time it's going to be under Marvel / Disney. This Deadpool sequel is the first rated R film from any Disney Marvel film and they were able to pull it off nicely overall.The story follows Wade's story from the ending of Deadpool 2 as he tries to search for some place where he can matter again. As the years went by, he was recruited by the TVA for a not so pleasant mission which lead him to different Earths to team up with a Wolverine variant to save his own doomed future. The film is full with action sequences specially the bloody fight scenes between Wolverine and Deadpool. The film was still able to pull off a good plot with good message but I guess what really brings this sequel to the next level are those cameos we did not see coming mixed with those we expected to see and they did not disappoint.Comparing to first DP films, this feels better than Deadpool 2. If you're a movie goer, a Marvel fan, a comic fan, you'll enjoy this movie and the wait is totally worth it. (You can see those bones and blood flying to you when you're in IMAX). And oh the soundtrack is probably the best from the three filmsCameos +++++ Story ++++ Action +++++ Humor +++ Soundtrack +++++The credits was a nice touch to Marvel Foxverse#deadpoolandwolverine is 8.5/10. I love it from start to very end"Everyone wants to matter. Turns out you don't have to be someone else to do it. You just need to open your eyes and look around. And if you're lucky, you'll find a few friends."

Review: And as of July 2024, Deadpool and Wolverine is the newest instalment in the pantheon of Marvel movies. This time though, Deadpool steps out of the 20th Century Fox universe and squarely into the Disney controlled Marvel MCU. If you don't know what any of that means, just type it all into google and see what comes out..In Deadpool and Wolverine, Ryan Reynolds drags Hugh Jackman kicking and screaming through an array of carnage, in-jokes, timelines and movie references. Chock full of cameos of past marvel characters who either briefly or never existed, this is a comic book movie fan's wet dream. If you are not a fan of any of this stuff, then this movie is not going to make any sense whatsoever, you will be completely lost as there is not much a plot to speak of.

Review: The first and second *Deadpool* movies had something truly special. The first film introduced us to the gritty, gruesome origin of Deadpool, and its dark tone was perfectly balanced with a fresh, comical, anything-goes style of production that we had never seen before. Ryan Reynolds nailed the role. By the time *Deadpool 2* arrived, fans were hungry for more of that same style, and not only did it deliver, but it also gave us a compelling plot with the introduction of Cable, played by Josh Brolin.However, this third movie seems to miss the mark completely. While Ryan's comedic performance is once again a highlight-and arguably the best part of the movie-after a while, the jokes start to wear thin and even become annoying. There's a time and place for everything, but in this film, it feels like nothing was taken seriously. And because Deadpool didn't take anything seriously, neither did we, which ultimately detracted from the entire experience.The cameos were fantastic, but the story itself fell flat. It was so poorly constructed that it felt like it was written by AI. I would even go so far as to say it's one of the worst plots in Marvel history. It made no sense from the beginning, and it's a shame they dragged a complex character like Wolverine into this mess.In the end, the film was dull, predictable, and annoyingly funny-not in the good way the first two were.

Review: Obviously a lot of fan service came with this one, but it's done a good way. Humor was top notch, chemistry between Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds was off the charts, action was great and story was satisfying. One of the best things was the soundtrack, all certified bangers. All the cameos were reaply nice and nothing felt forced to me. If i had to point a bad thing - or more like a less good thing - it's the antagonist. Without spoiling it, we pretty much have two antagonists, one i didnt mind and actually provided a lot of (even more) comic relief, but the other one was kinda meh. Not bad, just meh. But again, wouldnt call it bad tho.Also good performances by Ryan and Hugh, but especially Hugh, there are a couple of scenes where he went all out.Catch this one in the theater!

Review: Well, it's worth waiting for!The movie is great with a combination of unfiltered jokes and unexpected action scenes. Also, it makes my nostalgic feelings better by seeing my favorite childhood characters.This movie is one that fans have been eagerly anticipating for a long time, and it does not disappoint. The story is engaging and keeps you hooked from start to finish. The blend of humor and action is perfect, creating a balance that keeps the audience entertained throughout. The jokes are fresh and funny, often catching you off guard with their wit and timing. The action scenes are well-choreographed and thrilling, providing plenty of excitement.One of the highlights of the movie is its ability to evoke nostalgia. Seeing beloved characters from my childhood brought back so many memories. It was a delight to see how these characters have been adapted for the big screen, maintaining their original charm while also fitting into the modern setting. The filmmakers have done a fantastic job of respecting the source material while also bringing something new to the table.The performances are another strong point. The cast is excellent, with each actor bringing their character to life in a way that feels both authentic and engaging. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, making their interactions feel genuine and heartfelt. Whether it's the lead actors or the supporting cast, everyone delivers performances that contribute to the overall success of the movie.The visual effects and cinematography are top-notch as well. The movie is visually stunning, with beautiful landscapes, impressive special effects, and a vibrant color palette that brings the story to life. The action sequences are particularly well done, with smooth transitions and clear visuals that make them easy to follow. The attention to detail in the visual presentation adds another layer of enjoyment to the experience.The soundtrack deserves a mention too. The music complements the scenes perfectly, enhancing the emotional impact of key moments and adding to the overall atmosphere. Whether it's an intense action scene or a touching emotional moment, the soundtrack helps to elevate the experience and draw the audience further into the story.Overall, this movie is a fantastic experience that offers something for everyone. Whether you're a long-time fan of the characters or new to the story, you'll find plenty to enjoy. The combination of humor, action, and nostalgia creates a unique and enjoyable experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression. The wait was definitely worth it, and I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a great time at the theater.In summary, this movie excels in many areas. The humor is sharp and well-timed, the action is exciting and well-executed, and the nostalgic elements add a wonderful layer of depth. The performances are strong across the board, and the visual and audio elements are top-notch. It's a movie that will make you laugh, keep you on the edge of your seat, and tug at your heartstrings all at once. If you're looking for a movie that offers a bit of everything, this one is definitely worth checking out.So, if you haven't seen it yet, make sure to grab your tickets and head to the theater. You won't be disappointed. This movie is a great addition to any movie lover's collection and a fantastic way to spend a couple of hours. Enjoy the ride!

Review: Watched it yesterday on the big screen. It was ... well, yeah it was fun. But a very flawed fun that could have been way better. The action was great, even if Deadpool would not constantly have pointed out that the action is great. The brawling match between the two protagonists was fun to watch, but in the end both are pretty much immortal and none of the fights really mattered so the whole thing was kind of ... dare I say it - boring. Not once was I emotionaly attached to anyone in this picture. All the cool stuff of the first movies, like 4th wall breaks, the ultra-violence and the dick and ass jokes were simply too much. After an hour or so the film just started to reference itself over and over again. I could also not quite follow the time-line story with multiverse yadda yadda. And between all the dick jokes and the 500th 4th wall break were some supposedly serious moments, but since everything seems to be a joke in this movie even these serious scenes felt too artificial.The weakesst point imho is that there is never any urgency or real threat. All characters are just mocking images of themselfs now who constantly fight NPCs who do not matter - at all.All the meta stuff going on, like mocking Fox and Disney, the millions of eastereggs, the constant talking to the audience, the critics of marvel movies(!) might have worked for me, but am I expected to know production notes now in order to get the joke? Come on. As a movie it's a five for me, but I'll add a point for trying hard to be something on its own. I do really hope this will be the tombstone of Marvel. What else could there be mocked, referenced, pointed out or milked? It's like eating at McD: You leave with a full stomach but it's never satisfying food - or food in general.

Review: No spoilers! But let's just clear this up right at the beginning: this movie is basically 95% fan service. And if you buy into that (like I did) then you will have a fantastic time. If you don't (or if you hate Deadpool as a character) then you probably won't enjoy it as much.Aside from that though, the thing that I enjoyed most about the movie is that Deadpool feels much more like he should. I love Deadpool 1 and 2, but he always kind of felt like he stuck out in those worlds. Yeah it's the same universe as X-Men, but it felt like they wouldn't let him get TOO comic booky (and in the second movie he basically doesn't fourth wall break at all, it's just snark and pop culture references). But here though, they let it all fly, and it works brilliantly.There's fourth wall breaking, ridiculous (in a good way) fight scenes, and just general over-the-top shenanigans for the entire runtime. There's still lots of meta humor, lots of shots at Disney and Fox, but I enjoyed it. I had so much fun with this movie and haven't laughed that much in a long time.As for issues (aside from the fan service), it does feel like Deadpool gets a little sidelined at times. The movie tries to balance both him and Wolverine, and sometimes it's a little weighted in Wolverine's favor. The emotional stakes are also fairly shallow. Yeah it has them and tries to justify them (and Wolverine actually gets some good development), but it's nothing you haven't seen before and isn't going to blow you away.So if you go into this expecting Logan, you're going to be severely disappointed. But if you go in expecting a shameless fan-service filled action romp, then you'll have a grand time.

Review: I cannot understand why this movie is so highly rated. I have found it to be very disappointing. It looks cheap, with flat cinematography and with the sets that look like they were filmed in a garage or at a construction site. The movie basically looks like it was made for TV and streaming. The storyline is dumb, and it borrows heavily from previous Marvel tropes, ideas and cliches about multiverse blah blah. Because neither Deadpool nor Wolverine can be killed in a conventional sense the action and the fight scenes have no real stakes or tension, and they look cartoonish. Deadpool's constant verbal diarrhea quickly gets boring and exhausting, even if it contains a decent joke every few minutes. The "inside jokes" about Disney, Fox or Kevin Feige didn't work for me. Wolverine is one-note throughout the entire movie - serious and pissed off. The Marvel cameos are strictly for Marvel nerds, they didn't impress me much. Overall I didn't really enjoy this movie.

Review: It's crazy...no exaggeration, and really take my "bleh-ness" about media overall (and especially superhero stuff), even The Boys's dark satire, into account when I say this - the meta-mea-culpa, unfiltered, unmetered insanity-mixed-with-genuine-heart-and-emotion of Deadpool & Wolverine is legitimately incredible. Insanely entertaining, and timeline-breakingly heartening and affirming. I was so ready to hate away - I've been conditioned to. But genuinely, the best superhero-genre film since, I feel like saying Dark Knight. That's at least how I feel right now. So many Disney/MCU meta-self-stabs, worth the ticket price alone. Ryan got full control of everything said, it's very clear. I'll call it now that it's making over 2B - this catharsis of 'superhero films are just bad nowadays aren't they' growing since Endgame, *actually* addressed in the film. Tight editing too, and Matt McFadyen nails it. A lot of fun had making it, it's clear. So much laughter and cheering in the packed cinema - an audience that felt seen and met where they are, frustrated/tired/jaded/confused, instead of bludgeoned obliviously/arrogantly yet again with another confusing overwrought MCU slog. This film is *with* the audience, and (without any spoilers) literally kills all the confusion and bloat of the past 5 years in one swoop. You'll genuinely love it. I'd love to go see it again. It's actually insane - the film would literally not be as effective or entertaining if Marvel *hadn't* bloat-fested and over-indulged for the past few years, because the fact they actually did that (and messed up as bad as they have) *made* this film. The conceit is so clever, it makes it feel like all that was intentional, just to justify this film and its premise of meta-apologising/meta-scrapping-and-starting again. Genuinely impressed - if this is the last MCU film I watch I'll be truly glad of it. If they keep up this quality though, and stop funding/favouring harmful entities, we could actually return to pre-Endgame levels of appreciation for the genre. I would love them to see how much people appreciate their mistake-owning in film form, so that they make actually mistake-owning and apologising moves in real life. One can hope!

Review: When you go see a Deadpool movie you know what you're in for, or at least I do. For me it's kind of a one-time deal that's filled with sophomoric humor, gags, some good action and that's that. But this basically amps it up an another notch or two and it gets a little tedious towards the end. It's also openly sacrilegious so just know that going in. Hugh Jackman is very good in it though and there were some pretty funny gags at times. For me it all just got to be too much as the film progressed. I don't really regret having seen it but probably won't watch it again. This should be the last standalone Deadpool film in my opinion.

Review: Now I understand the very simple title and the short runtime..guys ,this is not a huge pivotal MCU movie..it's basically celebrating deadpool and wolverine plus the old x-men movies..for some people that was a bad deal..but for me it was worth it because I had a blast with this movie !..the cameos are awesome , action scenes with epic music are top tier as usual , a few times I was laughing out loud..deadpool is a little washed out and exhausted , but wolverine..wolverine MADE this movie !..every fight scene with him is just goosebumps , whenever it gets stale or the tone gets too silly , wolverine even things out..the only thing bad about this movie is that it's too short..I swear when it was near the end I checked the time and I was like on no they're gonna wrap it up now and I really wanted it to go on..especially since I feel like this movie was cut a little and a lot of cameos are missing !..but in the end ,what can I say..there will never be a bad deadpool movie..and Hugh Jackman as wolverine will never stop being epic..I was entertained..a 10 for me.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" offers a mixed bag of entertainment, capturing some of the zany charm that fans of Deadpool have come to expect, largely thanks to Ryan Reynolds' comedic flair and the numerous cameos sprinkled throughout the film. These elements certainly inject a dose of fun and levity, making the movie enjoyable in parts.However, the movie falls short compared to the classic Marvel films of earlier days. The storyline is thin, with the inclusion of the TVA and the multiverse feeling more confusing and irritating than exciting. The villain, a rather bland and underdeveloped character, lacks depth and screen time, failing to leave a lasting impression.Despite these flaws, "Deadpool & Wolverine" manages to surpass the likes of "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness" and "Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania," and is certainly a step up from "Ms. Marvel." Nevertheless, it's clear that Marvel/Disney has the potential to deliver much better.

Review: I loved Deadpool and I loved Wolverine and I loved all the cameos and the jokes and the fight scenes... BUT.. The story was so lame........The movie was very enjoyable but it felt like they came up with just any story to make the movie happen. It lacked the appeal of the first two Deadpool movies. There was nothing at stake and it just felt like the kind of lazy writing Deadpool mocked in the first movie. A superhero movie is only as good as its villain and despite Emma Corrin's great performance the movie didn't really do her character justice.This movie was mostly about fan service, as a fan myself, I think they delivered 100%. I just wish they put more effort into writing a great story as much as they did servicing the fans.

Review: I absolutely loved the first Deadpool-it was witty, funny, intelligent, and a real breath of fresh air.But unfortunately, they've managed to ruin it this time around.I enjoy a good action movie with humor and clever jokes, but they went way overboard with the profanity in this one. It felt like there was an unnecessary F-bomb every two seconds, and it quickly became repetitive and unfunny.The multiverse concept that has been driving the MCU lately is really starting to wear thin. When you have a thousand versions of the same character, it becomes hard to care about what happens to any of them.I hate this multiverse concept deeply.There was also almost no storyline here, just over-the-top action scenes with an overly angry Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds, countless cameos, and non-stop profanity, which all felt like a distraction from the lack of actual plot.A good action movie doesn't need to be a hyper-violent bloodbath, but this film seemed to think otherwise. The violence felt excessive and unnecessary, and it didn't serve the story in any meaningful way.I like Quentin Tarantino movies, so i'm not sensible about the matter if it serves the story.It reminded me of what happened with Thor: Love and Thunder-just like that movie, they tried too hard to replicate the magic of Thor: Ragnarok, but ended up failing, They made exact same mistakes.Honestly, the only aspect of this movie that was done right was the marketing campaign.And as for that dog licking Deadpool's mouth repeatedly? It was just plain disgusting.I'm done with the MCU, They were done after Infinity War, i just kept giving them chances one after another.

Review: The movie is pure cinema! Congrats to Shawn Levy, Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman, Emma Corrin and the rest of the crew whether they are in the movie or the backstage. Seeing this team-up of these two actors in their iconic roles after 15 years was the best movie experience since 'Spider-Man: No Way Home'. The cameos never disappoint but I don't want to get into that to avoid spoilers. The humor was amazing and very deadpooly. It was comedic where it wanted to be and unlike 'Thor: Love and Thunder' this movie was actually funny. The visual effects and the cgi were pretty good and in my opinion better than any of the recent marvel projects. Overall, this movie with all the characters in it didn't disappoint at all. Amazing movie, congratulations again to everyone who worked on it!

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" would be a phenomenal movie, combining the irreverent humor of Deadpool with Wolverine's gritty, intense persona. Both characters, played by Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman respectively, have a dynamic that fans adore. Their contrasting styles - Deadpool's comedic, fourth-wall-breaking antics and Wolverine's brooding, fierce demeanor - create a compelling and entertaining balance.The film could explore their uneasy alliance, mixing brutal action sequences with hilarious, biting dialogue. Their banter alone would be worth the price of admission, as each character's unique quirks and personalities clash and complement each other in unexpected ways.The storyline could delve into a mission requiring their reluctant partnership, showcasing epic battles, surprising twists, and deeper character development. The plot could also introduce new villains and allies, enriching the Marvel universe further.Cameos and references to other Marvel characters would enhance the experience, making it a treat for long-time fans. Overall, "Deadpool and Wolverine" would not only be a great movie due to its action and humor but also because of the rich character interactions and storytelling possibilities it presents.

Review: 7.0/10 (Definitely Recommend)I went into "Deadpool & Wolverine" not knowing what the whole plot point was because I wanted to be surprised. I don't know if that hurt my ability to enjoy the film or not, but after coming out of the showing I felt it was overhyped for what was produced. The story isn't anything special, and the villain is cool to see but comes out mediocre.Some of the sequences are over the top and excessive in the humour they produce. They start off enjoyable, but because they continue beyond appropriate enjoyment, my laughter started to die down. However, there are a lot of good parts that are funny and laughter ranges from little snorts to complete chuckles.The action and aggression that comes with the film are good, but they're lumped into parts instead of spread out to continue the enjoyment so boredom kicks in. Visually the film is just enjoyable especially in 3D. The violence and blood is excessive, but doesn't ruin the film.The chemistry between Hugh and Ryan is amazing. I loved seeing them on the screen together and their banter is enjoyable. I also liked the cameos that come throughout, and some of the easter eggs that I was able to catch.Overall, a slightly overhyped film that still entertains. I wish I could be more specific on things, but I don't want to ruin or spoil the film for anyone. Action is too lumped instead of spread out, the comedy is both lumped, but also spread out to maintain a form of laughter throughout. Visually appealing especially in 3D, and the cameos/easter eggs are fantastic.That's it for now. Thanks for taking time to read my review. Happy watching and enjoy the show!

Review: Wow, where do I even start? "Deadpool vs. Wolverine" felt like an absolute trainwreck. The storyline was paper-thin, with so many plot points that made no sense at all. It was as if they were just throwing random ideas together without any regard for coherence. One moment you're in one setting, the next you're somewhere else with zero explanation. It was like a bunch of disconnected scenes stitched together.There was no heart in this movie whatsoever. I didn't feel anything for the characters or their supposed struggles. It lacked any depth, emotion, or real stakes. It's like they forgot that great superhero films need some kind of emotional core to keep the audience invested. This was just mindless action without purpose.And the humor? It fell completely flat. Just because you throw in a ton of cursing doesn't automatically make something funny. It felt like a teenager trying too hard to be edgy, with juvenile jokes that made me cringe more than laugh. The whole thing had the feel of a script written by a 12-year-old who thinks swearing is the peak of comedy.Overall, this movie was a huge letdown. It tried to coast on the popularity of Deadpool and Wolverine, but without a solid story or any meaningful character moments, it was just an empty, chaotic mess.

Review: I have to qualify this by saying I never saw any prior Deadpool movies and only some of the X-men movies. Despite those facts I really loved this movie. There are definitely things I wish I understood better about some of the back story and characters but you can watch this one with no prior knowledge and still enjoy it. It is hilariously funny, edgy, and sharp. The script is good and self-effacing. The characters are great. Hugh Jackman is fantastic. This is unique. It is not intended for kids. It is adult and funny and violent and blue as hell. I loved "Mary Poppins" more than I can admit. This was a good time at the movies. I would see this again.

Review: Another fitting tribute THE Wolverine. The best version so far. The chemistry between Wade and Logan is spot on. The gore, the humor, the action, the "what ifs", nostalgia and more (;-))was on the money and exactly what the people asked for. If you're a fan of Marvel, Wolverine or deadpool, this movie provided.If nothing else this movie was entertaining and worth the ticket. Watch it, dont bring your kids and enjoy.Without spoilers, I highly recommend watching this movie. Bit of a warning though, some concepts do make reference to older x-men, marvel, MCU and deadpool movies so it might be worth catching up or rewatching some if you haven't already bit wont diminish your enjoyment when if you aren't up to date. Nonetheless this movie was fun through and through. Thank you Ryan and once again/most of all thank you to Hugh Jackmen for a fitting (final?) Tribute to THE X-man. You're legacy is safe.

Review: This is a tough one. On the one hand, I think the movie is exactly what most people want from it - Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman hanging out, making jokes, and having a good time in the MCU. If that's all you're looking for, this movie absolutely delivers and it's well worth the price of admission. On the other hand... it's easily the worst of the three Deadpool movies.Deadpool is ostensibly doing everything he's doing in this movie in order to save his loved ones - all of the aforementioned supporting players from earlier Deadpool movies - characters like Yukio, Negasonic Teenage Warhead, Colossus, Vanessa, Blind Al, Dopinder, etc etc. However, only one of these supporting characters from the previous two Deadpool movies gets more than 2 minutes screen time, many of the rest don't even get lines. Instead, this movie replaces those supporting players for cameos from various failed Marvel projects - often for nothing more than a single joke or lazy nostalgic references. The idea is that these characters will finally be given the opportunity to have the send off / swan song they were previously denied in their own movies - but... none of them really get to enjoy that. They're just used in a fight montage that basically doesn't matter at all in the grand scheme of things.I can't help but feel like this would have been a much better movie had it traded the mostly ridiculous cameos in favor of involving the supporting Deadpool characters we've all come to love over the past two movies.I enjoyed the jokes for the most part, and it's good to see Disney embrace the rated R label for something like this - but the movie ultimately kind of fell flat as a whole.

Review: This isn't a WIDE APPEAL movie, it has those elements, but this clearly was made for the nerds and marvel loyalists. Which isn't a bad thing, just means if you're like me and don't get all 1000 references, it's going to be a bumpy ride for you. I got a lot of them. It suffers the Rick and Morty, Smiling Friends, current era humor problem of needing 100 jokes per minute and as such there's really a weak semblance of a plot and story. It was weirdly "CUTE" which given the amount of swearing and violence, is weird to say. I wouldn't say I regretted seeing it opening day, but would say, this is a STREAMING movie. That way you can rewind parts to see the jokes and easter eggs you've missed.The pros: -Obviously the CHEMISTRY between two of the nicest people in Hollywood from what I've heard. It's great. Though they did have a few character breaks where it clearly was like take 100 and they didn't have the budget to retake something anymore so you'll catch a Hugh Jackman smirk here or there when he's supposed to be pissed off. Pretty sure Happy Hogan has a MAJOR character break in his scene.-Decent effects -Good jokes -Some obscure out of left field references, like the "Leifeld Foot Store". Rob Leifeld co-created Deadpool.Cons: -Over stays its welcome -Blind old lady that's hood is kind of a tired old trope, I mean Airplane did that joke and it was getting old by that point. It's like getting a child to say bad things.-Story is so who cares and you can tell, since it relies way more on plot conveniences than logic.-Music was trying way too hard to be LOL RANDOM. "Isn't it funny we're playing a pop song from the 90s and early 2000s while slaughtering a hoard of people?"Overall If you're a comic fan, and a fan of the first two, you'll like it. It's made for you guys. Those looking for an Action Comedy flick might want to look elsewhere.

Review: It's embarrassing to see this rated at eight stars. The first was a genius masterpiece. Witty, funny, likable characters, and you could see the effort all over the film for the full running time.The second film breaks the fourth wall yet more. Ryan Reynolds keeps talking about being the underdog, playing the likable guy who has an ongoing beef with Wolverine and Hugh Jackman occasionally, okay, that's funny. But there was too much effort into trying to make Deadpool into a billion dollar franchise with numerous spin-offs, etc etc. As a result, while the film had its moments, it definitely suffered with its focus on how to maximize the money and the depth the storyline.Come the third film and there is no fourth wall anymore. It's not an occasional fun moment. Wolverine isn't even Wolverine. It's just Jackman in a wolverine suit pretending to be angry with Reynolds because this was never, ever, ever, ever, ever going to happen. But now it happens, what a surprise. These guys apparently know that there are millions of desperate people around the world waiting to put the two of them together in a film and laugh about these oh so clever in jokes and be able to say how funny they are.Well the in jokes aren't that funny at all. They are told over and over and over. Wolverine had absolutely nothing interesting to say and just dropped the f-bomb, bub, and short short angry blurbs in order to provoke numerous cgi fights repeat themselves. The joke is on the audience. The story was dumb. The cameos were pretty dumb. Lots of cursing for the sake of cursing and then laughing like 5-year-olds that they were able to do it in a Disney film. Oh wow.The wit and smart jokes are gone. It's now full-fledged franchise with multiple other actors being Ryan reynolds's best friend because he's gifted them with their own spin-off superhero movie that will get greenlighted as a result of this film. It's totally mindless. It may take another film for people to realize, but this is really an unbelievably poor film that sets a low barrier for effort. And massive product placement.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine is probably one of the best movies Marvel has produced lately! This is what you call a comic book movie. The actors did an amazing job at bringing these beloved characters alive and portrayed them as expected, Hugh Jackman is the only Wolverine and Ryan Reynolds is Deadpool.The storyline of this movie was clear and well thought out, and unexpected moments were met with applause from the audience. Also, the comedy was actually funny this time around, lately, Marvel comedy has felt very forced, but this felt like a breath of fresh air. And another thing that I want to point out, is the soundtrack and sound design... PHENOMENAL!!!!! I found myself singing along to the songs and they added just that final touch to the scene, and the sound design was CRISP.Overall, please go and see this movie, it won't disappoint you. If you can't make it to any showings, please watch it when it becomes available on streaming services. 1000/10!
