Review: There's a lot of people talking about how the multiverse has "ruined" the MCU, and that this film was a multiverse cash grab and an attempt at falling in line with everything else. But, they're wrong. Deadpool is, and always has been, an irreverent character that takes personal shots at the writers, producers, and even the artists that have created him. This film is no different.Is it a classic Marvel movie? No. Is it a regular down to earth Deadpool movie? No. Is it an X-Men movie? No. It's more than that. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman bring this buddy-cop film across the multiverse to life and bring in some surprising cameos and make fun of and potentially set up the next great Avengers film with Secret Wars. Even if this is the end (which would be ending on a high note) they nailed it. Fan fare is what the people want, and then they complain when they get it.People like to complain that movies are just fanfare and cameos, and then complain when there isn't enough fanfare and cameos. Watch it for yourself. And love every minute of it.Ryan and Hugh are the best at what they do, and what Deadpool and Wolverine do isn't very nice.

Review: The opening title sequence, I liked. It was a bit different, props for that. In general the movie was ok. It was a Deadpool movie. If you like DP movies you will enjoy this one too.However, DPs many many monologues could be shorter. At the end there had been quite many and it got a bit boring. Otherwise they were well written.The story seemed a bit weak. In my opinion there wasn't a clear goal where the story was going. At least I feel the previous too were much more engaging and there was a clear direction and you as the viewer got engaged. I think they got too cought in the idiosyncrasies of DP and should dial it back a little for the next one.Still you should go watch it, it's a good movie. Could be better though.

Review: Well, well, well, if it isn't the two most obnoxious (yet lovable) mutants in the Marvel universe, finally gracing us with their long-awaited cinematic reunion. Deadpool & Wolverine: The Snarkiest Show on Earth is exactly what you'd expect - a delightfully chaotic, fourth-wall-breaking, profanity-laced romp that somehow manages to be both mindless fun and surprisingly heartwarming.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman clearly had a blast reprising their iconic roles, and their on-screen chemistry is so palpable you can practically smell the testosterone and sarcasm wafting through the theater. The plot is basically just an excuse for these two egomaniacs to one-up each other in increasingly ridiculous ways, but who cares when the results are this entertaining?Sure, the action sequences are a bit over-the-top (even for a superhero movie), the jokes sometimes land with all the subtlety of a Juggernaut to the face, and the whole thing is about as subtle as a Deadpool to the, well, you get the idea. But if you're looking for a cinematic experience that will make your inner 12-year-old giggle uncontrollably while your outer 30-something cringes, this is the film for you.Just don't bring the kids - unless you want them asking some very uncomfortable questions afterwards. Overall, a delightfully unhinged addition to the Marvel canon. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go wash the snarky off.

Review: This is a difficult movie to assess. My initial thinking was that one of these after six years is fine and I think this is in some ways a welcome return to form. On the other hand, the idea of the multiverse, which has already been overplayed, is in force here. Not on the same level as, for example, the second Dr. Strange movie, but still it is here. They are smart enough to make fun of it, but even if you are satirizing and commenting on something by doing that very thing, you are still doing that very thing.Same with fan service. The movie is both doing it and making fun of it. They brought back so many characters from the past. This kind of meta-irony doesn't really work for me as it has become a cliche on to itself. At the same time, it is Deadpool, so I kind of signed up for this specifically. I do admit that there was one little-more-than-a-cameo that was actually done in a very cool way (and as far as I knew, they managed to keep it a secret this time).Sure, there is stuff in this movie that gets me, but I'm easy that way. I'll cry for anything with weepy enough soundtrack. But again, there's one of these things that really works for me within all the noise.Deadpool movies haven't really needed a good villain, but Cassandra Nova works pretty well and they do some cool things with her powers here. Also, I always enjoy it when the actor seems to relish the role and that's definitely the case here.In the end, there's a lot of things to like. Pretty every scene is good on it's own, but the whole feels messy and unfocused... or more like focused on the wrong things. I liked it, but I don't see this as being the course correction MCU so dearly needs.

Review: I might be a victim of my own hype train. I've been hanging for this movie since the announcement. It doesn't help that Ryan Reynolds is a master of advertising. The marketing was so fun.So I was a bit sad that I left the cinema feeling a bit ... nothing.Now, that's not to say this is a bad movie. It is still entertaining. But it felt off and I'm not 100% sure why. I laughed, many times. Some jokes were really top tier too. But many jokes went longer than they should (Deadpool being suited up at the TVA comes to mind). The cameos were pretty cool (looking at you Vampire man) but were ultimately nostalgic cut ins with no emotion value at all. There was no time to gain a sense of comradery from any of them. They were either there for a cheap joke, or push the plot forward enough before being left behind. I know it's Deadpool "and" Wolverine. But could've had solid ground with other characters. DP2 managed it.The only thing I hated was the Venessa side story. Not only was it basically a couple of lines that followed the movie tendency to pump and dump. But the whole thing didn't feel like anything either character would do. It just didn't feel right. And Venessa deserves better (And more screen time).I enjoyed seeing Logan again. The movie intro dance was great. The fight scenes were great, though the music choices felt strange, like someone said: "hey, I like this song, and it's a whacky choice coupled with fight scenes, lets add it". I enjoyed the villain (even if she seemed to overdo it a bit) ... Vampire dude and purple bomber!Over all, watchable, but not something I'd go out of my way to watch again (I might grab a physical copy to complete my collection though - ooh, wait, I can't cause Disney stopped making physical media for Australia)

Review: Wow! Just wow! Might be one of my favorite Marvel films next to Logan. A self aware romp through a forgetten Marvel catalog of characters complete with some pretty explosive and unexpected cameos.The way the film pokes fun of the entire Superhero genre was quickfire and only got better as the film went on. The creators knew how to hold their card til just the right moment and the payoff was major. Big laughs from everyone in the audience and for once they felt natural to the characters.Speaking of which, a surprising amount of chemistry from Reynolds and Jackman. They really know how to riff off eachothers characters and it just felt right. At first, I was afraid the mash up was going to become more of a gimmick but I'm glad they made it flow into the plotline the way they did.Overall, without giving away too much, this is a Marvel masterpiece. Highly recommended to fans of the Marvel filmography, or Deadpool in general. And as always with the character, not for the kiddos in the slightest.5 vibranium katanas out of 5.

Review: Tone and Style: The film would be a wild mix of action, comedy, and heartfelt moments. Deadpool's meta-humor and fourth-wall breaks would provide a unique narrative style, often poking fun at superhero tropes and the X-Men universe. The blend of Wolverine's gritty realism with Deadpool's cartoonish violence would create a distinct and entertaining dynamic.Character Development: Despite the humor, the film could delve into the emotional depths of both characters. Exploring Wolverine's struggle with his past and Deadpool's search for purpose could add layers of complexity to the story. Their evolving friendship would be a central theme, highlighting their mutual respect and understanding.In summary, a film combining Deadpool and Wolverine would be a chaotic, hilarious, and action-packed ride. The dynamic between the two characters, along with their contrasting personalities and fighting styles, would make for an unforgettable and entertaining superhero adventure.

Review: If you still care about the MCU, is this movie necessary? Not at all.Is it a fun entry that gives the fans a bit more of what they like? Yes.I'm tempted to say this is a worthy cinematic experience.. ONLY because part of me understands this follows in-line with what Far From Home did and what it offered it's audience (enjoying it before somebody ruins it for you). Not because the plot was particularly memorable or well made! But because it rocks an excellent cast of surprises and has Cameos that are exactly what the latest Dr Strange's attempt wanted to be (giving a chance to something meaningful)! Not to mention excellent action choreographies, and how it works as a lovely farewell to a part of the Fox's Marvel entries.Personally, I felt the pacing was too slow in parts, and the movie a tad long. Some of the dialogue becomes tiring after a point, and the well-casted villain becomes an unnecessary cliché after a point.. just for the movie to have an ending. I was also sadly-reminded of the pointless Loki and all it entails. Also, it becomes a bit overindulging at the end, and the CGI gets progressively worse. I think that if the story is good, the CGI's quality shouldn't matter as much, as it serves a purpose to raise one's imagination and help the narrative visually. For this movie, I probably started to notice or care about it, because after a certain point the story is just whatever.But still! If the entirety of the MCU ended with this, I'd be fine with it.

Review: This film is an exceptional cinematic experience that offers a wealth of intriguing details for avid comic book enthusiasts. The meticulous attention to the source material is evident in every scene, creating a rich tapestry that honors the legacy of the characters while introducing fresh elements that keep the narrative exciting and unpredictable.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman deliver outstanding performances in their respective roles as Deadpool and Wolverine. Reynolds brings his signature irreverence and wit to Deadpool, perfectly capturing the character's sardonic humor and unpredictable nature. Jackman, as ever, embodies Wolverine with a raw intensity and depth that highlights the character's inner struggles and resilience. Their on-screen chemistry is electric, and their dynamic interactions provide both heartfelt moments and laugh-out-loud humor, making the film a thrilling ride from start to finish.The film's refreshing and engaging storytelling is a masterclass in balancing action, drama, and comedy. The plot weaves together intricate character arcs with high-stakes conflicts, resulting in a narrative that is both emotionally resonant and endlessly entertaining. The director's vision is brought to life through stunning visual effects and meticulously choreographed action sequences that are as visually spectacular as they are narratively compelling.Moreover, the film does not shy away from exploring deeper themes such as identity, redemption, and the cost of heroism, adding layers of complexity that elevate it beyond a typical superhero flick. The supporting cast also deserves praise for their strong performances, which add further depth and nuance to the story.Overall, this Deadpool and Wolverine film is a must-watch for fans of the genre. It not only pays homage to the beloved characters and their rich histories but also pushes the boundaries of superhero storytelling, delivering a cinematic experience that is as thought-provoking as it is entertaining.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine' is undoubtedly the most anticipated film of the year for many. A year that is now starting to pick up in terms of high-quality movies, and a Phase that has seen Marvel Studios struggle needed this film to succeed, and not just in terms of box office numbers. The Deadpool films have always been known for cheeky humor and legendary fourth wall breaks, but also for well-crafted action comedies that gave audiences what they wanted. Since 20th Century Fox, the studio behind those first two movies and that of X-Men, got bought out by Disney in 2019, many and I wondered how the merc's new home would go about maintaining the spirit of the character. Worries also revolve around how they could bring back Wolverine without tainting his legendary ending in 'Logan.' Was this third installment able to live up to expectations, and possibly exceed them? Yes.Except for one scene with shaky cam, the action was great, especially the expected fight between Deadpool and Wolverine. Shawn Levy knows how to direct entertaining and bloody action scenes. It showed in 'Free Guy,' and it shows here!Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are fantastic as their respective characters. After fifteen years of having to deal with their appearance in 'X-Men Origins: Wolverine,' this is the team-up we've all been waiting for. Ryan Reynolds has proven himself reliably great as Deadpool, while Hugh Jackman channels in his prior work as Wolverine while also portraying a complex, different version of the character.The cameos range from expected to mind-blowing. I'm glad I binged all of the X-Men movies prior and most of the other Fox/Marvel movies except for 'Elektra' and the 2015 'Fantastic Four.' I won't say anything else for the risk of spoiling it, but believe me, it's a multiverse movie that understands when to implement cameos and pays tribute to the legacy of the Fox/Marvel films.Other than that, the fourth-wall breaks are iconic, Cassandra Nova is a good villain, the CGI is great, and the movie ends satisfyingly and excitingly.Overall, 'Deadpool & Wolverine' delivers what I expected and more! Now and then, I don't expect this film to "save the MCU," but it manages to be a phenomenal farewell to the characters of Deadpool and Wolverine (for a second time).For the technical score, my only issue is that one action scene with shaky cam, which leads to it being a 9/10. Technically not the best film of the year, as films like 'Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga,' 'Late Night with the Devil,' and 'Longlegs' have more merit. For the enjoyment score, Deadpool & Wolverine is the most reliably entertaining film of the year that I'll buy once it's on Digital. 10/10. You were probably going to see it anyway, and for good reason! It's damn fun!

Review: In moviemaking, sadly, there can be a problem with going to the well too many times, and this latest installment in one of filmdom's better cinematic franchises verges on proving just that. This offering's predecessors (2016, 2018) significantly distinguished themselves from the kind of fare typically found in the superhero genre with their outrageously bawdy humor, hilarious sight gags and relentlessly maverick attitude. This time out, however, director Shawn Levy's latest effort is a decidedly hit or miss affair, with an often-incoherent script that feels like it was cobbled together from a collection of leftover parts, some of which work and some of which don't. I suppose that's not entirely surprising from a screenplay that was penned by four different writers, making me wonder how much consensus was in place in compiling the finished product. Moreover, this film appears to be intended to fold the Deadpool franchise into the X-Men franchise, an intriguing idea that, regrettably, is handled rather clumsily (as has often been the case with many other recent fusion offerings in the Marvel Universe). And, if all that weren't bad enough, this release gives short shrift to the colorful cast of supporting players that made the Deadpool films so funny, original and enjoyable, relegating them to little more than cameos in favor of walk-ons by a host of other MCU characters (some of them remarkably obscure, I might add) in an attempt to help cement the franchise cross-pollination going on here. It makes for awkward storytelling at times, especially for viewers who might not be familiar with these lesser-known figures, some of which are drawn from Marvel source material unrelated to its big screen offerings. To the picture's credit, it features yet another stellar turn by Ryan Reynolds as the off-color protagonist, as well as its share of hilarious bits (without a doubt the franchise's historically strongest suit), including a number of unabashed, razor-sharp asides referencing off-screen developments related to the studios that produced these films and the actors who have appeared in them. These strengths notwithstanding, however, this is a production that has sadly watered down the elements that best made this franchise work in favor of an overarching programming agenda that simply doesn't serve this film or the series particularly well. The creators would have served themselves and viewers better by sticking with what works and the basics of good storytelling than trying to force an issue for the sake of future productions that may or may not work over the long term. This has been a noticeable downfall in the quality of many of the most recent Marvel Universe releases, and I'd truly hate to see this franchise befall a similar fate.

consensus was in place in compiling the finished product moreover this film appears to be intended to fold the deadpool franchise into the xmen franchise an intriguing idea that regrettably is handled rather clumsily as has often been the case with many other recent fusion offerings in the marvel universe and if all that werent bad enough this release gives short shrift to the colorful cast of supporting players that made the deadpool films so funny original and enjoyable relegating them to little more than cameos in favor of walkons by a host of other mcu characters some of them remarkably obscure i might add in an attempt to help cement the franchise crosspollination going on here it makes for awkward storytelling at times especially for viewers who might not be familiar with these lesserknown figures some of which are drawn from marvel source material unrelated to its big screen offerings to the pictures credit it features yet another stellar turn by ryan reynolds as the offcolor protagonist as well as its share of hilarious bits without a doubt the franchises historically strongest suit including a number of unabashed razorsharp asides referencing offscreen developments related to the studios that produced these films and the actors who have appeared in them these strengths notwithstanding however this is a production that has sadly watered down the elements that best made this franchise work in favor of an overarching programming agenda that simply doesnt serve this film or the series particularly well the creators would have served themselves and viewers better by sticking with what works and the basics of good storytelling than trying to force an issue for the sake of future productions that may or may not work over the long term this has been a noticeable downfall in the quality of many of the most recent marvel universe releases and id truly hate to see this franchise befall a similar fate

Review: This is a movie where the story aren't the strongest carrying the movie being the primary motor carrying the movie forward, but it's one of those movies where it's not the point of it. This is a movie for the fans, fans of Deadpool, fans of Marvel, and fans of the unmature humor we can enjoy without shame while watching the movie8/10 stars, it would have been a 10 if the story had been developed more seriously, but I didn't had any longing for it while watching it.It's funny, and more funny, silly and stupid the right way, and of course Deadpool's meta level makes it worth every dime.As someone said; it's easter egg galore, and couldn't be said more fitting :D.

Review: Despite some strong actors and a little more than a half dozen genuinely funny jokes, 'Dead Pool & Wolverine' doesn't hold up to expectations.First, there is far too much emphasis on Ryan Reynolds. It seems like to makers of this film forgot that Dead Pool is the main character. Breaking of the fourth wall is used far too often, and more often than not it feels like Ryan Reynolds is speaking to the audience rather than Dead Pool.Second, there is far too much exposition. It rivals anime in the unnecessary or repetitive dialogue explaining things.Third, there is the inconsistent quality of CGI across the filmFinally, the jokes about Marvel and Disney not only undermine the suspension of disbelief the same way as Ryan Reynold references do, but they also go on too long. Well into the second act. This may have been meant to be satirical or "meta" but it ultimately makes for long boring stretches of the film.All in all, it's not as bad as Dead Pool 2 in some ways, but it is far worse in others. Hopefully this will be the last we see of Dead Pool in the MCU.

Review: This film had to go through many problems to be made. Film studios, characters, actors, directors, scripts, but I'm very glad that it worked out in the end. Technically speaking, this is Deadpool 3. The film had strong marketing, a high budget, but it will also make money.The film gave me everything I expected, wanted and hoped for. I smiled on several occasions, laughed out loud, enjoyed the action. This is pure 100 percent fan film, fan service, there is no doubt about it. But we needed one successful superhero movie after several years of (mostly) big flops.Far from this being the best movie ever or anything like that, it won't even be the best movie of the year. We can talk about the action and the story, but that is unnecessary, that is not the point of the film. This is an action-packed summer blockbuster for fun and relaxation. Clearly, the film has several action scenes and very bloody ones (it justifies its R rating), but they are brilliantly filmed. Also, for me, the best part of the film is certainly the numerous cameo roles, references (Easter eggs) and mockery of anything and everything that is current now or has been in the last 20 years. That was exactly the point of the film.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are great in their roles and have great chemistry in their scenes together, which is almost the entire movie. We even got a little touch of movie nostalgia because the subgenre of duos who can't work together because they're different but have to, which was very popular 30-40 years ago, is practically extinct today (eg Lethal Weapon).The only thing I don't know is whether you will catch all the jokes, taunts and references because I have the feeling that there were about a hundred of them, without exaggeration.

Review: Disney marvel movies always seem to struggle at finding the right balance between being entertaining and having a good story.It is clear from the opening act that D&W was made with the intent of entertaining the wider audience and providing great fan service to the more hardcore fans.However, this is no Deadpool 3... The events of first and second movie are largely ignored, due to a time skip. When we do hear about the aftermath of the second movie, it serves very little purpose. It feels as if there should have been a movie inbetween Deadpool 2 and D&W leading to the present events.The motivations also feel all over the place. Both Deadpool and Wolverine do not really go through much character development other than feeling a certain way to then feeling the opposite (very basic and there was never any depth to it). Any serious conversations that characters had lost a lot of emotion due to the fact you know it's building up to some sort of punchline.The movie is, extremely entertaining though. If you are prepared to leave your brain outside the theatre, unwind, and enjoy 2 hours of laughs and blood then you will have a really enjoyable time. The jokes hit, 80% of the time (which is a great ratio for MCU movies nowadays). The cameos are great, and the visuals and fight scenes are great too.Overall, this movie is a wholesome end to the Fox marvel universe.

Review: The much-anticipated team-up of Deadpool and Wolverine unfortunately falls flat in this latest installment. The plot is a mess, feeling more like a lazy patchwork of ideas rather than a cohesive story. It lacked the sharpness and wit we've come to expect from both characters.One of the biggest issues was the overuse of jokes. While humor is a staple of Deadpool's character, this movie bombards the audience with too many gags, many of which simply don't land. The humor often feels forced, detracting from the overall experience.That said, there were still some funny moments that I enjoyed, showcasing the chemistry between Deadpool and Wolverine. However, these moments are few and far between, buried under an otherwise forgettable plot.In comparison to the previous movies, this is definitely the weakest. The film struggles to find its footing and fails to deliver the engaging narrative that fans hoped for. Overall, while it had some enjoyable parts, this movie is a disappointing addition to the franchise.

Review: One of the most entertaining movies ive seen in a while. Deadpools vulgar and out of pocket humor Paris perfectly with a fed up grumpy deadpool. The comedy definitely stands a fair bit stronger than the action, which the movie is not hiding at all. Constant jokes, over the top violence and Breaking of the 4th wall really makes this movie worth watching.Its worth noting that this movie gravity relies on the viewer being caught up within the MCU. You really wont get the full experience without having watched, or at least have knowlage of the previous X-men movies (specifilly «Logan»), as well as the Marvel movies and series (mainly Loki).All in all «Deadpool&Wolverine» is a funny, actionpacked and awesome piece of fan service which surpasses any previous Marvel media all the way back to endgame.

Review: Was amazing with lots of humour. Deadpool and Wolverine, two of Marvel's most iconic characters, have captivated audiences for decades with their unique personalities and compelling stories. Their journey through comic books, movies, and other media has left an indelible mark on popular culture, and their impact is nothing short of amazing.Deadpool, also known as Wade Wilson, stands out as one of the most unconventional heroes in the Marvel Universe. Known for his sharp wit, irreverent humor, and breaking the fourth wall, Deadpool has redefined what it means to be a superhero. His self-aware commentary and unpredictable nature make him both endearing and entertaining. Deadpool's origin story, filled with dark humor and a mix of tragedy and comedy, highlights his resilience and unconventional heroism. His ability to heal rapidly and his penchant for chaotic antics set him apart from traditional heroes, making him a beloved character for those who enjoy a blend of action and comedy.On the other hand, Wolverine, or Logan, is a character who embodies raw strength, complexity, and grit. With his adamantium claws and healing factor, Wolverine is a formidable warrior, yet it is his internal struggles and moral ambiguity that make him truly compelling. His backstory, laden with loss, conflict, and an ever-present search for identity, adds depth to his character. Wolverine's journey from a weapon of destruction to a hero with a code of honor resonates with audiences on a profound level. His relentless pursuit of justice, coupled with his inner turmoil, creates a multi-dimensional character who is both powerful and vulnerable.Both characters have been brought to life on the big screen with remarkable success. Ryan Reynolds' portrayal of Deadpool is a testament to his ability to perfectly capture the character's eccentricity and humor. Reynolds' commitment to staying true to Deadpool's irreverent nature has earned widespread acclaim, making the character a standout in the realm of superhero films. The "Deadpool" movies broke the mold of traditional superhero films, incorporating a unique blend of comedy and action that appealed to a diverse audience.Hugh Jackman's portrayal of Wolverine is equally remarkable. Jackman's performance, spanning multiple films over nearly two decades, has set a high standard for portraying complex, layered characters. His portrayal of Wolverine's physicality, emotional depth, and conflicted nature has been widely praised, making him one of the most memorable characters in modern cinema. The "Logan" film, in particular, showcased a more vulnerable side of Wolverine, providing a poignant and fitting end to Jackman's portrayal of the character.The chemistry between Deadpool and Wolverine has also been a highlight for fans. Their interactions, characterized by a mix of tension, camaraderie, and humor, underscore the contrasts between their personalities while celebrating their shared heroism. Their dynamic adds an extra layer of enjoyment for fans who appreciate both characters' distinct approaches to heroism.In summary, Deadpool and Wolverine are remarkable not only for their superhuman abilities but also for their richly developed personalities and the unique ways they challenge conventional superhero tropes. Their portrayals in both comic books and films have captivated audiences, making them enduring symbols of complexity and entertainment in the superhero genre. Their ability to resonate with audiences through humor, action, and emotional depth solidifies their place as two of the most compelling characters in modern popular culture.

Review: For a moment it seems like "Deadpool & Wolverine" will manage to get away with it's multiverse story. Raising it's eyebrow to the idea that every world has a hero that is fundamental to its survival. Hence the search for a new Logan.But no. It doesn't. Just like all the multiverse movies that came before, it skips around abstract worlds, introducing unbelievable characters and situations, and destroying any possible drama.But that's probably not why you watch a Deadpool movie. You watch it for the jokes, the smut and the fourth-wall breaks. Of which there are plenty. This installment also has a long list of cameo appearances, none of which disappoint, with a handful being true highlights of the film (I won't name names to avoid any spoilers).Hugh Jackman plays Wolverine straight, with lots of slice-n-dice fight sequences. But he is definitely the support act rather than the co-lead. This film is all about Ryan Reynolds - or at least, whoever wears the red and black costume.Back to the "story", Matthew McFadyen is OK as the first British baddie. Emma Corrin is really poor as the second British baddie and never manages to find the right tone.To sum up, the laughs are there, the action is good but repetitive, and the story isn't even worth trying to make sense of. Which is why this film isn't a match for the previous two Deadpool adventures.

Review: I love the X-Men Universe and lore. This movie though, was just meh. The countless easter-eggs were quite nice, but require a deep knowledge of the subject-matter. The humour no more than decent. Deadpool himself was over-the-top much of the time, and not in a good way. The excessive sexual jokes were quite immature and often disgusting. Hugh Jackman and Emma Corrin delivered the best performances. Wesley Snipes was wasted for fan-service, and due to the plot, his character was completely out of context. Regrettably, as many of you already know, the MCU has died after Endgame. This film is no exception.

Review: Its story may not be the strongest, but the comedy makes 'Deadpool & Wolverine' an excellent watch!There are some top notch gags in there, particularly to do with the recent offscreen changes for Wade Wilson's alter ego. As you'd expect with Ryan Reynolds in this role, the jokes are plentiful and there is barely any time to react to one before another appears. That can sometimes not work as well as intended, e.g. 'Deadpool 2', but here the humour is executed perfectly.Reynolds himself is quality, it is a quintessential Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool performance. It's real neat to see Hugh Jackman back as Wolverine, he does play second fiddle to the other titular character but still more than holds his own, as you'd expect. Emma Corrin, meanwhile, enters the MCU with a great showing.As noted at the top, I do think the plot couldn't been superior - but not in a negative way. What is portrayed is still entertaining to watch, it's just not necessarily on the same level as the comedic elements. A fun watch, all the same. Do I like it more than the 2016 original? I think so, would only be minorly so though.

Review: You can't go into this movie expecting an actual movie, because that's not what it is. It's a parody of Marvel movies. Deadpool 1 (and sometimes 2) had an actual plot to follow. Deadpool 1 especially could stand on its own. This movie is different. Don't get me wrong, it's funny, and I love it for what it is, but there's a reason it's not called Deadpool 3. The plot is all over the place and the multiverse aspect (combined with the fact that they can both regenerate) makes the stakes non-existent. If you just turn your brain off and have fun though, it's a good time. It is however a shame that we probably won't ever see Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool in its own standalone movie again.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine is a riotous, action-packed spectacle that delivers on the promise of its title. This R-rated mashup of the two iconic anti-heroes is a rollercoaster of humor, violence, and unexpected heart.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman share an undeniable chemistry that powers the film. Their banter is sharp, their interactions hilarious, and their on-screen partnership is a joy to watch.The film doesn't hold back on the action. The sequences are choreographed with precision and filled with adrenaline-pumping moments.Deadpool's signature fourth-wall-breaking humor is in top form, complemented by Wolverine's dry wit. The film is constantly surprising with its comedic timing.Beneath the layers of violence and comedy, there's a genuine emotional core to the film that adds depth to the characters.The plot is fairly standard fare for a superhero film, with a few predictable twists.While the action sequences are impressive, some of the CGI effects feel overused and can be distracting.The cinematography is slick and stylish, capturing the gritty urban setting and the over-the-top action with equal finesse. The editing is sharp and keeps the pace consistently high. The soundtrack is a well-curated mix of both classic and contemporary tracks that complement the film's tone.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman deliver career-defining performances. Their portrayal of Deadpool and Wolverine, respectively, is iconic. The supporting cast provides solid performances, adding depth to the world.The film is packed with surprise cameos that will delight fans of the Marvel universe. While some cameos are brief, they add a layer of fun and fan service.Deadpool & Wolverine is a wildly entertaining film that successfully blends humor, action, and heart. It's a must-watch for fans of the characters and action-comedy enthusiasts alike.

Review: I have purposely avoided the comic book genre of movies for the last few decades since I view them as infantile. Superpowers, extended battles, ridiculous physics (or lack thereof), binary good vs evil characters...perhaps if I were still a 10-year old boy I might enjoy that monotony. Of course there were some classics like 1989's Batman which elevated themselves beyond just a "superhero" movie. But I have been happy to ignore the deluge since that time.Unfortunately I was dragged in to see this Deadpool / Wolverine abomination recently, and I feel compelled to express my dismay.Yikes. Is this what the moviegoing public is cool with? Most of it is simply a series of extremely graphic mass murder sequences set to upbeat music, juvenile jokes (I didn't laugh once), swearing, and the usual ridiculous CGI jumping through dimensions or whatever. Whatever "plot" there was, I missed it because it was complete gibberish.Yes, let's further desensitize ourselves to brutal violence by laughing at the murderous rampages. Are we supposed to be moved by the poetic arcs of blood and guts flying across the screen? Who is this for? Honestly, what kind of sick person *enjoys* this?I'd feel cleaner coming out of a trashy strip club than this movie. The high ratings and praise suggest that there's something very, very wrong with our society.

Review: I wouldn't say that Deadpool & Wolverine is one of the best Marvel movies, but Marvel is definitely making a strong comeback, reminding us, 'Hi, I'm here to blow your mind with entertainment!' It's incredibly entertaining, with Deadpool's signature humor hitting all the right notes. Ryan Reynolds, with his impeccable comedic timing, once again proves why he's perfect for this role. Kudos to the action choreographers and the special effects team for their outstanding work. The reappearance of Hugh Jackman as Wolverine sent chills down my spine. Overall, it's a thrilling ride full of laughter and action.Best to experience in IMAX 3D.

Review: Finally saw Deadpool & Wolverine a few hours ago, it was almost exactly what the fans of X-Men and Wolverine were waiting for, like myself.The action was insane, PHENOMENALLY COOL, BLOODY & BADASS filled with gore, the comedy may have gone a bit TOO overly profane and tedious by Deadpool, but when it did tasteful humor, the jokes and one-liners landed hard, the music was Sooo good & beautiful (the first fight theme reminded of Bleach OST "Battle Ignition") and used all that had come before as a very emotional (personally eye-teary) legacy of Deadpool and Wolverine's lives to mold their relationship and fates in this film.The movie was beyond pleasingly stacked with a gratuitous amount of these two together, and an incredible JAWDROPPING amount of cameos, ones you would NEVER expect, that you'd become confident to expect even those appearing that would seem impossible. Go into this movie with ZERO spoilers if you can!! Its the REAL Multiverse of Madness.Without spoiling anything this movie is a pseudo love letter and send off to what 20th Century Fox has done with Marvel and the X-Men with great appreciation and heartfelt embracement of what remains for the MCU. 2:20am.

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" brilliantly merges the irreverent humor of Deadpool with the gritty intensity of Wolverine. The film masterfully balances chaotic action with witty banter, creating an unexpectedly harmonious dynamic between the two iconic characters. The storyline, while refreshingly unconventional, maintains a surprising depth, exploring themes of redemption and identity. Exceptional performances from the leads elevate the film, making their chemistry electric. Visually, it's a feast, with dynamic fight scenes and stunning cinematography. This movie redefines the superhero genre, offering a unique blend of comedy, drama, and raw action. This is a brilliant and epic masterpiece with surprising cameos.

Review: Ryan Reynolds is annoying to listen to for long periods of time. It's not until the final 3rd of the movie where his lines are minimized (Thank God). The final 3rd of the movie was enjoyable to watch. The first hour of the film you could burn in a fire and no one would care. It's a typical Deadpool movie. Incredibly violent, gory, profane, etc.It's not that the movie needs non stop action to make it good, that's further from the truth. Too much action in a movie can be an energy drain on the viewer. What made the final 3rd of the movie enjoyable is that the plot actually went somewhere. Where the first hour of the film felt like filler; building things up at a snail's pace. In order to understand this film better I HIGHLY recommend that you watch the TV series "Loki" because MANY of the plot points come from the plot of that TV series. Without watching Loki I think a lot of viewers will be confused as to what is happening in the film.The credits have two special easter eggs. One shows up almost right away during the credits and the 2nd credit scene was actually genuinely funny. I can't tell you how many credit scenes Marvel has done that was down right pointless or not worth the wait. But the one in this movie was actually well done.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine (2024)" is like that decent pizza place down the street-good enough to satisfy the craving but not quite the slice of heaven you were hoping for. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are basically on autopilot at this point, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Their banter is still sharp, and the chemistry is undeniable, but it feels like we've been here before. It's like they reheated the leftovers from their past roles and slapped a new label on it.The movie is a wild mix of blood, jokes, and a plot that barely holds together. It's fun as hell, don't get me wrong, but it's also kind of like riding a rollercoaster that's mostly made of old parts from other rides. You'll laugh, you'll cringe, and you might even cheer a few times, but by the end, you're not really sure if it was the ride itself or just the thrill of seeing these two back in action.Overall, "Deadpool & Wolverine" does the job, but it's not the game-changer it thinks it is. It's like ordering the usual from your favorite takeout spot-you know exactly what you're getting, and it's just fine. Perfect for fans, but maybe not worth the hype if you're expecting something groundbreaking. Still, it's hard to complain too much when Reynolds and Jackman are having this much fun, even if the movie itself is just...ok.

Review: Marvel Studios' Deadpool & Wolverine is a movie close to 25 years in the making, ever since Hugh Jackman first donned the black leather suit and adamantium claws to play Wolverine in 2000's X-Men. While Ryan Reynolds was a more recent addition to 20th Century Fox's X-Men franchise, he became so synonymous with the Deadpool character that I'm certain I'm not alone in believing he would be nearly impossible to recast. Instead of going the recasting route, Deadpool & Wolverine utilizes the multiverse to not only explain their joining the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but offer an exceptionally fun buddy comedy.Ryan Reynolds & Hugh Jackman shine as superheroes with great comedic chemistry.Exciting action scenes & multiverse references cater to all types of fans.Weak character development and one-note villains may deter some viewers.Marvel Studios' Deadpool & Wolverine is a movie close to 25 years in the making, ever since Hugh Jackman first donned the black leather suit and adamantium claws to play Wolverine in 2000's X-Men. While Ryan Reynolds was a more recent addition to 20th Century Fox's X-Men franchise, he became so synonymous with the Deadpool character that I'm certain I'm not alone in believing he would be nearly impossible to recast. Instead of going the recasting route, Deadpool & Wolverine utilizes the multiverse to not only explain their joining the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but offer an exceptionally fun buddy comedy.The plot of Deadpool & Wolverine is somehow both convoluted and basic. The movie is essentially a buddy road trip story that's complicated by multiverse politics and red herrings. The TVA, introduced and explored through two seasons of Loki, plucks Deadpool from his timeline and tells him his universe is in trouble. Instead of working with TVA agent Mr. Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen), Deadpool looks for help from one of the multiverse's Wolverines. Since they've both gone rogue, the TVA banishes them to The Void - the multiverse's trash heap - where they face Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin).Look, I'm not going to sit here and say Deadpool & Wolverine is a "good" movie. The character development is thinly drawn at best, often taking a backseat to multiverse shenanigans. There's still an emotional throughline, as Deadpool searches for a purpose that'll make him matter - all to impress Vanessa (Morena Baccarin), because he's ultimately a selfish character. The new Wolverine has a barely touched tragic backstory to justify his anger issues. Everyone else in the Deadpool & Wolverine cast is a largely one-dimensional character, existing simply to serve the plot or get a cheer from the crowd.But that's not why you go to see Deadpool & Wolverine - and it's certainly not why I enjoyed the movie. Deadpool & Wolverine is a love letter to Marvel movies of the last 30 years, and I love those movies. I grew up watching the X-Men movies, and had to sit through the franchise fizzling out while enduring the false starts of The Fantastic Four. Deadpool & Wolverine gave me closure. The film is the ultimate fan service movie, couched in an odd-couple team-up. It's Fox's version of Avengers: Endgame, rendered through the playful and crude lens of Deadpool.Deadpool & Wolverine is best enjoyed by someone with a deep, enduring love for Marvel movies; as a result, the film sometimes leaves casual fans in the dust. The last three decades hold a lot of Marvel movie lore, and even those who have seen every movie referenced by Deadpool & Wolverine may be confused by some of the real-world callbacks. Thankfully,the movie strikes a good balance between very deep cuts and more general pop culture references. Still, this is very much the kind of movie where it's better to do your homework if you want to appreciate everything.

herrings the tva introduced and explored through two seasons of loki plucks deadpool from his timeline and tells him his universe is in trouble instead of working with tva agent mr paradox matthew macfadyen deadpool looks for help from one of the multiverses wolverines since theyve both gone rogue the tva banishes them to the void the multiverses trash heap where they face cassandra nova emma corrinlook im not going to sit here and say deadpool wolverine is a good movie the character development is thinly drawn at best often taking a backseat to multiverse shenanigans theres still an emotional throughline as deadpool searches for a purpose thatll make him matter all to impress vanessa morena baccarin because hes ultimately a selfish character the new wolverine has a barely touched tragic backstory to justify his anger issues everyone else in the deadpool wolverine cast is a largely onedimensional character existing simply to serve the plot or get a cheer from the crowdbut thats not why you go to see deadpool wolverine and its certainly not why i enjoyed the movie deadpool wolverine is a love letter to marvel movies of the last years and i love those movies i grew up watching the xmen movies and had to sit through the franchise fizzling out while enduring the false starts of the fantastic four deadpool wolverine gave me closure the film is the ultimate fan service movie couched in an oddcouple teamup its foxs version of avengers endgame rendered through the playful and crude lens of deadpooldeadpool wolverine is best enjoyed by someone with a deep enduring love for marvel movies as a result the film sometimes leaves casual fans in the dust the last three decades hold a lot of marvel movie lore and even those who have seen every movie referenced by deadpool wolverine may be confused by some of the realworld callbacks thankfullythe movie strikes a good balance between very deep cuts and more general pop culture references still this is very much the kind of movie where its better to do your homework if you want to appreciate everything

Review: Hard belly laughs, excessively gory high-octane action, and a grounded heart to round it off nicely. This film has it all, and gives you everything it has promised from day one (and WAY more.)Ryan Reynolds is back as everyone's favourite anti-hero, and this time he's busting the back doors of the MCU wide-open, and the MCU isn't holding back. (If that isn't enough, they've opened up wider to make room for Wolverine.)Hugh Jackman brings Wolverine back to the silver screen in true Hugh Jackman style - flawless, and together with Reynolds the combination of Deadpool and Wolverine couldn't be sweeter (or saltier, whatever you prefer. I like a mix)It has to be experienced in theatres. Much like Spider-Man: No Way Home, this instant MCU favourite will have like-minded fans cheering and whooping for joy. It has all the wicked wit and tongue-in-cheek (sometimes literal - looking at you Dogpool) humour of the first two films, but with an undeniable MCU glow up that is perfectly poked at with impeccable taste.Minor flaws, the film starts fast and keeps up the pace nicely until about the 3/4 mark. The plot isn't quite as air-tight as I'd have liked, but that isn't to say that it's weak, just not without its flaws.Despite this, prepare to laugh, cry, laugh some more, choke on some popcorn, cough it back up, act like nothing happened, and then laugh some more again. This film is about to invasively fondle your mind in a way that you'll never forget. So grab your filthy novelty popcorn buckets and march into those theatre doors with your head held high. This is your time to shine.⭐⭐⭐⭐

Review: This was a blast, I was expecting it to be fun, Deadpool back In 2016 was a nice Surprise, it was funny and had great writing. The newest Installment is exactly the same, but funner in more ways then one. The cinema was great especially for a midnight screening, plenty of laughs in the Cinema. So it's time to review, the ultimate, the Marvel Jesus, oh wait no it's just "Deadpool + Wolverine".Very fun start, it felt cinematic and had Brisc pacing and at break neck pace, quite literally. The first action sequence for that reason is very well done, it had plenty of laughs. The "206 Bones" in the body and then they made a joke about "Gossip Girl being 207" that was a creative joke and quite a clever one too. Deadpool is probably at his best, he's more brutal which is a good and bad thing, and he's also more funnier. And Ryan Reynolds puts in an outstanding performance. Very heart-felt and touching at times, but most importantly entertaining and funny.Wolverine was a great character to bring back, lots of fan service moments, and they worked well because it showed his emotional side and why he had given up everything, and Not only that but it was a top-notch Performance by Hugh Jackman. Possibly the stand Out, but both Ryan and Hugh Put in an excellent performance. I thought there chemistry did lack at times, but overall they were fun together, and I felt it was the right move from Marvel to pare these two up as they do have some great moments together and between them.Cassandra Nova was the Villain, we got some cameos from Marvel characters, Blade being the biggest serprise out of them all, I won't say any more on that because I don't want to spoil it too much. Cassandra was very powerful and could brake anything quite easily, she like goes into your soul and it shares some good and bad moments in your life, particularly moving when she did it to Logan.The chemistry was perfect between Hugh and Ryan, But I did feel as though his character was too jokey at times, and also the film was fairly gory, and too gory. Aside from that this film was very enjoyable and Entertaining. I'd certainly give it a re-Watch. And I like the team-work between Deadpool and Logan, they both worked together which was interesting to see. So the big question is...,Would I recommend this Film?,Yes absolutely, I think it balances humour, Entertainment, clever witty dialogue with some fun scenes very very well. Top-performances, Stella cast jam-packed with Bloody Fun Moments, quite Literally. I did ask most on there opinion on the Movie, Some had hoped for more, others really enjoyed it. So I am glad most of them enjoyed it. Just don't have overly High expectations like others, and you won't be disappointed. 8.5 out of 10.

Review: I saw this movie yesterday and it has everything I could ever dream of: comic accurate costumes, world class actors, comedy, action and emotion, all in one! But what made this movie special was how much heart and soul everyone put into it. Ryan Reynolds' back must hurt so much from carrying this movie. Because by writing AND producing this movie, he really saved not just his own franchise, he saved the ENTIRE MCU. And as for Hugh Jackman, I had faith he would come back for the role since Logan (2017), but I didn't want to get ahead of myself, but the waiting for this team up was so worth it. LFG!

Review: Superfans of the entire Marvel universe will find this film filled with top-notch comedy and action, Easter eggs, cameos that left the audience gasping and cheering, a lot of meta jokes and digs at 20th Century Fox...It's the perfect way to wrap up the "Deadpool" franchise for good. Deadpool & Wolverine isn't the height of the MCU, but it is the height of the MCU right now, and for a franchise that's struggling at the moment, it's the shot in the arm that the MCU needs. With the whole super-racket on the ropes, the cast of "Deadpool & Wolverine" seizes the opportunity to prove the power of their own charisma. Demand for the movie is high and, although it's not the be-all/end-all of superhero movies, its anarchic and rambunctious approach to the genre results in an entertaining hybrid of comic book action and straightforward satire.My Rating : 7/10.

Review: This is how you make a good movie! It's good to see that Marvel is still capable of doing great stuff like this, even if just reminds me of how it used to be. This movie proves they CAN make great/fun movies, but they simply DECIDED not to do that for almost 6 years.. (aside from Guardians 3) the dialogue, the jokes, the cameo's, the surprises, the fights, everything was done so well. It's unfortunate that it'll probably take another 3 years or so, for another good movie to come out, but we'll have to see. Maybe this has opened their eyes.We can only hope that they realise their mistakes & decide to focus on good storytelling & fanservice, instead of whatever they were doing until now. I'm glad all 3 Deadpool movies were a success.

Review: One of the most anticipated films of the year is finally here and, to be honest, is it critics who pay the bills for big productions? This is a better example of that, but let's get to the film.The first act starts off very well, with an excellent action scene, showing everyone who was afraid of possible interference from Disney, we had an adult movie at Marvel. And was it a well-made movie? It depends.The film doesn't care about keeping the plot cohesive, neither between itself nor between the universe, and is that important? Not so much. For Marvel fans and even those who have seen any superhero movie, there will be a shower of references in the film, here there are many characters from many old movies that simply They appear all the time in the second act. And you realize that I'm already talking about the second act and I didn't talk about the plot, because there isn't one. It's just an excuse for him to save the universe and the film is based on that.And unfortunately I don't have much more to say, there is no plot, the village plays the role of driving the story but the villain changes in the middle of the film and that's it, many box office success characters and no plot. 7/10.

Review: I had extremely high expectations going into this movie. I enjoyed the first two Deadpool movies and have been disappointed at several of the latest Marvel movies so I was hoping this would restore my faith in Marvel. It met and exceeded those expectations! Hugh Jackman seemed to be having a terrific time and Ryan Reynolds was his usual, incredible self throwing quips and one liners around like candy. The story was not what I was expecting, and had heard speculation about. The story was even better than I thought it was going to be. In my opinion the cameo appearances played into the story very well and did not just seem to be gratuitous. This is a movie that I will have to see multiple times to appreciate all of the subtle references and Easter eggs scattered throughout yet. I do hope that we get to see another team up of Deadpool and Wolverine!

Review: I will be honest and say I was underwhelmed by Deadpool & Wolverine. I was quite looking forward to it. I know Deadpool has always been an outrageous and comical character. However this film was full of random events that were forcefully pushed together. It lacked flow and I feel a massive opportunity was missed here by coupling up the most rugged character in the universe with the craziest. The humour was passable and worked now and then but it definitely wasn't as funny as I hoped it would be, given the two leads and how crazy they could have made the villain or antagonist. The villain did not even look formidable and just someone in a suit. This was another missed opportunity to have someone who could have been as formidable and hilarious as the two leads. This film would have benefited so much by borrowing the elements from Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 1 that made it so funny, logical and fun to follow at the same time.I just could not get into the this film and while people are raving about it, I honestly felt it was quite a weak mess of a film with no proper story, it was full of random and uninspired scenes and did not make as big a splash for me. This is a cash cow for Disney and Marvel but the quality of writing, great humour and nice story to weave it together was lacking.

Review: If you're looking for a movie to kick back and enjoy without too much thinking, *Deadpool and Wolverine* delivers. It's packed with humor and action, making it a good watch for a fun time. However, the over-sexualized jokes and dialogues often touch the cringe meter, detracting from the overall experience.Additionally, the use of the multiverse feels excessive. With the ability to bring back any character, dead or alive, it seems like nothing truly matters anymore, undermining the stakes and coherence of the story. While it's entertaining, the film lacks the substance needed to elevate it beyond just a casual watch.

Review: Giving this an 8/10 ratingThis film is bloody, has lots of swearing, great action, and has good feelings with it, and a more than fine storyline. It's an unexpected triumph, I hoped for just a good film, as the films in this genre ,this year, have been less than good.The marketing on this has been non stop for a long while, and almost drove me away. But today, I sat down and enjoyed a nice gem for the big screen. Fun from the start to finish, you have such a great cast of actors, and there is a big cast of them, so it was important that the script was not only funny, but had meaning, a good place for it to go, and characters that are believable. Motives aside, even the villains, have genuine bite and some caring to them, well, one does.If you like the first two films, you already know that you are going to see this, and this is great a late night cinema stay, just know that this has lots and lots of blood, and bad language, other than that, it's solid as they come.

Review: Six years after Deadpool 2, a lot has changed in the industry regarding 20th Century Fox and Disney. Ever since Disney acquired Fox, I think it's safe to say nothing has been done with its hero properties, and Disney/Marvel has been hurting.So does Deadpool have what it takes to reinvigorate some much needed life back into the MCU? Well, let's be honest regardless of how well this film does in theaters. Disney/Marvel needs more than one movie to come back to life.With that being said, Deadpool & Wolverine is perhaps the summer hero blockbuster the MCU needs right now.Is this the best film in the MCU? I would say no, but it's definitely better than recent Marvel projects. Deadpool & Wolverine is simply put a fun time at the theaters it gives us more of the merc with the mouth and lots of blood and action. Then stack that with Hugh Jackman in his return to Wolverine, but also put on top of that cameos galore featuring some great Marvel characters of yesteryear and this very easily can be seen as an instant fan favorite.Unfortunately, that's all this film has to offer. It's like they said let's make a movie based on nothing more than fan service. Not to say, fan service is bad, but a movie should have more than just fanfare. The story is shockingly shallow, and ultimately, I found it boring. The villain or "villains" were also boring. Then the charm of all this fan service wore thin surprisingly quick. When around every corner is supposed to be fanfare for the sake of fanfare, then those moments lose impact and magic.This whole movie felt like I was touring a "museum" (and yes pun intended) of Marvel characters past and present. In the end, though, it was like having a super annoying fan sitting next to you saying "hey you remember that character... hey, you remember this character?" All I wanted to say was yes. I remember these characters. Can we do something else now.As much fun as it is to see these characters on screen again, I'd rather visit their respective films than have them being used for what amounts to commodities for ticket sales.While Deadpool & Wolverine isn't bad, it could have been so much better, but hopefully, this will be a turning point for Disney/Marvel, and the MCU would have breathed in some new life. Only time will tell.IMDb: 6/10 Letterboxd: 3/5Watched in IMAX 3D.

Review: The main reason I watched "Deadpool & Wolverine" was to see Hugh Jackman back as the iconic Wolverine, and he did not disappoint. From the very start, with Deadpool's dance and the catchy song, the movie keeps you entertained. There are plenty of hilarious moments that had me laughing out loud. The fight scenes and the bromance between Deadpool and Wolverine are spot on. The cameos are a delightful surprise for MCU fans, adding to the fun. Overall, this movie is an enjoyable ride, delivering exactly what Marvel fans have been waiting for. The dialogues are super hilarious. I did not feel bored at any moment.

Review: Marvel really took the reins back into their hands. The movie is loaded with full power of hype and fan service and nothing more. Reynolds delivers another top performance as Deadpool, breaking all the walls and Jackman has heard the voice of the fans and returns to the screen better than ever. There are a few slower scenes in the movie, but you can forgive them, it's mostly a fun plot anyway. The idea of friends going on an adventure works well. The action in the film has been polished to the last detail, katanas and weapons swing at full power and with a big budget. This film is definitely worth seeing in the cinema, what an experience.

Review: I'll give credit to Disney for knowing how to make good money and milk and milk and milk until the cows have no milk but I can't stand how many timelines and how constantly aware these movies have become.I wanted to get up after half an hour but stuck with it because let's face it... I paid for the ticket.The movie to be fair is fun in very small doses and if it came out before the glorious avengers timeline and before Logan became a wonderful end, I would be probably change my tune to sum it up as fun but it's as bad as the last Thor.If I was given bags of cash to come back I too would have so I can't blame any of the actors - it's a job I get it.I just wish Disney / Marvel would hit the reset switch, take time off, and come back strong but that's not how business works unfortunately.Well done for a fun movie in its own right but fingers crossed that this is the last one to come out and ruin the wonderful history of movies. It felt unnecessary.If you go in with the idea of just watching a fun movie with no connection to anything else then you'll have some fun but if you felt any connection to the previous movies or characters you might have a feeling of being ripped off by someone who knows how to make money and make money Disney will.To sum up how bad I thought it was, my review started out as 4 stars and with a bit of time and thought it went down to the now more accurate 2 stars.

Review: Deadpool And Wolverine (I can't believe I'm saying this!) Is a 2024 dark comedy action film with Ryan Reynolds not only returning as Deadpool but the Hugh himself returns as Wolverine after 7 years, but this time he's wearing his classic suit and seen as a letdown in an alternative universe as he failed to save his X-Men team.As their misadventures continue throughout it's over 2 hour runtime the enjoyment and pure fun this film produces is awesome, along with insane cameos and breathtaking visuals this entry in the Deadpool franchise is most certainly different from it's predecessors.What makes it give it the huge difference in comparison is the very powerful chemistry between the 2 leads. Deadpool is what he always has been and has not been altered in any way but Wolverine kind of bounces Deadpool back with some colourful language too and it's like sometimes, their arguments are like a long tennis fight, and I think it was absolutely hilarious.While it's hard to talk about the film without going into spoiler territory, trust me DO NOT GET THIS FILM SPOILED. There's really surprising character comebacks and it's crazy to actually witness on the big screen where you should definitely watch it.Overall Deadpool And Wolverine has the same qualities as the original 2, but with it's horrific but funny gore and explicit jokes comes with more heart and enjoyment with battles and quotable dialogue that really could change the tide of the MCU, this film really is the best of the year so far and makes a mark on Deadpool and the MCU as one of the most fun films I have ever seen, Well done guys!Grade: A+25th July 2024 Showcase Cinema Deluxe Southampton.

Review: Usually by the 3rd sequel, the luster has worn off of the franchise so maintaining that shine is difficult. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman just killed it in this 3rd installment of Deadpool. The jokes, the fight sequences, the jokes...are just non-stop and if you walk out of the credits and miss the usual MCU after the credits...you lost. The whole multiverse concept has not gone over as well as the Infinity Stone story line, but Deadpool may have saved it. The fact they were able to bring back Wolverine and NOT mess with Logan...simply genius. The references to 20th Century Fox, references to old X-Men movies, old Super hero movies is just done so well....and Ryan able to get his wife in this movie, was a really nice Easter Egg. I rated this 9 of 10, but I honestly don't know why I didn't give a 10. I supposed that's serious films, I dunno.

Review: Do you believe that movies should show respect to its characters, and make you FEEL? This movie does just that! It is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen. It works not just on its own but as a whole sendoff and farewell message to the whole of Fox's marvel properties. The comedy is something that is nailed in this film. The journey of Deadpool and Wolverine is something to behold. The intro comes out like a hammer and believe me when I say that it is the greatest way to start the movie. I loved every second of this. My only criticism could be some of the fight choreography was a bit hard to comprehend when it involved large numbers of characters. But this movie has something that will resonate with all, instead of a lifeless movie that belittles characters the audience loves, this movie has SOUL and UPLIFTS its characters. It is cinematic history in the making! Go give this a watch!

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine is a spectacular showcase of Marvel's ability to seamlessly integrate Fox characters into the Marvel Universe. Serving as a nostalgic farewell to the Fox era, the film is packed with clever references that will delight longtime fans.While the dynamic duo of Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman undeniably steal the show with their impeccable chemistry and hilarious banter, the film's plot unfortunately falls flat.Despite lacking depth, the movie compensates with its over-the-top action sequences, stunning visuals, and non-stop humor. The jaw-dropping fight scenes are a highlight, and the witty dialogue had me laughing out loud.Ultimately, Deadpool and Wolverine is an entertaining action-comedy that's more style than substance. Reynolds and Jackman's performances are electric, and their on-screen partnership is pure magic. I eagerly anticipate seeing them share the screen again.

Review: Oh my god basically everything about this movie is great. The comedy is on par and sometimes better than its predecessors, the action sequences are easily some of the most satisfying fight scenes in the MCU and the dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine was amazing. The cameos were also really surprising and relevant to the overall story (one in particular completely made me lose my mind). The villain was solid and entertaining enough to move the story along. However, one of my main problems was the pacing. It feels like they were able to put a 3 act movie into the first 75 minutes and then all of a sudden there's still 45 minutes left. The story after was still great but it just felt a bit off. Plus they didn't really cover the whole Deadpool Corp thing enough for me to understand and care about the conflict. It was still very funny but the narrative side was a bit confusing. Other than those small issues, this is easily one of the best things Marvel has released in a WHILE.

Review: This is the movie that I had been waiting for a very long time. 24 years ago I saw the X-Men in theaters and I kept wondering why they were all dressed in black. Wolverine finally gets to use his correct costume, the one we all love from the comic books and cartoons. This movie is plenty of fun, with Ryan Reynolds constantly breaking the fourth wall and just being himself. The multiverse is the perfect plot device to bring back dead characters and explore dead movie franchises which this movie does beautifully. I am glad the Hugh Jackman is back. I recommend seeing this in 3-D as not many movies are made this way anymore.

Review: If Marvel wasn't so greedy, I'd say this should be their sean song. They brought back elements and long forgotten characters from over the years while someone tying up a lot of loose knots. While there were a few "wtf" CGI moments, (namely Logan once he puts his mask on,) but otherwise it was truly perfect. It wasn't at all watered down as many of us fears when comparing to the previous 2 installments in the trilogy, and even made sure to be VERY self aware while never taking itself too seriously. Sadly no, this DOES NOT MEAN Marvel is "saved." We all know their next movie will be right back to the garbage they've been doing since End Game, (Spider-Man excluded.) The SMART move would be to allow this to be the final film they make for a while and then start with a fresh reboot. Buuuuut we all know that won't happen.

Review: This might be one of my new favorite movies of all time. It hits a lot of specific movie tropes that I really enjoy, such as found family, time travel, and AUs. The soundtrack is AMAZING, and I've been listening to Like a Prayer on loop since I left the theater after seeing it the first time (I've seen it twice in theaters already). Ryan Reynolds is amazing as Deadpool (as always), and Hugh Jackman is equally great as Wolverine. Their on-screen chemistry is perfect, even - or especially - during the tense moments. I was pretty surprised that I liked this movie as much as I did, especially considering it was a three-quel. It's definitely a must see!

Review: Not all good movies are enjoyable, and not all enjoyable movies are good. This one is solidly in the latter category. If you like Ryan Reynolds' humor style, especially that of the prior Deadpool films, it's almost a lock that you'll laugh at and enjoy this as well because, well, it's more of the same.The action is also quite good. Some of the sequences can overstay their welcome at times, but they're always at least initially visually interesting. They just needed to be about 20% shorter, I think.There's a strong visual spectacle to the whole thing that is also quite good...probably better than the previous Deadpools.The acting was decent. I think Jackman in particular gets to go places I'm glad he went with this character. The moments are brief, but they're good. Reynolds...not so much. Cassandra Nova's actress did quite well I thought. Chris Evans is delightful in his cameo. But most of the rest were highly forgettable.But let's talk about the bad. The Plot. There isn't one. Okay, that's not entirely fair. There is a plot. It's just TERRIBLE. It's little more than a light justification for stringing together random cameo sequences and Reynolds' comedy bits. The movie feels almost like a sketch comedy show but with two recurring characters in each sketch, like a Python movie.Both villains' entire plans are undone by the fact that both of them are extremely stupid for no reason...multiple times. Each time Logan and Wade get the better of them, you WILL see it coming in the same way that a train blasting it's horn at you is hard to miss.Logan's character arc makes good sense, and resonates, but Reynolds' kind of doesn't. It is invented for this movie. To some extent that might be inevitable in the third installment of a trilogy.And while the fan service/homages/references/cameos are often done well and in a comforting way (the movie would have been insufferable had they been done poorly), they are nonetheless empty calories.And of course, plot holes. There are so many plot points that feel arbitrary and nonsensical. Characters doing things for the purpose of advancing the plot. Technologies or magic system points that come out of nowhere to justify things. I don't think it's a spoiler to name the most egregious one: The 'Anchor Being' concept is so profoundly idiotic and inconsistent that I actively encourage you not to think about it lest you lose 5-7 IQ points from psychic damage. As I did. And believe me, it's FAR from the only one.But at the end of the day, the question is: Did I have a good time? I did. As stupid as this movie was, Reynolds is funny and charming. The action is fun. There are a few parts of the movie that just DRAG, but I had a good time. And isn't that the point?

Review: Rating: 8/10The "Deadpool & Wolverine" movie is an absolute blast from start to finish! Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman deliver electrifying performances, bringing their signature wit, charm, and action hero credentials to the table.The film's clever script masterfully balances humor and heart, with plenty of laugh-out-loud moments and heartfelt interactions between the leads. The action scenes are intense and expertly choreographed, showcasing the duo's unstoppable chemistry.Reynolds and Jackman's banter is pure gold, and their characters' unlikely friendship is genuinely heartwarming. The movie's pace is relentless, with constant surprises and thrilling set pieces.Overall, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a triumphant union of two beloved characters, delivering non-stop thrills, humor, and excitement. Don't miss this unforgettable adventure!Positives:

Review: Okay, so there's not much of a story here. They give us just another reason to save the world. But Marvel has taken this simple plot and done what they do best. Give the audience what they're craving for.Superhero face-offs, spoofs, breaking the 4th wall lavishly with enough humor and intense action sequences.And they know when to give you something, I mean the exact moment to deliver something that you've been waiting for from the beginning of the film.In this movie, the cameos deserve special mention. It is almost like Marvel never give up on their superheroes. It is all about leaving a legacy.I can't say much without spoilers but some of the cameos were a lovely gesture to some long lost superheroes.Three cameos particularly stands out. One where most of the audience guesses the character wrongly. Then the one with the glasses (you'll understand when you watch it) and last but not the least, the one from .. oh I can't reveal that.But it's a beautiful way to poke all the DC fans out there (me included).And now to Wolverine,So nice to see Hugh Jackman reprising his role without feeling any pressure on him. We could sense that he was enjoying the role again. There was a sense of calm this time (along with the rage). And the end credit scenes will leave a smile in you.

Review: This whole film and convoluted story shouldn't work, but it does because it is so funny. If Marvel were to stop making movies now, this would be a perfect ending. This phase of the MCU has been dire but Deadpool & Wolverine has made suffering through the awful Thor Love and Thunder and Antman 3 worth the wait. If it were any smarter, it'd write a book, a book that would make Ulysses look like it was written in crayon. It would read it to you. I can't remember the last time that I saw a film that caused so many laughs and happy reactions from the collective audience. Forget about the newish Doctor Doom. Give Deadpool his own phase.

Review: I loved this movie and I am not even a Marvel fan. Talk about one surprise after another. They literally brought back characters that were trapped in the back of the closet of my childhood memories. It has the right kind of edgy rated R comedy you would expect from Ryan Reynolds, and perhaps one of the best action sequences with the perfect amount of gore you would expect from a Deadpool movie. And of course nobody did this movie more justice than the return of Hugh Jackman to the Marvel/X-Men universe. He truly returned to the big screen with a loud echoing bang. Both he and Ryan Ronalds have such a chemistry together that made this movie one of my favorites. Wolverine with his serious attitude and Deadpool with his nonsensical humor. Truly opposites attract. This movie is definitely the best Deadpool movie of all time and is definitely one of the best Marvel movies of all time.
