Review: For those of us that were disappointed with Origins' depiction of this duo, the long wait is over. All I can say is thank you to Ryan Reynolds for persisting so that this project could be done, and done right.The comedy is gold, not just from the Merc with a Mouth, but from the rest of the cast as well. The script did not disappoint, it was dynamic and held enough surprises to keep you engaged throughout. The timing was definitely on point, every moment of repartee seemed to keep the pace at a dizzying speed.The action sequences, in my opinion, surpassed the incredible work of the first and second installments. I'm waiting for my rewind button to be able to back up for everything that I missed. Visually stunning, the artists that kept putting in Easter Eggs for us should be praised.Reynolds and Jackman put in maximum effort on their delivery, as we knew they would. The supporting cast brought their A games as well. I'll spare going into any depth at this time, because, spoilers.What I didn't expect was the amount of credit, homage and just sheer respect not only to past projects and those involved, but also to the fans. I'm grateful for the tied up loose ends, new doors opened and everything in between.Mr Reynolds... Thank you, thank you, thank you. You'll never know how much this movie meant to some of us.

Review: Is this a good movie? I have no idea. Is this the best superhero movie ever? Also no clue. Is it consistent with all the timelines in all the movies? Review: Finally Marvel has admitted quite directly that the multiverse saga has been a train wreck. Deadpool was the perfect character to do this. In putting Deadpool with Wolverine , Marvel has essentially been able to start the tare down and rebuild in the same movie. I was worried bringing back Wolverine was out of desperation, and it probably was, but it paid off. It was nice having Wolverine's seriousness to offset when Deadpool does in fact get annoying at times. Wolverines world also reminds you that some good superhero movies have been made and maybe it's possible again.As for the actual plot of this movie it's not really all that interesting. However, making the TVA a key feature of the movie was also clever. One thing from this saga most enjoyed was Loki. By including the TVA, Marvel has set up the potential for a nice conclusion to the saga instead of dragging us through more money making clutter.One thing that I will also add is that aside from Endgame , having watched lots of previous content will make the film much more rewarding. There are a lot of nice easter eggs along the way in this one. The soundtrack is probably also second best to Guardians.In conclusion, as a stand alone , the movie would probably be average with some funny moments you'd forget by the end of the ride home from the theatre. However , in setting up a promising future in just one movie, I say well done to a franchise that has not done much but let down for years now.

Review: This is exactly what I needed for this year. From the over the top unhinged comedy to the best fourth-wall breaking cameo's, an absolute must see & a sure way to cure depression. Switching production companies and giving directors the free reign to do what they want without hindering the franchises explicitness was the best decision they could have made. I genuinely smiled through majority of the film as well as had more than 50 unique laughs throughout the entirety of watching. The whole theater was in roar with bursts of laughter mixed with "Ooh's" & "Awes" leaving the atmosphere with NO WORRIES of the world.Suggestion: See in the theaters during a packed time while enhanced on THC or Psychedelics for a max, once in a lifetime experience.Bring your children as long as they are 13 or older, mature & understand the nature of comedy in film. Not safe for immature kids.Sneak food into the theater because everything promoting the movie is tempting but 25% more expensive than the regular non-themed items.Also, be prepared to become an instant "Deadpool & Wolverine" superfan because according to Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman & himself are going to be held under contract being forced to act as they main protagonists until they are 90 years of age.

Review: I have to say I am a huge Ryan Reynolds fan. The man is an absolute genius. Known more for his relationship then his mediocre movies he films the first Deadpool and shoots himself to the stars. He is not playing Deadpool, he is Deadpool and he took advantage of that the best way possible using it to become a super successful businessman and marketing executive. He knows his strengths and his weakness expertly and plays exactly on them.Having said all that about my admiration of what he has accomplished, I have, like many experienced superhero fatigue. Enough with multiverses and meaningless super heros. The Deadpool team knows it and plays it perfectly. Put on top of that Hugh Jackman who is going to be impossible to replace ad wolverine (until you are 90) and a bunch of Easter eggs and cameos this is an honest to God fun film. Don't care if the story is the greatest story ever or whatever other technical problema people have found, this was a fun fun film to watch. Even my wife loved it who HATES anything that has to do with superhero movies.If this is goodbye for Ryan Reynolds Deadpool and Hugh Jackman Wolverine, I could not imagine a better one.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine is a fun and comical with a lot of adult jokes, gore, violence and a lot of 4th wall violations. I liked the humor and Hugh Jackman being back as Wolverine and it was like two buddies on a road trip and getting on each others nerves occasionally.As much as I like the chemistry both the two leads, loads of exciting cameos and introduction of new actors in familiar and alternate Marvel roles, the underlying story, journey and conclusion was only alright for me. I probably had an overdose of multiverse and time and reality adventures in recent years that this movie was only alright for me.So, come to the movie to appreciate the visual and crude humor and familiar characters from bizarre alternate reality. The editing, action, sound and visual are excellent. Just don't expect much of tidy and profound story.

Review: Deadpool 1 and 2 were some of the best things to come out of Fox. When Disney brought Fox, I hoped that Ryan Reynolds would remain as Deadpool. Thankfully this is the case but they also brought back Hugh Jackman as Wolverine despite the perfect send-off in Logan. Does Deadpool continue to entertain or is this a tainting of Ryan and Hugh Jackman's legacy?Let's get the obvious out of the way, Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are still phenomenal as their Deadpool and Wolverine respectively. Both of them have excellent antagonistic chemistry. The contrast between Jackman's serious performance and Reynolds's jokey performance is incredibly fun to watch. What made previous Deadpool movies great is that while it was primarily a comedy, it had a lot of heart too. This is still the case here. Deadpool's love for Vanessa and his friends is still here and despite his stupid antics, it is very clear he is serious about them. Wolverine has immense guilt and Jackman's excellent performance conveys the pain perfectly. Both have great character arcs that are honestly very heart-warming and satisfying.On that note, the comedy continues to be hilarious! You still get the crude and dirty jokes, the fun meta ones, the downright silly ones. All of which got a chuckle out of me. What I appreciate most though is that the movie doesn't shy away from jokes that point fun at Disney or the current state of the MCU. The movie being part of the multiverse saga did worry me about it being a cameo fest. There are definitely moments with short appearances of individuals but there are also some proper appearances. Some of these "cameos" feel more like a supporting character. The movie also has a killer soundtrack that is used very effectively. There is a great sequence with Madonna and NSYNC that still stick in my mind. There are also some very entertaining action sequences that are well-choreographed. There is an excellent one in the intro and a unique one involving a car.Yet, for some reason, one of the action sequences in the beginning of the 3rd act is just weirdly bad. This one particular action set piece had such awful cuts and shaky camera that it was nearly impossible to tell what was going on. It is weird as every action set piece before was terrific and even the one after is amazing. None of them had shaky camera, except that one particular one. The Deadpool movies have had a lot of jokes that feel like you would need a bit of knowledge of things that occurred in the real world to understand. In this entry, there are definitely a lot more of these types of jokes. I understood all of it which is why it made me laugh but I was watching the movie with someone else and the jokes flew over their head. It's not a big problem but it is something to note, especially if you plan on watching this with another person.One of the weakest aspects of this movie compared to previous entries is the story. The stakes are higher than it ever has been with the whole universe of Deadpool being at stake. The problem is that we don't ever really feel it. There is no tension, suspense or urgency to the oncoming doom. Deadpool and Wolverine don't ever feel like they're in any rush. The multiverse setting also results in what feels like nothing is truly ever at stake. Characters could die but it never really feels like their death means anything. It also introduces more rules to the multiverse and it just raises so many questions. Despite this being a Deadpool movie in the MCU, the story is very inconsequential and doesn't really add anything. I also find the villain, Cassandra Nova, to be quite dull. They have cool powers and Emma Corrin gives a lively performance as the character. However, the villain's motive is very weak and they are not given enough depth for us to care one bit about them.Overall, Deadpool is Marvel Jesus. After a lot of stinkers from MCU movies, we finally get a genuinely great one. It doesn't taint the legacy left behind by Fox X-Men movies. If anything, Deadpool & Wolverine is a celebration of those past movies. It respectfully honours our nostalgia while also giving us hope for the future of MCU movies. I can't wait to see where Deadpool will turn up next!

Review: This movie is one of the most entertaining films, I have ever seen. From start to end I had a smile on my face. The action was some of the best I have ever seen from the Deadpool movies and Hugh Jackman's acting was incredible. This movie was full of suprises but still focused on Deadpool and Wolverine and gave them both necessary character arcs. This move is the conclusion of the Fox era of Marvel and as this film points out, it was a bittersweet journey that set the foundation for the current Marvel era. This movie brings the laughs, nostalgia and action while at the same time, bringing two characters together who fans have waited to see for fifteen years. This definitely the best film in the Deadpool trilogy and I highly recommend it for X-Men fans.

Review: "Welcome to the MCU! You're joining at a low point" tells the merc with a mouth to a brooding, self-loathing and hurting Wolverine. This line, along with the many fourth wall breaks that the titular anti-hero Deadpool performs now and then serve as a reminder about what this whole thing's business is: setting the record straight. It's a brash ad campaign for the fact that Disney is not afraid of the R-rating and that its questionable decisions in the past regarding the MCU were just one of many directions they can go. Make no mistake, this is Disney showing off but the reason why none of us are bothered by it is because this movie is helmed by flamboyant, relatable and wicked Ryan Reynolds (and I really do mean "helmed", as he is also part of the three co-writers).So then begins a dare: how many Joker-esque puns involving gore, drug abuse and masturbation (sometimes all at once) can one anti-hero cramp into a two hour running time before Disney gets its point across and the whole thing becomes an endurance test? Well, apparently a bit too many because by the end, the movie's sequential rapid-fire anecdotes do start to get tiring. Even Reynolds admits this, as there is a moment close to the ending of the movie where Deadpool looks at the camera and tells the audience to hang in there, as we are on the home stretch. I admit, having such a loveable hunk like Reynolds asking us to bear with him did make me cut him some slack.But while "Deadpool & Wolverine" might not be the best of movies, it's definitely worthy of belonging to the upper echelon of Marvel movies when it comes to entertainment. Its moments of fun are just cramming to get on the screen, most of them hitting the comedic timing perfectly: pop culture references, socio-political parodies and snappy one-liners that take you by surprise--I nearly choked on soda at one point). But they have to be like that, because there is not much depth to them. It's like doomscrolling through a webpage of memes whose lasting power is as brief as they appear on the screen, except that the memes are done professionally. It's all part of the dare.But this is not what all this movie is. There are moments when even the most depraved of anti-heroes must stop and take a look around. When the mask is off and Deadpool becomes Wade Wilson, he struggles with relatable personal pain like insignificance and meaning--"I don't know how to be a hero", he says at one point. This movie's plot, beneath all the distractions, is more or less him finding out how. And also not to mention Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, whose performance seems to only get better with age. He is a defeated and lost soul tormented by a great pain involving past failures. Together, Deadpool & Wolverine become the buddy-comedy duo of the MCU.After watching this movie, a lot of people might feel hope for the future of the MCU. Self-proclaimed internet pundits might even punch themselves in the chest, claiming Disney finally saw the errors of its ways and returned to form. But we cannot be sure that this is just not another phase--after all, of course a movie involving Deadpool would put the ESRB to work. Plus, regardless of anything, there is only so many ideas and so much energy a franchise has, even something as big as the MCU. I'm not saying the good days are behind us, I'm just saying that no promises have been made. Still, I will definitely smirk when I will inevitably see this quirky poster on Disney's streaming service next to the likes of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarves" or "The Sound of Music".

Review: I enjoyed this movie so much! Every moment in this movie is interesting, funny, full of action, or captivating. It's the first time in my life that I'm going to see the same movie twice! Ryan and Hugh do a wonderful job, staying true to their characters from previous movies and developing a relationship that I hope will continue in future films! I can say that, in my eyes, this movie saves the failing cinematic universe that Marvel has become in recent years. Additionally, this movie is a dream for '90s kids or anyone involved in the Marvel cinematic universe since the early 2000s. Go see it; you won't be disappointed.

Review: Deadpool once again filled us with jokes and plenty of interesting references and full suprise. The conflict between Deadpool and Wolverine in every scene works really well, and I really enjoyed it. However, the story and villains in this film seem overshadowed by these. The plot is rather flat without significant development. The villain in this film also lack strong motivation and characteristic.Deadpool & Wolverine are like trying a new variant of ice cream. Initially, it may taste fresh and special, but over time, it becomes just typical marvel film. Nonetheless, it's still an enjoyable film that you can rewatch, recommended for those who just want to enjoy the film without a heavy plot.

Review: A ton of fun at the movies, with definitely the highest count of jokes that actually work in the MCU.But...is it really an MCU movie? Tangentely, perhaps. It's not even a full Fox Mutant movie either. It ends up being something very much unique, given the history of Marvel on film.The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds being his quipy self and Hugh Jackman in a permanent state of grumpy annoyance is off the charts and both actors play off each other perfectly,If you're into easter egg hunts, this movie might be your new treasure trove. The amount of in-jokes, cameos and references is staggering and it might take you a few times to catch all of them.

Review: If you liked the previous offerings, you will like Deadpool and Wolverine.Just watched it in 3d, and it has a consistent fast pace, all action and very funny humour throughout. The film never slackens in pace and humour. It is consistently very entertaining throughout.Storyline exactly how wolverine gets in the film is actually irrelevant. The whole multi-universe thing is just a vehicle for lazy script writing to allow any character and any scenario, justified by the mumbo jumbo of a parrallel universe and mixed time dimension jibber jabber.However, the 'why' and 'how' in this film is irrelevant and forgotten, because Reynolds and Jackman are so funny together and it's non stop action. Ably supported by many other stars.There is also a lot of irreverence about fox, and interestingly about Disney (perhaps they are starting to get the message, we watch cinema to escape reality in a good story, not be lectured)Solid 8.5/10 very entertaining and one of the few films I've seen over the last 12 months that is worth the price of a cinema ticket.Went to see this at a 'midnight' viewing and it was a great experience.

Review: Went to the theater with the missus to enjoy Deadpool and Wolverine and was not disappointed! It is a raunchy, over the top, action filled, comedy that still manages to do what I love aabout all of the deadpool movies: It has heart. Moments of gravity that ground the movie and makes you care about the characters. Hugh Jackman returning was done (dis)tastfully in a way that works for fans of Logan, like my self, and people who just wanted to see the team up. No spoilers, but the amount of special cameos and refrences in the movie are a treasure trove of rewatchability! The writing was spectacular and everything else from the cinematography to the special effects and soundtrack were top notch! I can see why someone might not like it in the sense that it is a lot, the villain motivations are a little weak, but they drive the plot forward in a way that makes it feel equal parts world ending and personal. I'd put it just below the first one in terms of over all enjoyment and slightly above 2. It was as lot of fun and I can't wait to see it again!

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" (2024) is a highly entertaining and humorous addition to the Deadpool franchise. Directed by Shawn Levy, the film features Ryan Reynolds reprising his role as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman returning as Wolverine, delivering strong performances with their characteristic charm and chemistry.The film's plot involves Wade Wilson (Deadpool) coming out of retirement to address a new existential threat, leading to a team-up with Wolverine. This installment is noted for its comedic tone, with plenty of meta-humor, fourth-wall breaks, and fast-paced gags that fans of the previous films will appreciate. The humor is even more pronounced than in the first two movies, making it the funniest entry yet.Despite being an R-rated film under Disney, "Deadpool & Wolverine" does not shy away from adult content, featuring gratuitous violence and strong language, ensuring that it remains true to its predecessors in terms of tone and content.While the film excels in humor and action, it does face some criticism for its pacing and the underdevelopment of its villains. However, the strong performances by Reynolds and Jackman, along with numerous cameos and nostalgic references, more than make up for these shortcomings. The film serves as a fitting tribute to the Fox/Marvel universe and is likely to be a hit among fans of the franchise.Overall, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a delightful, action-packed film that embraces its chaotic, comedic nature, making it a must-watch for fans of the Deadpool series and Marvel enthusiasts alike.

It was entertaining and funny the way they carried about but I was kind of wishing for more calm in the relationship.It was gorey and gruesome and unholy in the violence at times. But it was funny and silly and not realistic which masked that. But, horrible if you think about it much.

Review: Why, Hugh? Why? You had a great end with Logan. Why come back for this fan fare?? It was just a movie of cameos. Story was weak. Logan was a masterpiece. Review: I don't think I'm a Marvel guy. I have liked some of the Marvel movies, but the vast majority have struck me as just being comical and stupid. However, I liked the first two Deadpool movies a lot, and I thought I would like this one as I like Wolverine. However, it ended up being a bunch of nonsense and garbage with a weak storyline, violence for the safe of violence without enhancement of the plot, and a predictable ending. This was just a reason to put Wolverine on the big screen with Deadpool with no thought given to how to develop a story and actually make it make sense. I was shocked by how bored I was during the movie and how meaningless it felt. Maybe the last Marvel movie I'll ever go to.

Review: I am a huge fan of the Deadpool movie and the Wolverine movies & I am a huge fan of all the Marvel and DC superhero movies but I went in not sure if this was going to be a good movie but as the credits started to roll I wanted the movie to keep going. It is action packed from beginning to end, it's extremely funny and the entire storyline was amazing as well as the movie using Madonna's number 1 hit song like a prayer from her 1989 like a prayer album.Also a little trivia about them using Madonna's song Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman had to go to Madonna's house to ask for permission to use the song Madonna wanted them to come in person and from what Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman said on the TV show the view last week Madonna actually gave them Ideas for the scene where the music was used and the Director actually listened to Madonna and made the few changes and added a few things for Madonna to approve it and it's rare for Madonna to ever allow her music to be used in movies.P. S I've loved Madonna since her 1st single in 1983Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman did an outstanding job and the chemistry they had on the screen was amazing but not surprising considering in real life they are extremely close friends & for any of those who have left negative reviews you're just a tad bit insane because I couldn't find one thing wrong with the movie and Marvel Studios made a home run movie with this. Also this movie was a huge blockbuster hit Deadpool & Wolverine' Lands 6th Biggest Opening of All Time.The Ryan Reynolds Hugh Jackman superhero movie smashed numerous records both domestically and overseas for a stunning global launch of $444.1 million & it certainly made it money back considering the budget on the film was 200 million.I really hope that they make a sequel to this because it definitely deserves a sequel because it was that good. Also, as far as the negative reviews do NOT listen to them at all because people have become so picky & insane about everything marvel & DC does makes, these so-called marvel/DC fans have trashed the last few superhero movies that were all excellent movies. I truly don't know what they want or expect but I don't ever listen to the negative reviews because when people say it's horrible I end up loving it.I truly don't know what people are looking for in these superhero movies anymore. They're amazing so again do NOT listen to the negative reviews. Go see the movie for yourself and I'm sure you will love it as much as I did.

I haven't been this excited about a film since Spiderman: Far From Home. The film has a running time of 2 hrs but those hours felt too short with all the visuals that it had. This film made me excited about the next projects Marvel is going to put out. They have been releasing filler movies previously that were flopping; but they look to be going back to excitement. They really made a film for the fans. They heard us and they delivered. A must watch for any marvel fans.

Review: Despite being an overall enjoyable ride, ultimately Deadpool & Wolverine is a disappointment.On the surface the movie seems to have the same ingredients as its predecessors: tons of immature jokes out of which a small percentage is actually funny, constant pop culture references, fourth wall breaking, cameos and abundant violence. But there's one key ingredient missing: heart.Where DP 1&2 had great chemistry between characters, DP&W has nothing, not even between the titular duo. Reynolds and Jackman act out the same caricature in a series of sketches - one is an annoying idiot (this time for real, they managed to dumb down even Deadpool) while another growls angrily. There's no convincing character development or bonding here - just whining that one wants to matter and save his friends while another let everyone down and is thus sad and grumpy. Wade and Vanessa's relationship went from believable and touching to virtually nothing: there's now an implausible problem between them made up specifically for this movie, and it gets resolved automatically for the sake of happy ending without any effort on their part.All of which leads to another big problem of this film - its plot, or rather lack thereof. It is just a messy excuse to tie together a few scenes, and if you take a moment to think about what is happening on screen it falls apart instantaneously. It feels like an elongated SNL sketch, or an R-rated Disneyland attraction - there isn't a story being told, it's just going through motions. Now's the time for the 100th gay sex joke from Deadpool (their concentration increased suspiciously now that it's a Disney production), and now on to an obligatory uninspired blandly-choreographed fight. Quick pause for cameo, repeat for 2 hours straight. The first two Deadpool movies made it just fine without a convincing antagonist, but this time around the two villains are such painfully evident overly-grimacing cardboard cutout cliches that it gets so jarring to watch them.Sure, there are some cameos that are actually surprising and well-done (I didn't watch any trailer past the first one), and jokes that land (do watch the after-credits scene, it's hilarious). Time flies by relatively fast, even if with some drags closer to the third act, and I left the screening with an overall positive impression, but still, sadly, Deadpool & Wolverine is a huge step down compared to Deadpool 1 & 2.

Review: Disney has the reverse Midas touch and when you compare this Deadpool to the first two, it really shows.Ryan Reynold's jokes, while witty, got a little tiring because they didn't really go anywhere or relate to the plot. Multiple jokes at Disney, Fox, being from Canada, including references to the go-to fast food in one of the cities he lived in, ans countless gay jokes toward Wolverine which amounted to nothing. Like if you're gonna go the route of gay jokes, at least give me some action like a make out scene between Deadpool and Wolverine.The plot? There is no plot. It's your typical Disney Marvel movie, which is just CGI violence that goes nowhere. This one was slightly better in that it was the jokes of Ryan Reynolds with CGI violence. But basically no different than if you watched stand up comedy and video game demo at the same time.The antagonist, like every other Disney Marvel movie, was British. The UK has more dialects of English than the rest of the world combined, yet for some reason every Disney villain has the same British accent.And like all Disney movies, it was ugly. The characters were all unattractive to look at, despite the actors not being unattractive in real life. The scenery was ugly, and everything had that orange tint to it.If Ryan Reynolds did Stand-up, I would watch it. But Disney maybe needs to pay their actors less and take that extra money to pay someone who actually knows how to write a screenplay.

Review: As a kid of the 80's and 90's watching the Uncanny X-Men, reading comics, seeing the evolution of the characters in film, this movie made my wife and I, both 44, feel like kids again. It is pure love for the fans and we love you Ryan, Hugh and the whole team who brought this to life.No part of the movie felt slow or drawn out, the action was intense, frequent, and gloriously bloody. The characters are well established and treated with love without wasted world building. It feels fresh and new all while keeping the nostalgia alive and constant. From start to finish it constantly pulled us back to our childhoods and kept us smiling the whole time. Just be sure to stay after all the credits play, DO NOT leave until the very very end.

Review: Irony everywhere. We live in a world where standup comics have to tone down their material for fear of triggering, and email users have to watch the words they use for fear of "misinformation" laws (Canada). But, wonder of wonders, this film teaches us that there yet remains a sacred space where ANY topic can be mocked, riffed, and deconstructed, with no fear of reprisal. In fact, the money just rolls in. No matter that 7 decades of canon and character-building are sacrificed. No matter that an entire generation is growing up thinking this is the way films are supposed to be made. The good news is that Jackman gets a payday (which he deserves), and Reynolds thinks he is funnier than Robin Williams (which he isn't). All in all, a merry time was had by all. ((Designated "IMDb Top Reviewer." Please check out my list "167+ Nearly-Perfect Movies (with the occasional Anime or TV miniseries) you can/should see again and again (1932 to the present))

Review: If there is any film released this year that movie goers were going to see regardless of what Rotten Tomatoes thought, this would be it. The ghosts of Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel could not stop audiences from seeing this thing. Hell, nothing short of nuclear war or Madame Web type of word of mouth could prevent D & W from being a huge hit.With that said, I can't imagine anyone enjoying this who isn't already some sort of Marvel super fan. I mean, I like Marvel movies but there were tons of references in this flick that I didn't get and had to look up when I got home. Personally, I didn't like homework when I was in school. I certainly don't want it in my cinema experience. Of course, as I mentioned, this is a huge box office success so I might be in the minority on that. In any case, I did laugh at the jokes I did get. And I'm enough of a Marvel head to wonder why Loki's supporting cast is in this but Loki isn't. Other than that, all I can say is, if picture is fondly remembered (or remembered at all) in a decade I would be very surprised.

Review: One of the best marvel movies in awhile. Hands down the best Deadpool movie. Would watch over and over again. There are no word that explain it. No works of art can compare. Deadpool and Wolverine's latest film is a thrilling ride packed with irreverent humor and intense action. Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool brings his trademark wit and fourth-wall-breaking antics, while Hugh Jackman's Wolverine delivers the grit and intensity fans love. Their chemistry is electric, balancing humor and drama effortlessly. The storyline cleverly intertwines their worlds, offering fresh dynamics and unexpected twists. With stellar performances and top-notch visuals, this film is a must-watch for superhero enthusiasts craving a mix of laughter and edge-of-your-seat excitement.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine is the third Deadpool film. This film is directed, partly written and produced by Shawn Levy, director of Night at the Museum, Reel Steal and Free Guy.After all Wade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) his adventures he is now trying to take it easy. He tries to live a more normal life, without using his superhero alter ego Deadpool. This changes when the time agents of the TVA come after him for all the adjustments he has made to the timelines.When mutant Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin) then forms a bigger oath, Deadpool must try to stop this threat together with a variant of Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), before all timelines are in danger.After Disney took over the film studio 20th Century Fox, they also got the film rights of the X-men, as well as the rights of the character Deadpool. Deadpool is actually not a character you expect to see in the more child-friendly world of Disney. Fortunately, they have found a good way to bring back the character of Deadpool in a familiar way, without making it really child-friendly. This is, strangely enough, the first official r rated superhero film in the Marvel film series.It is good to see that Disney now also seems to dare to make more adult films, so that they can also please older viewers. This film is such an entertaining r rated film, with brutal action, blood, swear words and other adult material. The Disney film studio gives itself more opportunities to also make films about adult material. In this way, in addition to family and children's films, they can now also try to reach the adult target group with their own r rated films. In addition, they can now also try to use other, more adult acquired film rights from 20th Century Fox, to also make these film series their own or to continue with them.Ryan Reynolds has, in addition to playing the lead role, also been involved in this film as a producer and writer. In this way, he has made a great effort to ensure that the character remains as well-known as possible for fans of the character. Fans who know Deadpool from the two previous Deadpool films, from the comics or from other films, or animations can have a similar experience with this new film. Furthermore, he also provides many moments of meta humor about the film world, other things from pop culture and of course moments where he breaks the fourth wall. Hugh Jackman seemed to be done with playing the Wolverine character, after the film Logan from 2017. When Ryan shared his ideas with him, to come back as the character again, he eventually did so. The two are also good friends with each other and, like their characters, have good chemistry. In this way, they know how to play well with and against each other.Fortunately, the story has also become a good thing of its own, because many feared that this film would become more of a film with comic references and cameos. Several cameos and references are in the film, but fortunately without them overshadowing the film and trying to be something of their own. So, after a more low point in the Marvel film series, they can hopefully handle the future film ideas and stories a bit better after this film and get the series back in shape.Director Shawn Levy already has experience with directing action films, but in this comic film adaptation, during some action scenes, many things happen at the same time with several different characters. Here, everything is sometimes not always clearly shown, so you can't always follow everything exactly. This can sometimes take you out of the film or cause confusion.

Review: This fun cross-over met my expectations! I will preface that my rating is only slightly on the lower side because that's how I felt about the other Deadpool movies too. Solid, slap-stick, gore-y fun!These actors are top-notch and the action scenes were great. The humor was well performed and the graphics were smooth. The plot was a little scattered at times, but that's consistent with some of the Marvel movies if you don't do your research before. I think the comedy is what elevated this movie- Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool guarantees hysterical witty punchlines, and in conjunction with Hugh Jackman (Wolverine), I was entertained from start to finish. Definitely recommend to any action/Marvel lover!

Review: Ok so just to make this clear, I'm just a casual moviegoer who decided to watch this movie because I had nothing better to do. I'm not a Marvel fan, and I haven't watched any of the X-men movies. With all this in mind, I was due for some pretty interesting surprises.What I can say from my experience, with all due respect, is that I could most easily relate this to No Way Home (one of the few Marvel movies I've actually seen). Although the story itself is kind of convoluted and ties into lore from several previous X-men and Marvel installments, most of the experience is carried by the non-stop action and satirical jokes by Deadpool, which filled the movie from start to finish. The reason I tend to compare this movie to No Way Home is because I think both are films that are designed primarily for the life-time fans of the franchises (hence the many cameos), however they tend to provide a solid and (to an extent) smooth experience for many casual moviegoers like me. If I had to pick my preference between the two I'd have to go with this one, just because of the amount of jokes that kept me rolling.Maybe your wondering the reason I only gave this movie 7 stars. Like I said, I'm not a Marvel fan and I haven't seen any of the other Deadpool films so of course I'm not going to understand every little detail. My primary criticism with the movie comes from the lack of explanation or clarification to just how insanely convoluted and twisted the entire premise of the movie is, let alone the hero's' objectives. I guess I'm not fluent enough with the X-men lore to have understood many of the details regarding the characters and their universes, although I will say it definitely had an impact on my experience. I know it may seem a little mixed because this movie itself is technically a sequel (although I had no idea how interconnected the Deadpool franchise was with the X-men universe).I could go on about this and highlight more of my specific praises and criticisms with the movie but at the end of the day, I can appreciate it for what it's trying to be, even though it's not my kind of movie. I'd probably only recommend this to people who've at least seen enough Deadpool or X-men films to have a basic understanding of the worldbuilding. However, I still had a good time with it, and to anyone else who enjoys action-filled dark comedies I think you'll have a damn good time with it as well.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a regular movie, with a script with tons of black humor, irreverence and offensively funny dialogues that in this era are not so common in film productions and that will manage to bother closed minds and amuse open minds, but the story becomes slow at times and even repetitive in the Marvel universe. The performances of the duo Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are fun and with a lot of chemistry, while Emma Corrin plays a ruthlessly comic villain. The soundtrack is full of good songs (mostly), the cinematography is ordinary without any notable quality, the level of production is perceived to be low and the special effects manage to be realistic in some scenes and terrible in others. A film with no other pretensions than to provide fan service, with a fun story of black humor but full of ups and downs.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine, directed by Shawn Levy, is an obnoxious film that stars Ryan Reynolds and is a double act already paired up in Marvel comic books. Both are self-healers, have authority issues, and have substance abuse problems. However, their differences, such as being slashed, stabbed, and punched out in close combat in a Honda minivan, give the film its juice. The film earns every last month of its 15 certificate for its gore and risque gags. Deadpool and Wolverine are flung together after the timeline of Deadpool's universe is threatened with abrupt termination by Mr. Paradox, a rogue agent of the Time Variance Authority. Since the death of the Wolverine in Deadpool's universe is a key factor in its demise, Deadpool goes multiverse-hopping for a replacement, finding the worst version - a self-loathing, drunken failure. Redemption beckons, but not before plenty of effects-driven carnage and a run-in with Cassandra, the deranged evil twin of Professor Charles Xavier. The film earns every last month of its 15 certificate for its gore and risque gags. Disney acquired 20th Century Fox in 2018 and began working on its first sequel to Deadpool, a popular R-rated Marvel character. Despite being from the Marvel label, Reynolds' character was not easily adapted into Disney's less edgy PG-13 Marvel Cinematic Universe. Six years later, the first R-rated MCU movie, Deadpool & Wolverine, was released in 2024, bringing a dream teaming for fans. The results for Deadpool & Wolverine are truly out of this world. Deadpool & Wolverine, a film directed by Shawn Levy, stars Reynolds and Hugh Jackman in a forced odd coupling, reminiscent of Godzilla vs. Kong and Midnight Run. The chemistry between the stars is evident, with Reynolds describing the film as like Fox dumped Wolverine, Disney picked him up, and Jackman "has to play him until he is 90." The movie is the most anticipated of the summer, proving a new future for both characters in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Reynolds' character, Wolverine, is a crackerjack quipster who constantly breaks the fourth wall, letting no one off the hook, including the studio. The jokes come at you so rapid-fire that one viewing is way too much. Levy, who co-produced and co-wrote the film, abandons his family-friendly filmography and fits comfortably into this particular universe, allowing the blue comedy to rip and the action to soar while ingesting heart and friendship into a winning mix that never seems off for a minute in the 127-minute running time. Rated R for strong bloody violence and language throughout, gore and sexual references.

Review: I'm a die hard fan of Wolverine and after the great "Logan", I was a bit scared that they would screw up this temporary comeback. But man, it was perfect. 2 minutes in, I knew what I was getting into and I was grinning like a kid. I'm so grateful for the fans that didn't spoil the cameos and the guests actors ! What a joy to see some favorites reappearing. And what a great gig for an older Hugh Jackman, who's in top shape, more charismatic than ever. I laughed, I applauded, I cringed, I cried (during the credits). The villain is great and plausible. In a nutshell, it was such a fun ride that I can't wait to see it again.

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine is well worth the entry cost.Yes there is no story, it's just a string of action, comedy, violence, quips, swearing and more cameos than you could fit on the Ark but it is so much fun.The Cameos in particular are fun but meaningful if you know your comic book.movie history, and some unexpected ones. Lot's of quips at expense of Disney and 20th Century Fox too. The connection between Ryan and Jackman make it work.If you don't like swearing, violence and gore then this isn't for you, but if you know the seadpool movies that would be well known.It's fun, go see it in the movies.

Review: Went to this movie a little over a week after it released. Thank god, because I had heard that people clap for every character that was cameo'd and i find that to be so annoying (my theater didnt, LUCKILY). I feel that I can accurately review this movie because the largest disney fan in the world sat next to me; let me tell you about her. This lady laughed as loud as she could, even the jokes nobody else thought was funny and had to explain to the guy she came in with who every character was in every single cameo, one time he even shushed her. I can attribute my bad viewing experience with this lady because the movie was basically pandering to anyone who has consumed a large amount of disney media, rather than actually flesh out a movie. The cameos were cool but yet were shoe-horned into the movie to make up for plot.I must say it had cool action scenes and I liked Wolverine and Deadpool's relationship dynamic. Word to the wise; wait a week before these movies come out so you don't sit with anyone as annoying and unlikable as the woman I sat next to.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is absolutely fantastic, a true rollercoaster that takes us on a hallucinatory journey at full throttle. The movie fulfilled what it promised, giving a huge breath of fresh air to the "MCU" even without making a significant change in the paths already traced, but rather by providing "Marvel's" return to the good movie's and giving a true experience to those who go to a movie theater to see a movie from this studio. This movie is not meant to be an epic record-breaker like "Avengers Endgame" was, but rather it is a "Marvel" event in the style of "Spider-Man No Way Home" because it is full of surprises, special appearances, lots of comedy and hilarious moments with the "Deadpool" signature, non-stop action with lot's of gore in the mix, great combat scenes, good special effects and lot's and lot's of fan service. In short, "Deadpool & Wolverine" leaves us with a smile on our faces after the movie ends and when we leave the movie theater we want to see it again, that is the most important thing and it's been a long time since that happened, It should be noted that the movie is "Deadpool" in it's purest form like the previous ones, and it carries this movie in a fantastic way once again by the hands of "Ryan Reynolds" who makes this role his life, but the icing on the cake It's the return of "Hugh Jackman" as he once again plays "Wolverine" and once more, without exception, every time he appears, he ends up completely stealing the show, making this duo something truly special to remember later once again. "LFG"

Review: I recently watched Deadpool and Wolverine on Amazon Prime (yes, I paid for it, unfortunately), and while I enjoyed it, I couldn't help but compare it to the first two Deadpool movies, which I found much more entertaining. Don't get me wrong, I laughed-just not as much or as consistently as I did with the previous films. The humor felt a bit more restrained this time around, which isn't necessarily bad, but it didn't have that same relentless energy that made me love the original two.I went into this movie like a disciplined Puritan, avoiding all the teaser clips on YouTube to save myself for the full experience. In hindsight, this probably would've been better in theaters. It's one of those films, much like Oppenheimer, where I'm glad I saw it, but I'm equally glad that I won't need to see it again. Well, maybe I'll give the extended director's cut a go when that inevitably gets released, but that's likely it.Unlike the first two Deadpool films, which I can pick up and watch from any scene and still enjoy over and over, this one doesn't have that same rewatchability. I appreciated it for what it was, but it lacks that magic that would make me want to revisit it regularly. For fans, it's still worth the watch, but for me, it doesn't have that endless charm. Decent? Sure. Instant classic? Not quiteDo I think trolls and bots beef up the reviews online? Absolutely. There's no doubt in my mind that a bunch of trolls and bots were at work, boosting the reviews for Deadpool and Wolverine. You can spot them a mile away-overly glowing, repetitive comments that don't quite match the actual experience of the film. It's almost like they were written by people (or algorithms) who hadn't even watched it. While I did enjoy the movie, the rave reviews online seemed a bit... overhyped. It's pretty clear that the internet armies were out in full force to give it an artificial bump.

Review: Some of the people I watched this movie with were complaining how there was no real story and nothing happened except action. But come on, its a Deadpool movie.I think the point of this movie was pure fan service and pure fun. Of course it did not branch out of a classic Marvel movie but I enjoyed it over most of the superhero movies I have seen in last years.For me this is on par, or slightly better than the first part which was a masterpiece.Will have to rewatch it again to catch all the references and cameos.I guess it will be a hit or miss depending on what you are looking for. If you are expecting a fully developed complex story its not for you. If you appreciate jokes and cameos and fun, with some refreshing things for recent Marvel movies, then you will for sure enjoy.

Review: This movie was such a wasted opportunity. It could have been something, something more, but it chose to be a movie of this moment. That will delight many people, it will be catharsis for others after recent struggles, and annoy some as well.The original Deadpool was a great satire of the superhero genre that the mcu was. This is more akin to an internet comment section comes to life.Ryan reynolds is having a blast, so is Hugh jackman, I enjoyed Emma corrin as well.The action suffers from being unimaginative. By this I mean every one fights the same way. It's been an issue in every superhero movie. There is no reason that Deadpool and Logan would fight the same.If you want to see a movie that repeats a few juvenile jokes for 2 hours, this is for you. Over the top violence for the sake of it, for you. A ton of sexual references, for you.I was just disappointed because I was hoping for than Ryan reynolds making dick jokes and three year criticisms of the mcu. The Deadpool franchise has the ability to take risks and plays to the lowest common denominator.This movie will absolutely delight many people which is evident by the score and multiple reviews. It just doesn't work for me due to being paper thin in just about everything and very repetitive with its jokes.

Review: The good, was entertaining, good action scenes, Wolverine definitely didn't get enough raw slashing time in previous movies.Cameos were cool and the really abstract and meta idea of merging cinematic universes was realized. The multiverse overall is tough for movies because it's so abstract and distant from reality and you've seen that in marvels box office struggles this phase.Villains were an interesting choice, while well done, I don't think we'll see them again, which is somewhat disappointing to lack the MCU continuity there.Wolverine and Deadpool had good chemistry and the actors themselves seemed like they were having fun.Could you skip it? Yes. Was it entertaining? Yes.

Review: About 10 minutes into this film I had a startling realisation. I realised there was a good chance I was going to have to give a film in the much despised (by me) MCU a 10/10 rating. I was just having such a good time with 'Deadpool' on his own unleashing brilliant line after brilliant line. Then 'Wolverine' came into the picture and the film quickly lost a lot of momentum.I'll never understand what people see in the 'Wolverine' character. My only guess is that Hugh Jackman is such an incredible and charismatic actor that he was enough to make people fall in love with an otherwise boring character. And usually I would just accept that and move on. But I'm Jackman's biggest fan and he does nothing for me as 'Wolverine'.The only other gripe I have with the film is the amount of time we have to spend watching the two leads fight, despite knowing that neither one can do any harm to the other one. Sure, some of the choreography is funny and it breaks up the story a bit, but man, could they not find some way to put some stakes into it?Otherwise I had a pretty good time with this one. 'Deadpool' was as hilarious as always, the music choices were terrific and the villain was decent. 8.5/10.

Review: The two main characters did not need to fight each other that many times, or for that long. The minivan fight, really!?Secondly, I'm no prude, I love R rated films and as much gore as you want, but I'm classy believe it or not, so I don't throw F bombs around all day either. The writers here don't see superheroes that way, and the only thing overdone more than fight scenes is the number of F bombs. It gets to the point where you think you're watching an 80s high schooler's demo film who got the teachers approval to use profanity. Do better Marvel/Disney/whoever is running the ship now.Anyway, I'm glad I didn't pay for the ticket to this flick.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine was a good movie. A movie that was able to help me forget about Marvels latest shortcomings. I am extremely happy Disney didn't intervene in this project because they tend to destroy good things. This was probably my favorite of the three Deadpool movies even with the pretty big plot holes and inadequate writing. I like the character appearances, they gave the audience those big oooohhhh, ahhhhhh moments. Overall in comparison to older Marvel Greats like Ironman and Captain America, this doesn't compare on a story level. However, everyone knows these Deadpool movies aren't meant to be taken seriously. I gave the movie an 8 because it was actually watchable compared to movies like the previous Ant-man movie, and it gave me a good laugh.

Review: We all know that Marvel has been a little shaky lately with productions that are not at all captivating. Heartless films that seem like they are only there to compose a universe that always seeks to expand without caring about the story being told and only bringing uninteresting things. That said, how good it is to see a film that was made with the heart, with the sole intention of having fun and having a good laugh with what you are watching. Deadpool & Wolverine was everything we needed, a film that cares about telling its story and making you laugh with the (sensational) jokes that the film has, but those who have a certain amount of knowledge of the films before this one can enjoy it even more .Regarding the story, which isn't actually as incredible (which isn't supposed to be and that's a good thing) compared to the other two. And unfortunately, it felt a little dragged at times, especially in the second act of the film, where I felt that some scenes went on too long, especially involving certain characters introduced during the film. In addition to having missed a little how the film deals with old characters from the Deadpool franchise, as much as that is an opinion.The film's humor is IMPECCABLE, seriously, all the comedic moments in this film are really good, and especially the jokes involving the MCU. The same level of incredible can be said about the action scenes, which are very well directed, with many scenes in which the action is done in sequence, which makes the scene much more organic. The film's CGI is great in the film, although at one point or another it remains very fake and ugly, but in general it is very good... The first act of the film is personally the best part of the entire film, where all the funniest parts of the film are and ESPECIALLY its opening, which is honestly one of the best openings of a film I've seen in a long time. Its second act in this case has great scenes, but as I mentioned it has some scenes that are a little more drawn out involving a certain character in the film. And the third act where a series of frantic action scenes take place and which, yes, has a good conclusion to the story, although the solution to stop the threat in my opinion was a little... without consequences, I think. But it's not bad, just a little strange.The film's title characters are definitely the best thing about the film, seeing these two acting together and talking is a treat for fans of this character, and especially for fans of Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, my God, how good it is to see this man returning to the character. Ryan Reynolds, as always, delivering everything as Deadpool, only this time with a much more personal and emotional objective in the film, meaning that his character is not just about the jokes, giving an even more emotional tone, which is enhanced by the character of Wolverine , which also has a heavier tone for his character. But these two together are incredible and VERY funny and all their scenes are incredible, because these characters along with their actors have an absurd level of charisma that always makes us want to pay attention to them all the time. There are several other characters in the film, such as the film's special appearances, which are many, and which are really surprising (some are more surprising, but surprising) and which help the film, being (mainly) in the comedy or even in the emotional weight of the film. Film. The antagonists/villains, however, are a slightly more complicated case, at various times they are very interesting to follow and have understandable motivations given who their characters are, for a few moments I found the interpretation of each of the actors to disconnect me a little from the film. , as much as I know that part of the film is to be that and I overlooked that point. Other characters in the film, like those in the previous films, don't appear much, but they're there, they're not really missed, but at least they're there.The separate songs for the film are sensational, my goodness, what a good thing to hear in the film, but not only are they good, they also make a lot of sense with the scenes in the film. The opening song says so. Not only that, but the film's entire original soundtrack is very good.--------//-------//--------Deadpool & Wolverine is a good comedy and action film that doesn't reinvent the wheel but does a well-done and fun job, which is what we've needed for a long time in this Marvel universe. The two title characters have an absurd chemistry and that's why every scene of interaction with them works perfectly. Definitely a film worth watching not only for its characters, but for its incredible comedy and action scenes in an uncompromising and very fun film, something we need more of in certain hero films nowadays.

Review: I've seen many comments mentioning that the movie is great in so many aspects, but has no story. I think great part of it is because the villain story is so weak. It's that kind of villain that's just there to be beaten at the end. Her motive is so weak that you don't feel the real threat. Basically "I love living in the void, so ultimately I want to kill all other realities so the void is the only one". Even though it makes no difference for the if the others realities exists or not, since she only lives in the void.But ok, enough with the bad part (in my opinion)The movie is great. Not only because all of the obvious things (cast, nostalgia, cameos, soundtrack, etc), but mainly because it's a ray of hope that MCU can eventually get back on track. The movie specifically admits that the MCU is failing, that the F'd up.Of course there's a possibility that this is the money grabber so they can then continue making bombs like Shehulk and Marvels, but i don't think this will be the way.Deadpool is a delight for the fans. And I'm happy to see that Disney didn't mess up this great character.

Review: Hello film fans I hope you are all well. So they finally did it, they got Hugh back to play everyone's favourite mutant! Was it worth the wait? Yes, yes indeed it was! As a huge Deadpool fan, reading the comics, playing the games and been to every midnight preview of each film, I was VERY excited to see this one! I even called jackman being in part 3 as me and my friends left the cinema after the brilliant second movie(I LOVE DUBSTEP! Lol). The first film was a good start, despite DP not having the multiple personalities that he has in the comics it was a great introduction to the character. The second one was for me one of the best comic book movies ever, great story, great action, great gags and of course, a great soundtrack! So the bar was already very high for this next one especially with Jackman back! It surpasses expectations! From the BRILLIANT opening credits to the final showdown it is pure brain candy! It has everything you'd expect from a DP movie and more! I won't give any spoilers but hurry up and see it before you hear any! I had my favourite cameo spoiled before seeing it but it didn't ruin anything luckily! This film has single handedly saved the poor excuse that is Marvel these days, this film will do the numbers that endgame did and it deserves to! Endgame was a movie that was totally overhyped and just delivered plot hole after plot hole! This film nails everything it aims at! Jackman is (surprise surprise) brilliant as Logan as usual. The chemistry between him and DP will keep you laughing all the way through, and the violence, well, let's just say it's as graphic and as brutal as you'd expect from these two titans of comics! Ok so without giving ANYTHING away I'll have to stop there! Go see it asap because you WILL want to see it again! Thank you for listening and until the next time, stay safe, and may the force be with you.

Review: This movie was everything you expect from a deadpool movie. Don't expect a detailed plot with a great story. We wanted hilarious 4th wall breaks, nostalgic cameos and great action sequences. And my God they delivered.I can't remember the last time I laughed so much in the cinema. From the first second till the last I was in stitches from the non-stop jokes. The chemistry from Ryan and Hugh is second to none.Probably the best Marvel movie I've seen since No way home. The MCU hasn't been great this phase, but we may have found our saviour.Part of the MCU deservedly so. Just absolute pure fan service.8.5/10.

Review: I found the movie, overall, to be an easy watch. Some of the jokes landed well, the costumes for many characters looked nice, and I love the nostalgic cameos that we get. I like the opening montage where Deadpool dances / kills to N'Sync's "Bye Bye Bye"; and I like the first fight scene between Deadpool and WolverineSeveral shortcomings prevent the movie from reaching A+ level though. Some of the jokes, particularly the ones involving Fox Network, fall flat. Too much of the movie occurs in The Void, and Professor X's sister is nowhere close to being intimidating or interesting enough to be the primary villain. The whole plot involving "Anchor Beings" and multiverses seems lazyMy last criticism is that I just didn't like seeing Jackman reprise his role as Wolverine after Logan. He had the best send-off to his character. Many people defend his return by noting that "this is another Logan from another universe," but I find that nuance to be splitting hairs. The character in this movie is still Wolverine played by Jackman, and we see many references to Logan, including an appearance one specific character. Therefore, the movie does diminish Jackman's sendoff in Logan.

Review: Per its title the 2nd "Deadpool" sequel "Deadpool & Wolverine" unites the superhero characters of Ryan Reynolds (sassy) & Hugh Jackman (grouchy - and back from the 'dead') - to fight each other and baddies like Matthew Macfadyen, in a bloated sea of CGI (polished by director Shawn Levy) & star-cameos (Jon Favreau, Channing Tatum, Chris Evans, Henry Cavill, Jennifer Garner, Wesley Snipes, and more). With its fast talkin' filth (superbly written by Reynolds, Levy and three co-writers) and fourth-wall breakage (oft at Hollywood's expense) it maintains the 'Deadpool' rep of being Marvel's most irreverent, fun sub-franchise. Those into the 'MCU' rejoice.

Review: ...I wanted to deduct 'points' for the foul language but I found could not due to the fact that I had such a fun time watching this flick.... It was so obviously put together by people who love the lore of these characters and you could see that they had fantastic fun in the putting together of all the myriad segments of this,dare I say...Masterpiece...There!....i said it..and I think it was , of its ilk, certainly..... if you can judge a film on its enjoyment value then this is a Masterpiece... I had a smile on my face from the first moments to the last and I never lost it , not once. Ok , the cartoon violence was close to stomach turning , at times but that's 'Deadpool'... it's not for children,at all. The joke quotient was tremendous with oodles of laugh out loud moments,(..one gag near the end was one of the funniest tings I've ever seen/ heard...still chuckling about it now..Hee hee hee..). The cameo's were fabulous and seemingly endless , one in particular,(..a certain Mr T..),was especially chucklesome, if you know anything about behind the scenes shenanigans and films 'development hell' of past years. All the actors were great but obviously the 2 Mains were quite Stupendous ,bringing all their experience and gravitas to their signature Roles. Just fantastic ,adult,comic strip fun...Absolutely loved it...(..PS..Some viewers may not get all the gags and references and may deduct 'points' accordingly but being a Fanboy since the 60's I think I got most of them and almost certainly will' complete the set ' when I watch it again, as I surely will...).

Review: Sometimes, in rare cases, a good movie doesn't need to have deep or good story, as long as it delivered what it promised: a fun movie. And this film is exactly that, and boy it really was a fun ride from start to finish.Not saying the stoy is bad, it's not, but it wasn't the focus of this movie. This movie is a fanservice movie done right. If you're a fan of the characters and the Marvel IP, then by all means go dig in and have absolute fun. It was never intended for other audiences other than Marvel fans, because there's a lot of references and other things that would only be understood if you're a fan. And sometimes, having these kind of movie is okay if done right, and full of passion and heart. And this movie is exactly it.

Review: I loved every moment of this movie. The atmosphere in the cinema was electric. People were laughing out loud, groaning and yippeeing at all the appropriate moments. Hugh Jackman was absolutely amazing. He is no longer a young man, but wow, is he in shape!!! This movie had humour, pathos, comedy, and some of the most frenetic and intense fighting scenes I've ever seen. Lots of blood and gore, but I was riveted the whole time. Not one person left at the end of the movie. We all watched the extras at the end and they were great. Showed some of the history of the franchise. The jokes about Fox and Disney were spot on. I want to watch the three movies again in sequence.

Review: The film "Deadpool and Wolverine" can be described as a fantastic comedy satire taking place in the Marvel multiverseNevertheless, it cannot be denied that the movie is a rattling mix of banter, charisma and battle scenes that will not leave the audience indifferent. Deadpool, with his cheerful sarcasm and the destruction of the fourth wall, creates a unique contrast with the tough and laconic Wolverine, whose claws cut not only enemies, but also the "thread of matter time". Together, they turn the film into a bacchanal of humor and action, where every frame is filled with references and moments designed for omniscient millennial fans. The cartoon plot, intentionally exaggerated to the point of absurdity, allows the filmmakers to ridicule their own superhero seriousness.Each vivid scene and sparkling joke is a joy, but also a reminder of how far large corporations can go in exploiting our feelings and memories. The storyline is extremely sarcastic and is a satirical parody of the multiverse, which was parodied by Marvel managers with their bureaucratic myopia.The film also features multiple cameos and cameo appearances by other characters from the Marvel universe, many of whom have long been forgotten or pushed into the background. I was pleased with the appearance of "Blade", and yes, I don't see anyone except Wesley Snipes in this role!These "returns" delight and make you smile at the paradoxes of the multiverse, which is why the antihero calls himself a "Paradox".Constant intersections of time lines and ridicule of the complexity of the plot can confuse new viewers, but for devoted fans it will become a kind of intellectual game and an occasion for revisions and discussions, although I would not take the movie seriously at all, because the film has only one purpose - to entertain, and it succeeds, but not for me, well, that's my "different worldview"However, despite all its advantages and success with a large audience, the film cannot hide from the shadow of its own success. He plays on nostalgia and the cult status of his characters, but his deep dependence on recognizable cliches and fanservice opens the door to possible criticism, but this pop icon is absolutely not afraid: the film laughs at itself in every scene.Ultimately, "Deadpool and Wolverine" stay true to themselves, creating a fun and vibrant cinematic experience. This is a film for viewers who can laugh at their favorite characters, not forgetting that behind every comical moment there is a loving and appreciative audience. And although I perceive this picture with irony, like the characters Deadpool and Wolverine themselves, but I admit that such a decrease in the degree of seriousness only enhances its uniqueness. Enjoy watching and don't take the movie seriously.

Review: I really hate it when members of an audience make it obvious that they get all of the in-jokes in a film by forcing a knowing laugh at every available opportunity. I'm not that type of person - I sat stony faced throughout Deadpool & Wolverine, despite actually 'getting' some of the references: they simply weren't funny to me. And that's not a good thing when almost the entire film consists of fan-service and self-referential quips.It took me maybe ten minutes to realise that I had made a mistake in going to see this film: the opening gore-drenched fight scene was neither exciting nor funny. And the rest of the film followed suit, as Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) teams up with Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) to prevent corrupt Time Variance Authority employee Mr. Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen) from deleting his dimension and thus terminating all of his loved ones.Over two hours of mind-numbingly repetitive cartoonish violence and utterly inane humour (I laughed just once, at the ass-slapping during the costume scene), this latest travesty from Marvel is hopefully another nail in the superhero coffin.2.5/10, rounded down to 2 for the ugly dog, who got more screen-time than a lot of the big stars.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine are a buddy comedy match made in heaven. For his third outing, the court jester of Marvel brings his A-game to what is an explosive summer blockbuster. It has everything fans wanted and hoped for, and yet, I still wanted so much more. This is more of a satirical send-off to the 20th Century Fox, X-Men cinematic universe than it is gleeful middle-finger to Marvel studios. Every now and then, D&W targets Marvel in glorious fashion. But you'll notice how much was left off the table. But for all we know, they could be saving a lot of that for Deadpool 4, if and when we get one. What you do get doesn't disappoint. I love how these movies leave audiences roaring with laughter. I miss good studio comedies.

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine is literally what Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness should've been when it comes to cameos! This movie had tons of cameos and surprises! With this being Marvel Studios' first R-rated movie, they really used that rating to their advantage to show intense action scenes and deliver hilarious jokes; however, I believe some of the jokes are weak, but when the jokes are good it's really good. The issue I have with this movie though is the writing is a bit weak in areas such as the emotions and plot; it's still good don't get me wrong but there's definitely room for improvement. Overall, it's great and I recommend watching it.Rate: 8.8/10.

Review: I was expecting this movie to suck because of what Marvel has done with most of his new content since Endgame. But luckily I was wrong, this has been one of the best movies I've seen this year. This summer is such a win for superhero content. We got the new season of The Boys, we got Deadpool & Wolverine, and we are getting the last season of Umbrella Academy! This movie was a love letter to Fox's many movies about X-men and other superheros I don't want to spoil. The fighting scenes were so good they had a great coreography, they were bloody violent and gory I forgot this was Marvel! I could have gone with less Marvel Jesus jokes because they repeated them so many times and they were not funny but oh well. I also disliked the amount of sex jokes, way too many, someone needs to go to horny jail. This was yet another multiverse marvel movie that introduced new multiverse rules never before established. I was sad to see some actors missing that had previously been in Deadpool and Deadpool 2, would have been nice to see them. Oh and the whole Wolverine deal was not clear, like I get what happened, but how did it happen? Couldn't they show us, maybe using comics instead of actors so they did not have to pay them if that was the problem? Oh well, I got a poster for going so I'm not complaining, and I also bought 2 little Deadpool figurine. I went with my brother and his girlfriend and they were able to follow the movie despite not knowing some stuff because it was from shows they haven't seen. Overall would reccomend, 8/10.

Review: Well, new into the fandom, Deadpool really is one of my favourites.. went to watch this film with friends and a little let down, if i have to be completely honest.. The opening credits to this film is a visual rendezvous of everything amazing!! Be it the action choreography, camera angles, credits rolls or BG, i loved it every bit.The cross over of characters, universes, dimensions, in the most unexpected way, are moments of rejoice for the fans, with the iconic crackling humour of Deadpool and the cold humour of Logan hit the spot once again..What turned me a little sad was the story in itself. Somehow, it just felt that despite the good intentions of the plot points, somehow, it was a tired narration of a story where you're banking on the love for the character rather than his/her journey. Logan's arc did have a lot of intensity and so did Deadpool's but somehow, what joined the arcs didn't somehow workout for me..Even the fight choreography, kinda felt tired by the time it was the last one- considering action has always been iconic in Marvel movies.I really liked the use of bus windows in the last fight though..But overall, who literally cannot like Deadpool and Wolverine together? So hit the theatres!Ps- avoid 3d shows if ur city doesn't have a good 3d infrastructure. It will just ruin the experience altogether..

Review: I came out of the cinema confused. I loved the film for its nostalgia, it was funny, plenty of action and I enjoy how the deadpool films engage with the audience. I also enjoyed that a lot of the jokes connected with real life rather than just the MCU. I didn't expect a good plot so I wasn't disappointed when it wasn't. And as far as deadpools go, it's the best one.BUT... wolverine is over 200 years old, he has been through so much heartbreak, so much loss and we've been on that journey with him, from Gene dying (twice) to meeting X23 and everything inbetween. He has lost everyone close to him, turned to drink and wanted to die over and over. I felt this story was too lighthearted for his journey. (Even though it's a variant) They touched on it, they had the chance to deliver and I felt they missed it. Logan (2017) was a fitting end for him, I have no issue with them bringing him back but i just hope it doesn't turn into a path that changes who he is. We don't need another deadpool character.

Review: I viewed Deadpool and Wolverine at the cinema yesterday, on July 26, 2024. I have to admit, it was an exceptional movie experience that I thoroughly enjoyed. The dynamic between these two characters may not have seemed compatible, but when they finally came together at the end, it was truly remarkable. I hope that this movie surpasses the billion-dollar mark, as I believe fans and movie enthusiasts alike would truly appreciate and love it. It is indeed a genuine multiverse movie from Marvel.A love letter to the Fox marvel characters. I got emotional when they run the behind the scenes footage from all the previous X-Men and F4 etc movies .

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine deliver a thrilling experience that perfectly blends intense action with the irreverent humor fans of both characters crave. The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool and Hugh Jackman's Wolverine is nothing short of electric, with their witty banter and shared history making every scene a joy to watch.The action sequences are top notch, showcasing Wolverine's brutal strength and Deadpool's chaotic fighting style in a way that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The film balances these adrenaline-pumping moments with laugh out loud humor, ensuring that you're entertained from start to finish.For fans of the characters, this pairing is a dream come true. The movie does justice to both heroes, respecting their individual legacies while creating something fresh and exciting.However, the movies plot feels a bit thin at times and the humour can try too hard leading to jokes that don't always land.

Review: Every non-Disney Marvel movie was honored in a sendoff that had heart and a butt-load of laughs. As a lifelong Wolverine, X-Men, and Deadpool comics fan, I couldn't have asked for a better movie. A masterpiece of action, comedy, and love for fans.Without spoilers, this was a magnificent way to showcase the best and ridicule the worst of Fox's contributions to Marvel. I assure you if you're a movie fan <30 years old, you'll enjoy the cameos throughout. This is especially true as you're experiencing it with Deadpool through the 4th wall.My only criticism is the homework. If you're like me and stopped after "Endgame", then you might want to look up the events of the show "Loki" (but probably not essential to enjoy the premise).An outstanding movie, that parents should leave the kids home for - or take them and toughen them up a bit. Either way, it's a blast.
