Review: Keep it brief review:"Deadpool & Wolverine" is the 34th film in the MCU and the first Disney Deadpool film. Deadpool & Wolverine is the 3rd film in the Deadpool trilogy this time featuring the team up and highly anticipated return of Hugh Jackman as Wolverine.It's no secret that the MCU has been suffering from fatigue and creativity lately. The hype around this film was that it was going to be the MCU saviour and a step back in the right direction. The film even jokes about this constantly. With expectations at an all time high can Deadpool pull of this endeavour?The short answer is yes...yes it sure can. Deadpool & Wolverine is pure and simply a summer superhero blockbuster. It knows what it is and just thrives on being a fun film. From the opening scene Deadpool sets the tone and lets the audiences know what they are in store for. Deadpool is consistently funny, has some amazingly done action set pieces, and perhaps better yet throws surprise after surprise at the audience. I went into this film blind as I've just kind of been done with the MCU lately...and let me tell you this is the best way to see the film. Avoid spoilers at all cost.Overall this is a true summer film. One that is meant to be enjoyed in theatres. The plot is serviceable although not groundbreaking or setting the path for future Marvel movies. It knows what audiences are looking for and what they have been asking for and it gives it to them...hard. This is definitely a step in the right direction and I hope Disney/Marvel can continue this momentum going forward.Positives: + The chemistry Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman have serve this film very well.+ consistently funny+ some very well done action set pieces+ love him or hate him Ryan Reynolds was born to play Deadpool and 3 films in continues to give a top notch performance.+ Tons of surprises throughout the filmNegatives:Rating: 4 out of 5.

Review: **Deadpool and Wolverine** is a must-watch for fans of both characters and superhero movies in general. It successfully merges the best elements of its titular heroes, creating a film that is as emotionally resonant as it is entertaining. With its perfect blend of humor, action, and heart, this movie is sure to leave audiences eagerly anticipating whether there will be another movie for this dynamic duo.The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman is undeniable, bringing a unique energy to the screen that perfectly captures the essence of their characters. The witty banter and relentless action sequences are balanced with deeper, more poignant moments, offering a well-rounded cinematic experience. The film's innovative storytelling, combined with top-notch special effects and a killer soundtrack, makes it a standout in the superhero genre.Overall, the movie not only meets but exceeds expectations, and I can simply say that Marvel Studios is saved by Deadpool and Wolverine.

Review: Finally, after many years of waiting and speculating, we have an answer to the big question. How will Deadpool fit into the MCU? I imagine most of the readers already know, a lot has happened between now and the previous films Logan (2017) and Deadpool 2 (released 2018). To sum up: The film Logan ended the Hugh Jackman's Wolverine story, Endgame wrapped up the Infinity Saga, Disney bought out Fox, and the MCU continued into the next Phases (4&5). In middle is Deadpool. What to do, what to do. Well, the wait is over, and we have our answer to the Deadpool question. The answer is spectacular.Deadpool (played by no other than Ryan Reynolds) has retired the "superhero" life. While enjoying a birthday party, he is kidnapped by the organization TVA (Time Variance Authority, seen previously on the Loki series). During his escape from the TVA, he gains the help from a most reluctant ally, no other than the Wolverine (played amazingly by Hugh Jackman). Together, they must put a stop to the TVA's plans of destroying Deadpool's current timeline and go head-to-head with another menacing villain known as Cassandra Nova (played by Emma Corrin). They will brutally fight villains, as well as violently fight between themselves.While past Marvel movies, in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, are rated PG-13. Make no mistake, this film is a hard rated R film. I can speak on behalf of the fans by saying, thank you for making this film rated R. Between both Deadpool and Wolverine, they will swear constantly, and spill all the blood of their enemies. With a few powerful moments of Hugh Jackman's serious moments are Ryan Reynolds classic nonstop graphic comedy. For a two runtime, the jokes and violence doesn't necessarily get old. Over the top, maybe, but I can tell the audience never got bored with this film. The main villain, Cassandra Nova, might be another forgettable MCU villain; however Emma Corrin performance shines with the rest of the cast. Especially with the inclusion of so many cameos, and each one of them was a welcome surprise. Whether the cameo was a familiar face or even one's the audience has forgotten about.Unlike the previous Deadpool films, the story itself for this movie felt chaotic at times. Understandably, Deadpool was always a chaotic force of nature and thrives in it. However, keeping up with all the humor and characters can feel like the story is taking on too much. In my opinion, dealing with the subject of the multiverse always presents this problem. However, having Ryan and Hugh's character performances anchor the film and helps steer the film in the right and epic conclusion. If any other character in the MCU lead this film, the chaos wouldn't have worked as well. For a Deadpool movie, this works perfectly within the chaos.Overall, fans of the Deadpool and Wolverine franchise will love this film. Anyone looking for a superhero comedy/action adventure will also enjoy this film. As I said before, the two-hour runtime was just right, even with all the constant graphic humor and violence.

Review: I know it's always unfair for movies that set the bar so high in terms of expectations, there's always a high risk of those same expectations not being met and I guess that's all right... I have to admit I was hyped for it, I enjoyed it but I thought it could've been greater...Let me start with what I really enjoyed about the movie, as always it doesn't take itself too serious as it shouldn't, Deadpool was always a comedic approach to the super hero genre filled with meta commentary and jokes targeting real life situations, the peak of 4th wall breaking, I feel this continues to be the strength of the film and they manage to keep the jokes funny and most importantly fresh!The fact that both these actors, Ryan and Hugh, seemingly have been born to play these roles makes it also a really pleasant experience, they do it perfectly and their chemistry, most likely also due to their real life friendship, shines on the big screen.I also really enjoyed the cameos and the references, regardless of some people calling it fan service, I don't see why that's a bad thing, I feel that if you are going to be ridiculous about the Multiverse there's no better movie than a Deadpool movie to do that.It had some really funny scenes, good action sequences and fights and the soundtrack was really something else.And one thing I was surprised was, regardless if you find the plot interesting or not, they actually nailed the way they set the story, how they managed to bring Wolverine back, adding the TVA into the mix to explain some of the plot decisions, I felt that for a movie that doesn't take itself serious it was a really solid explanation of context.With all of this being said, I did have a few issues with it and the reason why I won't rate it higher;All in all it's an entertaining and good movie, its greatness is simply achieved by the two main actors that bring the characters to life.

Review: I've been really disappointed with Marvel movies ever since Endgame, but damn, this really gave the MCU a huge W. I really appreciate that this was obviously made by fans for fans. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman really made sure to give us all the things we've been begging for for years, if not decades. They took the mess they were given by the current state of the MCU and made it work in a way that makes sense and is just the right amount of silly. It's genuinely such a breath of fresh air to see this duo sort of unshackled from Disney's (and Fox's) censorship, with the exception of not being able to do cocaine, lmao. Yes, Deadpool has been rated R in the past. Plenty of violence, language, etc. But this felt different. This was them frolicking through a field of rated R goodness, being gratuitous but in the best way. It's honestly pretty great, and it worked perfectly for this film. It stayed true to the core of what Deadpool is, and is a step up from the sequel. Loved the cameos, the writing, the palpable homoerotic tension between the titular pair. You could argue that there was a bit of an overuse of music throughout, but it was mostly done well enough for it to not bother me. I definitely recommend this for Marvel fans and those without delicate sensibilities.

Review: The dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine is one of the most intriguing and entertaining in the Marvel universe. Their contrasting personalities create a unique blend of humor and intensity that resonates with fans. Wolverine's disciplined and stoic nature often serves as a grounding force against Deadpool's wild and unpredictable antics. This not only leads to comedic situations but also highlights moments of genuine friendship and mutual respect.Their interactions are a testament to Marvel's ability to craft complex character relationships that transcend simple hero-villain dynamics. Whether they're teaming up to face a common enemy or clashing due to their vastly different approaches, Deadpool and Wolverine's relationship adds a rich layer of storytelling that continues to captivate audiences.Moreover, their shared history as products of the Weapon X program adds an extra layer of depth to their relationship. Both characters have endured immense suffering and loss, which occasionally brings out a more vulnerable side in each of them. This shared trauma sometimes creates moments of unexpected solidarity and understanding.The banter between Wolverine and Deadpool often provides comic relief amid the more serious and dark storylines, making their scenes together memorable. Fans appreciate the unpredictability of their interactions, never quite knowing whether they will end in a fight, a begrudging team-up, or a surprisingly heartfelt conversation. This dynamic continually evolves, ensuring that their stories remain fresh and engaging.Moreover, their shared history as products of the Weapon X program adds an extra layer of depth to their relationship. Review: While this film pokes a lot of fun at the MCU, Fox, and the hero genre in general, it is abundantly clear that the writers (including Ryan) have such a love and respect for this universe of superheroes. There are so many references, easter eggs, nods, and cameos that will surely require multiple viewings. I would be doing a disservice to spoil anything, much of the films enjoyment on first watch will surely be jumping out of your seat at what is arguably the greatest cast of cameo appearances to ever be put on film. The fanfare here is worth the price of admission alone. The humor is spot on and pulls no punches, the action is brutal! This is a Deadpool movie, so seeing characters from PG-13 hero films performing brutal and at times gory action is incredibly satisfying. There is a lot to love here. The film almost never misses, apart from a couple of lines that cater towards gen z lingo that didn't land perfectly. The film also feels a little small at times, not quite as large scale and epic as an Infinity War or Endgame, but is of the same caliber and feels right at home. Ultimately, there is nothing to critique here. The movie doesn't waste your time nor does the pacing feel rushed. This is a must watch for any fan of the genre, and is pure insanity and enjoyment from start to finish. They absolutely stick the landing on this one too, I refuse to let myself cry in a movie theater but I definitely felt myself tearing up at the end. The Deadpool franchise is a blessing to the MCU and I sincerely hope this isn't the end for Deadpool and Wolverine.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a refreshing breath of irreverence and grit in the Marvel universe, a film that might just be one of the best things Disney and Marvel have produced in years. From the get-go, the movie captures the chaotic energy that fans of both characters crave. Deadpool's trademark humor is as sharp as ever, cutting through the action with a relentless barrage of fourth-wall-breaking quips and meta-commentary that feels both fresh and familiar. Meanwhile, Wolverine brings the grizzled intensity that perfectly balances Deadpool's manic antics.The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman is undeniable, driving the movie with a dynamic that feels like a violent buddy comedy-if the buddies had a tendency to eviscerate their enemies in creatively gory ways. The plot, while not groundbreaking, serves as a solid backbone for the characters to do what they do best: unleash carnage, bicker, and begrudgingly save the day.Visually, the film is stunning, with action sequences that are as brutal as they are stylish. The direction embraces the R-rated potential, ensuring that neither character is diluted for a younger audience. This is a film made for fans, and it knows exactly what they want.Where "Deadpool & Wolverine" really shines is in its willingness to take risks. It pushes boundaries-not just with its humor and violence, but with its narrative choices that cleverly subvert typical superhero tropes. However, it's not without its flaws. The pacing occasionally stumbles, and a few jokes feel more forced than fluid. But these are minor quibbles in an otherwise exhilarating experience.In the end, "Deadpool & Wolverine" delivers a bloody, hilarious, and surprisingly heartfelt romp that proves that sometimes, all you need is a foul-mouthed antihero and a cigar-chomping mutant to breathe new life into the superhero genre. It's not perfect, but it's damn close-a triumphant return to form for Marvel's edgier side.

Review: Probably the worst one ever created. Jokes are not as good as they were before and the story not really making it.One of the most disappointing aspects of "Deadpool 3" is its reliance on tired tropes and recycled jokes. The film often feels like it's trying too hard to recapture the magic of the first two installments. While self-referential humor has always been a cornerstone of Deadpool's appeal, here it falls flat, feeling forced and repetitive. The once-refreshing quips feel like they've been run through a blender of clichés, and the novelty of Deadpool breaking the fourth wall has become stale. Instead of clever commentary, we're treated to a barrage of eye-roll-inducing one-liners that seem to be there just for the sake of being there.

I wouldn't change anything I saw the costumes, the characters involved, the sometimes over done comical elements. Watch it and enjoy it I did and from the sounds all over the imax screening I attended I was in a screen space full of people who thought the same haven't heard people interacting with a film like this for years.I don't want to give any spoilers away hope this has been somewhat helpful.

Review: This is Deadpool from the marvel comics.Have you not read them, you probably won't recognize the themes.Deadpool is about the most skilled and miserable, technically immortal mercenary with a mouth, searching for his place in the world of mutants and superheroes.Deadpool is a psychopath and quite unlikeable most of the time, but as Colossus says: "Four or five moments - that's all it takes to become a hero." This is the essence of Deadpool in the comics, where 98% of the time he seems to just be fooling around, but in the end his good side shines through and he actually uses his skills for good.This huge contrast between fooling around, owning up to his responsibility and being a hero can create some surprisingly wholesome moments in the comics.Deadpool and Wolverine is the best take on the Deadpool comics and Hugh is playing Wolverine the exact way we see him in the Deadpool comics. He is always the guy to shut down Deadpool's BS with a good load of dismembering.It is possible Ryan have read Deadpool or his vision is just so spot on that because of his likeness to the character.Either way this movie probably isn't for you if you've never read anything similar to Deadpool or if you don't like over the top action movies with spectacle, dirty humor and a lot of gore.If you are looking for a movie with deep intellectual storylines with a lot of emotion, intricate mystery and social commentary, then save your money and time.

Review: This movie was an eagerly anticipated showdown that promised an exhilarating clash between two of Marvel's most beloved anti-heroes. Unfortunately, it fails to live up to the hype, leaving fans with more frustration than satisfaction.First and foremost, the plot is a convoluted mess. Rather than delivering a coherent narrative, the film is a jumble of disconnected scenes and over-the-top antics that lack any real substance. The story feels like an afterthought, merely an excuse to bring these two characters together without any meaningful development or stakes.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, while charismatic as always, seem to struggle with the material they are given. Their performances come off as forced, as if they themselves are not convinced by the direction of the film. The banter between Deadpool and Wolverine, which should have been a highlight, often falls flat and feels repetitive.The action sequences, typically a saving grace in such films, are surprisingly underwhelming. Despite the potential for epic battles, the choreography is lackluster and the special effects feel subpar compared to other recent Marvel entries. Instead of jaw-dropping fights, we get a series of poorly executed set pieces that fail to impress.Moreover, the film tries too hard to blend Deadpool's irreverent humor with Wolverine's brooding nature, resulting in an awkward tonal imbalance. The humor feels forced and out of place, while the darker, more serious moments lack the emotional depth needed to resonate with the audience.In conclusion, this movie is a missed opportunity. It squanders the potential of its iconic characters with a disjointed plot, mediocre action, and a tone that fails to strike the right balance. Fans of both Deadpool and Wolverine will likely walk away disappointed, wishing for a more worthy confrontation between these two legendary figures.

Review: The good: This movie has one of the best intro (credit) sequences I have ever seen. It is funny, irreverent, meta, entertaining and subversive all at the same time. It is flawless - sadly the movie never reaches those heights again. But this movie more or less delivers on what you expect - Deadpool + Wolverine + gore + comedy + 4th wall breaking. A bonus, is that somehow, Hugh Jackson has still got it. And he carries most of the emotional weight of the film. The movie is well paced, with action scattered through out. And finally, the cameos - whilst some do miss the mark - most are good, some are brilliant. Subversive, honorary and/or just simple hilarious fan-service. Overall they add to the movie rather than subtract from it.The bad: The big bad is probably the worst part of this movie. She's so infuriatingly 2-dimensional, with a "destroy world because people mean" kindergarten drive. There's also too many plot conveniences to get the main characters to their next destination that it's grating. I'm wildly confused as to why the writers couldn't just come up with a logical reason to move characters from scene to scene.Summary: Overall the movie earns it's spot amongst the MCU echelon. Probably coming at a time when marvel needs it most. It's definitely a top 1/3 superhero flick and is worth the watch. The marvel messiah it is not, however.

Review: "Deadpool vs. Wolverine" delivers exactly what fans have been craving-a chaotic, hilarious, and action-packed showdown between two of Marvel's most iconic characters. The film balances sharp wit with intense fight scenes, showcasing the unique dynamics and chemistry between Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman. The plot is as unpredictable as the Merc with a Mouth himself, filled with surprising cameos and meta-commentary that keeps you on your toes. If you're looking for a wild ride through the Marvel universe with plenty of laughs and jaw-dropping moments, this is it. Don't miss out on this experience in theater.

Review: As a lifelong comic book fan, especially Wolverine this was the movie I've waited my entire life for. Not only was homage paid to characters and their comic history but the making of a duo that was always meant to be. This was a raucous, comedic, action pack movie of heart, substance and full of surprises bringing honor to several past Marvel characters and giving them fitting hero tributes.The action is incredibly well timed, and the comedy is gold and the storyline does not disappoint. This movie not only fulfilled childhood dreams for this nearing 50 year old gal but what comic book movies should be.

Review: I like this movie. I like it a lot. Probably need to watch it again to discover stuff I didn't noticed before. The movie gave me a lot of good laughs with enough semi dramatic scenes to prevent an overkill of jokes. The type of jokes is what you can expect from Dead Pool, but for the MCU and also Disney it is a novelty. The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman was as expected great. Lot of inside jokes (they prank eachother loads of time in rl), but also lots and lots and lots of franchise jokes. And that is what I think is an reoccuring MCU issue: you are expected to have seen about every previous MCU movie, other Marvel movie and tv show and read all the comic. Sure I exaggerate a bit now, but lot of cameo's date even before MCU, but also were referring to comics. Some of the storyline can be confusing for people who missed the Loki series (like my wife). But ok, it was fun to laugh at some jokes most of the younger people in the audience wouldnt get (I am getting old), and even though my wife hates complicated stuff like multiverses or references to other movies she had a great time (and she hates MCU movies). So dont bother to dive too deep into the storyline, it will spoil all your fun. I have read some more negative reviews and they all took the movie too serious. Dont do that. Just sit back, relax and most important have a lot of fun.

Review: With the third installment of Deadpool, Marvel is back on top again by introducing the X-Men into the MCU as The Marvels had anticipated and has maintained all the mature tone and dark humor of the previous films. Deadpool had already predicted in the PG-13 version of the second film that Disney would buy Fox and that generated certain concerns once it came true. In the end, Disney introduced Deadpool into the MCU in a worthy way adding to the X-Men franchise. With his characteristic humor and charisma, Deadpool keeps the essence of his previous films intact. He continues with his references to popular culture, breaking the fourth wall and also jokes towards gen Z. The film offers its clever gags combined with a good mix of action and comedy. The soundtrack has very good songs, including an epic version of Madonna's Like A Prayer. The X-Men were already being considered for the MCU, and the best way to start it was with Wolverine. To be honest, Wolverine has become almost the face of the X-Men saga since the first film. Hugh Jackman was brought back as an alternate version of the original Wolverine, but he retains his tough personality. The film also brings back some characters that have been seen in the X-Men saga. In addition, not only does the MCU manage to link this saga as part of the multiverse, there is also a possibility that the X-Men animated series from the 90s could also be part of this multiverse. That's because Wolverine wears the classic costume from the animated series and Gambit also appears in the same outfit he had in the series. All of that is just part of the best of this movie because the rest officially confirms what was suspected to happen after the last Spider-Man movies and the Doctor Strange sequel. The movie also features the appearance and mention of some characters from the Marvel movies that were made before the MCU started. This movie officially confirms that all the Marvel movies that were made over time are part of a multiverse. They knew how to take advantage of the theme of alternate realities very well to connect the movies and series as it happened with DC Comics in The Flash movie. That even helped a lot so that some Marvel movies that passed without pain or glory got a second chance. Deadpool & Wolverine is indisputably a great movie that revives the fascination with the multiverse and also the appreciation for Marvel's filmography even if it is out of a feeling of nostalgia. My final rating for this movie is 10/10.

Review: The current reigning champ at the box office comes right at a time where some MCU fans have given up on the Marvel saga which follows Ryan Reynolds mouth in a mask partnering w/an anchor character (expect to hear about more of that phenomena since Robert Downey Jr. Is our Doc Doom), Hugh Jackman's clawed lone wolf to right the wrongs before their timeline gets flushed down the astral toilet. Their surprising nemesis is not Professor X's sister Cassandra Nova, Emma Corrin (she played Princess Di on Netflix's The Crown), but the unctuous Paradox, Succession's Matthew Macfayden, who hopes our heroes will follow the diseased timeline & go away. Fun all the way w/a layer of cheapness (the sets look found & lived in, maybe lying around since the Loki finale?) w/the emphasis on the humor ginned up between these 2 contrarians who are the best of friends in real life. Hopefully the brass at the Mouse House will learn from this film's lessons & go forward on the good foot not complicating the simple but who am I kidding?

Review: Deadpool : Known for his irreverent humor, fourth-wall-breaking antics, and chaotic unpredictability. Deadpool's constant wisecracks and meta-commentary provide endless entertainment.Wolverine (Logan): The gruff, no-nonsense mutant with a brooding demeanor and a strong sense of justice. His serious and often stoic personality contrasts sharply with Deadpool's zaniness.Humor and Action Blend: The combination of Deadpool's humor with Wolverine's intense action sequences would create a unique blend of comedy and high-octane action. Deadpool's comedic approach to fighting and Wolverine's brutal efficiency would complement each other, leading to innovative and entertaining fight scenes.

Review: My most anticipated movie in quite some time has been released. Does it live up to the nearly infinite amount of hype? Well just keep reading to find out. DEADPOOL & WOLVERINE is a movie with SO many surprises and spoilers in it, it would be very tough to go into this blind. Don't worry, I won't spoil a single damn thing for all you fine people reading this. As a die-hard Marvel fan, this review will probably seem biased, but that's just a part of who I am. Even though I haven't read a single Marvel comic book, I have ingested everything they have released since 2008's IRON MAN, even some from before that. This is a buddy movie between two actual buddies, Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman as Wolverine. Both were born to play these roles. This is Hugh's 10th time as Wolverine, and he hasn't lost a single ab- I mean step. Ryan is literally the "Merc with the Mouth", he's just getting paid to be himself at this point. I'm not going to say anything about the plot, other than the fact that it's the weakest link of this movie. Saying that, I loved literally everything else. It has extremely profane language, has extremely satisfying violent action scenes, and is fantastically funny. There are an absolute litany of cameos that I can't even mention here, all so good. Emma Corrin plays a great villain, whose name I can't even say. This is what Marvel fans have been asking for for a very long time now. It's fan-service up the ass, pardon my Deadpool-ness. There are a lot of "in jokes" about companies like Disney and Fox, and for comic book nerds. To understand all the jokes, I recommend watching DEADPOOL 2, LOGAN, and season one of LOKI. I gotta stop myself here before Kevin Feige starts hunting me down. Will DEADPOOL & WOLVERINE save the MCU? Only time will tell. Is DEADPOOL & WOLVERINE a must-see for any fan who has waned a bit because of the 5-year quality dip from Marvel? Let's f***ing go! Stay till the credits stop rolling.

Review: Another one of my most anticipated films of the year and it delivered. Got what I was expecting and I am satisfied. Deadpool & Wolverine directed by Shawn Levy starring Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman ofcourse, is a really entertaining and fun deadpool and wolverine film with lot's of camoes and multiverse stuff. The multiverse , the variants , the cameos etc.. were honestly becoming lame which kind of led to Marvel's downfall but in this one , the multiversal stuff made it even more enjoyable, there is no plot but it's just pure chaos and fun. It continues that Deadpool 2 vibe but with even better humour, most of the jokes were great , all of these meta references and Wolverine being Wolverine. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are simply irreplaceable as Deadpool and Wolverine respectively. Their chemistry was the main highlight of the film. Marvel is kind of back with this one and Deadpool is really the Marvel Jesus. Great soundtrack , great opening , the meta jokes , the cameos , Deadpool & Wolverine's chemistry , the fight sequences and Hugh Jackman returning as the Wolverine made this film a really fun and enjoyable ride from start to finish.

Review: You must admit that, in terms of entertainment, the sequel managed to surpass itself, offering a more fun experience full of exciting moments.However, when it comes to epicness and greatness, the third installment remains firmly in first place. This film is a true masterpiece, a true cinematic joy that has managed to capture the essence of what it means to be epic in every scene.The numerous cameos are a delight for fans, each carefully thought out and masterfully executed, giving the story an additional dimension that enriches the plot and makes it even more memorable. The appearance of these characters is not only exciting, but also adds a level of depth that few films manage to achieve.Furthermore, the film's central message is especially powerful and resonant. Through the story, we are shown a hero who, despite his carefree attitude and tendency to take things with humor, truly wants to be recognized and valued as a true superhero.

Review: Action-packed, heartfelt, and a thrill ride all in one movie! Movie starts out in perfect comedic fashion with Deadpool trying to find Wolverine while he smack talks about how he is overrated. This movie even managed to turn me into more of a Deadpool fan. The special effect fighting scenes are the best I've seen in years of movie releases.They managed to include the right amount of gore while keeping the fighting comical but badass. The villain story did not have much unique appeal but the way they retold the backstories of Deadpool and Wolverine to emphasize their past trauma is what brought the two rivaling faction heroes together.The pace of the movie was perfect, no scene felt out of place, and the environment settings were wicked. Some scenes took place in a desert type mad max environment or as relative to the common civilian areas of Deadpool's apartment, city downtown, and traversing through the woods trying to find the enemy base.If you are either a Wolverine fan or Deadpool fan you will enjoy this movie! They captured the personalities of both characters without being too over the top. Deadpool's comical but heartfelt personality is the strongest a Marvel heroes wholesome personality has been since the original Peter Parker Spider-Man in my honest opinion. Marvel even included a scene honoring Iron Man brilliantly showing how Deadpool knows of the Avenger's top tier existence while envying the fact that he isn't included but also while relishing in the moment how Deadpool is not objectively contracted to be told what to do. Saying something along the lines of "an Avenger or time travel mission boy?"... you can't tell Deadpool what to do! Do you know who I am?! I'm Deadpool baby, I'll break your nose and roundhouse kick you in the nuts before you tell me what to do and handle the mission myself even without the overdosed testosterone furry man behind my ass.The film makes you feel like you are in the movie experience with the unfiltered one liner humor of Deadpool making fun of every possible person he comes into contact with. If you don't laugh more than 3 times during this movie I'm going to boldly say you must not have a great sense of humor because the insults in this film are top notch. Movie music soundtrack also does not disappoint... I'm not going to spoil it but let's just say there is a troll song that Deadpool fights too like something Starlord would put on and a classic rock song in a fight scene that the likes of Ironman would use. Both music fight scenes were relevant music and captured the fighting essence of movies like Avengers, Star Wars, and Transformers special effects. Fighting was not too zoomed in and not too flashy.My only 2 critique's with the movie was number one I was not a big fan of Juggernaut. I think he looked too human like and the fact that once they made it to the villain base there was NOT a lot of story or fighting in the main villain's area.Character role casting and dialogue were outstanding but the villain story interaction was on more of the short lived side to the point where the main corporate anti-time travel crony guy was more story focused. This didn't make a whole lot of sense since the villain was supposed to highlight the aftermath results of Professor X dying. Story spent a little too much time on the inner battles of the multiverse time travel.Movie was excellent overall however, a great film, excellent characters not just including Wolverine & Deadpool, and the best part is the that the fact that it was action badass but totally wholesome all at the same time. I would buy this movie in a heartbeat once it becomes available on dvd or digital store marketplace. I give the film an overall score of 83.5. This has been the best film since Deadpool 1 beating out both Deadpool 2 & Logan in my honest opinion.In a ranking table I would probably rank it like: Avengers 1- 93 Ironman 1- 91 Deadpool 1- 85.5 Deadpool & Wolverine- 83.5 The Wolverine- 82 Logan- 81 Deadpool 2- 80.

Review: I enjoyed X-Men comics as a child, but let's face it all the hero's were complete dorks...with a slight exception of Wolverine and Gambit. To this day I don't understand why Gambit has never made an appearance, he was by far the coolest X-Men. So, I was excited to see him even though how limited his screen time was.Deadpool franchise really brought the Marvel universe for the adults who enjoyed Christian friendly Marvel comics as children, to the big screen, unlike Spider Man.The third installment to the Deadpool franchise, did not disappoint. It's not my favorite, but the originality of this film really made it a fun to watch without a single dull moment.I think this film is very child friendly despite the over the top comedic violence and vulgar language. This film is a morality play, about forgiveness, dealing with differences, and finding common good among characters who seem irredeemable.Enjoy!

Review: I was so looking forward to watching this. I cant believe how anyone can say it was good! Absolutely no plot. One fight scene after another, so it got extremely boring and beyond silly. Some of the dialogue was hard to follow and rubbish anyway. Hardly any was funny enough to make me giggle never mind laugh like in the first two films. Deadpool always remained likeable even though you knew you shouldn't like him. In this film however, he was too far removed from reality to make you even care a jot about him, never mind like him. Having a toothless, tongue out, mega old chinese crested dog myself i did appreciate the dog. Even the great little dog though wouldn't tempt me to ever watch this film again. What as waste of money. With all this talent it's a shame they didn't get good writers on board too.

Review: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulWade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) has put his alter-ego Deadpool behind him, and has now settled into a quiet life working at a home convenience superstore, along with the rest of his 'X Force' crew. However, one night, at a raucous house party, he finds himself rounded up by soldiers working on behalf of the zany Mr. Paradox (Matthew MacFadyan), who wants to create a time shift that will wipe out Wade's universe. His only hope is to locate his old adversary, Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) whose universe suffered the same fate, and form an unstoppable fighting team.In the world of the Marvel Comics Universe, and DC Comics, which have an unstoppable grip on the box office which shows no sign of abatement, it's easy to get burnt out with the lack of distinction between them all, a mass churning out of the same thing, as long as it all pleases the fanboys. And so, Deadpool is an all the more refreshing character, an anti-hero who doesn't play by the rules, and with all the character flaws not present in traditional action heroes. And Wolverine, of the X-Men, serves as a perfect foil, and they now have a long awaited collaboration that should please those who've been waiting for it.What could have been a self indulgent, self congratulating borefest is instead quite evenly balanced, and successfully pulls off what it wants to do very well. Reynolds occupies the first half, with Deadpool's story told in reverse, and delivers the goods, with Deadpool as his wise-cracking, pop culture referencing best. Wolverine doesn't enter the proceedings until about two thirds of the way in, but when he does, they form a snappy dynamic, with Jackman injecting his grunting, volatile take on Wolverine. Support wise, MacFadyan hams it up as the mysterious villain, while there are surprise cameos from Jennifer Garner (Elektra), Wesley Snipes (Blade) and Chris Evans (Captain America), in their respective superhero roles, as well as appearances from Channing Tatum, Henry Cavill and Wunmi Mosaku.In what appears to be a farewell to the characters, director Shawn Levy has crafted a loud, fun, riotous romp that pays a more than respectful homage to its two central characters, and leaves fans, either casual or obsessive. ****

Review: I 100% agree with Hugh Jackman when he said he never quite got to scratch the depths of Wolverine in his previous movies. Deadpool & Wolverine ticks off every missed opportunity in terms of storylines, quips, costumes and things fans from the comics always hoped they'd get to see. They packed in everything and more into a film that, by modern superhero film standards, wasn't excessively long either. I'll forever be grateful for these three men (& Feige) for finally delivering a well-rounded Wolverine to the audience. D&W is a film where, the more knowledge a viewer has about the actors, studios, characters and comics involved, the more they'll enjoy it. Deadpool & Wolverine's jokes and references operate on so many levels, it's a film viewers can appreciate more with every viewing. People who say this film wasn't as funny as they'd hoped it would be, or question why Channing Tatum was cast as Gambit, have completely let the last 20 years of superhero movies and general pop culture news whiz by them. Savvy nerds and geeks will feast upon these easter eggs. That's not say D&W can't be throughly enjoyed without knowing all the meta jokes. It's similar to how adults appreciated jokes in Shrek that the younger audience didn't get. On a personal note, it was thrilling to see Jackman back as my favourite character from the Marvel comics and movies. He and Reynolds are a magic combination and each gives something extra to their performance when onscreen together. You can replace Bond, Superman, Spiderman and Batman, but for me, there can be only one Wolverine. Let's hope Disney really do make him do this til he's 90!

Review: The length of the film was quite challenging for me. I had to take four breaks just to get through it, and unfortunately, I only truly enjoyed the last quarter. Despite the strong performances by Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, the overall story did not resonate with me as much as other films like Logan and DP2.The inclusion of Laura x23 felt rushed and lacked depth, while Channing Tatum's cameo seemed out of place and unconvincing. It's clear that this movie was made for fans, but the lack of development in both the story and characters left me feeling underwhelmed. I don't mean to be overly critical, but this film just didn't meet my expectations.

Review: I was hesitant about watching this - maybe because Deadpool 2 ended in a not-so-happy way - but I am thrilled to say that this was the best Marvel film I've watched in years. Reynolds and Jackman understand their characters well, and the back and forth banter, the push and pull of their yin and yang personas, make them the perfect "odd couple" duo. They're both dealing with similar loses (won't go into details because that would be a spoiler) but the circumstances allow them to understand that they're both trying to rewrite history. The aspect of the TVA is quite literally how they plan to do that, with Logan more-or-less agreeing because of a half truth. The fight sequences, the cameos, the locations, the dialogue, literally everything was perfect. And my favorite quality, the sarcastic, inappropriate wit of Deadpool complimented Logan's dry, mature perspective, making their quest epic.

Review: It's one of my top superhero movies honestly. I thought Hugh and Ryan had great chemistry on screen and all the cameos were cool and well thought out, unlike multiverse of madness. It was the perfect multiverse movie without getting ridiculous and it was hilariously brilliant. The fight choreography was sick also.The comedy within the movie was the perfect amount of humor with jokes that actually landed. The action and fight choreography was very fun to watch. I thought they finally did Wolverine comic accurate and I'm convinced nobody can out do Hugh Jackman as Wolverine. Ryan Reynolds just exudes Deadpool so that was amazing as well. The dancing throughout the movie was one of my favorite parts.

Review: I was really optimistic, despite Marvel's lack of consistent movie making lately, that they would continue the good work done by Fox to make another good Deadpool film. And they definitely delivered. The comedy was very entertaining, and the action was impressive and classic of Deadpool. He still was the merc with a mouth we love! There was a lot of 4th wall breaking which I loved, and there were many amazing cameos. The plot was not the greatest I've ever seen, but it was more than enough to move the movie forward and explain the multi-verse changes and leaving the plot of Logan alone and bringing back Hugh Jackman as the one, only Wolverine. The ending was very satisfying as well. I would highly recommend watching this movie in the theater!!

Review: I've never felt the urge to write a movie review before, but here I am, iPad in hand, ready to tap out words of praise. Why? Because if you're a Marvel fan, you'll watch the movie anyway. But if you're like me - a bit meh about their universe - you might skip it. And that would be a mistake.I want you to be as astounded as I was by a film I had zero expectations for. The only other movie to both baffle and exceed my expectations like this was Life is Beautiful. Yeah, I know, it's an odd comparison, but it's true. So deal with it.Deadpool and Wolverine managed to make me laugh and cry simultaneously. How? Go watch it and see for yourself.Simply magical.

Review: I watched this film feeling like I was in the 2000s. I'm a 30-year-old adult who grew up watching the golden age of heroes, with incredible fun films like Spider-Man (2002 and 2004), Fantastic Four (2005), The Punisher (2004 ), between others... Deadpool & Wolverine is practically a celebration of this incredible, experimental, fun and unforgettable time. I feel grateful for being born in the 90s and having the opportunity to watch those films in the 2000s. This third film in the Deadpool saga is simply the BEST of the trilogy, and perhaps it won't have the same effect on the younger generation.It's so worth it! Fun from start to finish with lots of Easter eggs, unbelievable cameos and a damn good ending!

Review: I truly adored the second edtion (which was absolutely brilliant) and therefore I had high hopes for this 3rd sequel...The bad: There is definitely a lack of good dialogue and the story is all over the place. I couldnt make sense of it. There is also a lack of good character's chemistry. It's just off. It doesnt flow like the second edition did with ease. And without a good flow and solid characters that I can relate to, without all that even some of the better jokes dont land. They fall flat.What's left? A ton of nonstop bloody action, a lot more than the previous editions. And I get BORED by endless bloody fights just for the sake of trying to impress with CGI effects.It's not a terrible movie for sure, but the editing is overkill with it's constant fast cuts (even in talking scenes). Not letting the characters TALK and INTERACT with each other at a more natural pace, like the second edition did that is a big let down for me.This 3rd sequel didnt surpass the brilliant second edition I am disappointed to say. It was quite underwhelming to watch this latest 3rd sequel.I wont recommend it to my friends and family like I did do with the brilliant second edition. Not terrible, but quite underwhelming...

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine (2024)" delivers everything fans could hope for and more. The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool and Hugh Jackman's Wolverine is electric, blending humor, action, and heart in perfect balance. The film is packed with razor-sharp dialogue, breaking the fourth wall in classic Deadpool fashion, while also giving Wolverine his gritty, no-nonsense edge. The action sequences are exhilarating, combining Deadpool's chaotic energy with Wolverine's brutal combat style. Fans of both characters will love the playful banter and the emotional moments, making this crossover a dream come true. It's the perfect mix of comedy, action, and nostalgia that leaves audiences eagerly wanting more.

Review: Let me preface by saying that this is my first *movie* review on here. I have been meaning to get into it for a time but gaming reviews have been all I have had time for up to this point. However, after seeing this film, I really felt I needed to share my thoughts.First and foremost, this movie is excellent; but it will not be what you expect. I personally am a hardcore DC fan (despite their disappointing movies) and I still found myself eagerly awaiting "Deadpool and Wolverine". I followed the development of this film thoroughly and paid close attention to cast & crew credits with interest. I grew up liking Marvel before it was cool so I had high hopes for this film.As for this film, you certainly get the best of both worlds with both old and new Marvel. You'll certainly laugh until you cry if you get the references, but the little details are what truly bring this movie up to an 8 for me. The story itself is kind of boring and poorly written. But the acting and dialogue are so good that you don't really care.I would put it in my top 5 MCU films for sure but I still felt that they left something to be desired. I do recommend this film and I will probably see at least once more myself at some point.

Review: My life is complete. I want to kiss on the mouth everyone who was involved in the making of this movie. Let me tell you why you need to do yourself a favor and see this masterpiece. 1- The multiverse centered plot was executed perfectly, which most other Marvel movies have failed to do. Many other films butcher this redundant dramatic story of a character needing to save a timeline, but Deadpool 3 transforms it into a hilarious, meaningful character arc for both Wade and Logan. Instead of taking themselves seriously, the writers embrace the ridiculousness of Marvel, creating a perfect self deprecating comedy. 2 - The jokes and cameos had the entire audience laughing without one, cheap corny quip that Marvel is famous for. Obviously this is Deadpool, so the dialogue wasn't child or their overprotective mother friendly, but this raunchy comedy is just what this cinematic universe needed to kick the restraints Disney put on their shoulders. 3 - The performances of Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman really complete the 10/10 rating. Both actors convey the complex moral conflicts that make these characters unique so well, you can't imagine anyone ever usurping these roles. I don't think I could run out of compliments for Deadpool and Wolverine and this movie secures the title of best trilogy that the Marvel universe has.

Review: Firstly I'm going to start with this movie is not for everyone, if you are going to watch this movie I am going out on a leg to assume you are not easily offended and at least fit into on of the below categories!If you enjoy a good action flick with some top tier laughs this is for you. If you are an avid follower of the Marvel Universe (comics and movies) then buckle up because you are in for a real treat.I fall in to the latter category and without any exaggeration I am absolutely chuffed with how good this movie was. Without ruining any part of the movie with spoilers all I can say is the references, the little jabs, the breaking of the fourth AND fifth walls on top of comedic excellence as well as fitting it snugly into Marvels over-complicated MCU was just an absolute delight.I will be watching this again!!

Review: This is a brash movie full of brutal, grotesque sequences, but below the surface there is joke after joke and reference after reference. It's just brilliant.Maybe I'm biased because I'm a 90s kid and I got all the references, so I found it particularly great, but i think I'm astute enough to not be bowled over by a nod to something nostalgic.This is a superb film.My wife and I laughed out loud so many times. The humour oscillates between ridiculous and huge self awarenes. And thankfully they've gotten rid of the more slapstick stuff.This has immediately become one of my favourite movies of the last decade.Watch it, relax and enjoy.

Review: I absolutely LOVED this movie! It was everything I hoped for and more. Deadpool and Wolverine together on screen is pure magic. The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman is off the charts! Their banter, action, and comedic timing kept me laughing the whole way through. The humor is spot-on, with endless witty jokes, meta-references, and just the right amount of absurdity that we love from Deadpool. Wolverine's tough, no-nonsense attitude combined with Deadpool's chaotic energy creates the perfect balance. The action scenes are top-notch, full of intense fights and epic moments, but it's the humor and heart that truly shine. Whether you're a fan of the characters or just love a good action-comedy, this movie delivers in every possible way. Hands down one of the best Marvel movies ever made - I can't wait to watch it again!

Review: I had pretty much given up on the MCU since Endgame but being a fan of Hugh Jackman and his past cinematic runs as Wolverine I decided to give this one a shot. The violence, profanity and scatological humor is as you'd expect, off the scale, and there is something of a convoluted plot going on, but really the main drive of the film felt like two characters who hate one another and spend a good portion of the film trying to kill one another. But the problem is, knowing that both protagonists are essentially immortal (one with endless regenerative abilities, the other with an unbreakable adamantium skeleton and a fast-healing factor) then their fights become essentially meaningless. They can't kill one another, so it's just basically watching two guys fight with one another and waiting for it to resolve so we can get on with the story. Maybe it was a little interesting with the initial fight but after awhile, it gets old. Likewise the many numerous cameos that I won't spoil here were amusing at first, but you can only do so many "oh it's him" or "oh its her" reactions and then it gets tedious, especially when you're teased with a cameo and then the character either dies shortly after or just isn't seen again. It's nostalgia key-dangling at it's worst. As mentioned, I am a fan of Hugh Jackman and his return to the Wolverine was fantastic, like he stepped right back into the same role he was so legendary at before, but unfortunately there's just not enough of him and, to be completely honest, I would have preferred to see him in his own film instead of in a tiresome, gory buddy comedy.

Review: Yep, this will save Marvel enough. I can't imagine the amount of effort to put together a coherent script that contains a hot stew of satirical comedy, The-Boys-level violence, fourth-wall superimposing, and out-of-everywhere cameos and to convince Disney to fund it. Despite playing under Marvel's worldview of TVA and multiverse, Deadpool & Wolverine actually tells a simple story of two losers saving the world and redeeming one another --- a could-not-get-any-simpler formula but made with such respect and compassion of the lore which we have not seen from Marvel productions in a long time. It is a rewarding experience to all the fans who accompanied the cinematic superhero history thus far, whether the universe under Fox, Marvel, or more. However, this movie is extremely fan-based, as well as many other superhero films that are successful in part because they allude to prior works, which is concerning because the story itself is often placed secondary. Anyhow, this film deserves to be enjoyed in a crowded theater or with a bunch of friends --- just like the old Marvel.

Review: I don't know why the current screenwriters are always doing some stupid plots, but when I see the characters who grew up with me appear on the big screen again, I really can't describe the touch and sadness, as if the past time once came from behind again, only I was in the middle and the memory was around. Sore. You can experience the lost time in a movie, through our favorite characters, even those inconspicuous villains. They used to live in front of us, and then in our memory. Now they appear in front of us again. This is the surprise and touch brought by various guest appearances. They make me feel the real passage of time, the past and the present.

Review: I cannot think of another movie which was so incredibly hyped up and actually came close to living up to its billing! Comedy is for me the most difficult thing to produce in a movie theatre..... one great hilarious scene can make an average movie into a good one! I'm a huge comedy fan in every genre..... I've flown around the world to watch stand ups! This was just brilliant! I'm sure their will be the fair share of wannabe "edgy" critics who will always try put themselves on a pedestal by going against the crowd but I'm sorry if you didn't laugh out loud during this movie then this type of action comedy just isn't for you! Don't watch it and certainly don't tell people it wasn't good! I don't watch or review romantic period dramas because I don't like them! However DP&W I loved!! There's really not much more I can say! I just loved it! The fight scenes were choreographed spectacularly, the off the cuff 4th wall break comments you could easily miss were so funny, Ryan and Hugh were always going to be a great pairing and yes they really did deliver! I won't put any spoilers in here other than to say do yourselves a favour.... Go see this movie and then give an accurate IMDB (which is the only site worth anything in my opinion) review so others can enjoy it too! Well done guys! This will take some beating!!

Review: (MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD) I was very hyped for this movie. I was very excited to see the chemistry between a collaboration expected for years, I was excited to see the cult-funny action moments and the humor all the Deadpool movies, I was excited to see the Villain of the movie (Kassandra Nova) who looked quite interesting, in general everything about this movie looked promising to me at least. And I am happy to say that I was not let down or disappointed one bit at any part of the movie. Don't get me wrong now the movie is not flawless. It's 2 problems for me are the minor plot holes and kind of the way they managed the movie's time. These would be big problems if the movie was taking itself too seriously. DeadPool 3 is a cult superhero movie full of action that aims to only be fun and enjoyable and it isn't afraid to show it. However it still is an objectively quite good movie. I liked the cinematography, the soundtrack, the acting...Everything in this movie just amazing. Is this the so called ''Marvel's savior'' movie that will make us forget 85% of what happened after phase 3? I don't really know. Maybe. What I liked is that I sat down enjoyed 2 hours of MARVEL/DEADPOOL action, didn't get bored ONCE watched a very good movie and in general had a spectacular experience. That is something both MARVEL and DC aren't so generous nowadays so...have fun and enjoy 2 hours and 7 minutes of pure cult, funny, R rated action.

Review: I'm thrilled to have seen a Marvel movie this year, especially featuring Deadpool and Wolverine. These two make an incredible duo. The fight scenes were fantastic, and the comedic storyline had me laughing throughout. The film was packed with Easter eggs and cameos. It had two villains: Cassandra Nova and Paradox from the TVA. Cassandra's powers were intimidating and she had a truly scary presence, although I wish the MCU would do more with her character rather than potentially letting us down. Some scenes felt dragged out, and the pacing was occasionally slow and awkward. Despite this, the movie was overall fun and exciting. It was the great summer blockbuster we had all been waiting for.

Review: If we may have hoped in vain, no, this film will not "save" Disney's Marvel Universe. It can't even save neither the "Deadpool" series, whose first sequel was the only one at all fresh and interesting, nor the "X-Men" series, whose "Logan" from 2017 could have been a decent ending. The way it is, the movie wouldn't even deserve any comment, but it's good to draw a line once again and state how far this franchise has come. As far as I'm concerned, any interest faded long ago with the disappointing "Endgame" back in 2019.What can I say, except that you can like the movie only if you really liked the TV series "Loki" (unfortunately, I don't know such viewers), and if your humor remained at the level of preschool age, but far from the fact that the film is recommended for the mentioned age. I'm not even sure who this production is actually intended for, because with this amount of gratuitous violence, severed heads, hectoliters of spilled blood, constant swearing, profanity and cheap lines, it's hard to determine the target group that this wish-wash should like.All that aside, the biggest problem is the lack of any meaningful story, even reasonable motivation and characterization of actors, and that the reminders of some other heroes from Marvel history are reduced to literally appearing and disappearing in the next frame, wouldn't it cause a little nostalgia for long ago past better times, which represents, if not an insult to ours specific once-favorite characters, then certainly an insult to the good taste of the aggrieved audience. Also, there is an obvious intention to plan the future of the Marvel franchise by recycling the same characters from parallel universes, of which this film is just an announcement.I will add at the very end, the only two bright little spots are the main protagonists Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, who despite everything showed that they can somehow act in this kind of movie without any inspiration, script and real dialogues. Judge for yourself if you think that's enough to watch it.

Review: We all knew that Marvel had a lot at stake with this premiere to get the MCU and its stumbles back on track, but there was a trio that had an ace up their sleeve to make our hearts beat again.Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman and Shawn Levy give us a really fun, adult movie, designed to satisfy all the needs of fans. Beyond the fact that one can talk about fandom, the interesting thing that Marvel's new project proposes is to honor its past and look together to the future with a duo that breaks it on screen with charisma, blood and emotions.No one can argue with Reynolds' charisma, but it's good to know that Jackman is joining us to give us the tone necessary for an on-screen adventure full of gags, incredible sequences and the adult quality that we all wanted and that we now also know we needed.This is where the intelligence of a director like Levy comes in, who knows how to handle humor, action and blood and sets out to give us all those Marvel-style madness in a correct, precise and fearless way. So much politically incorrect humor, references, jokes and transgressive moments that are squared even over its two predecessors. Decisions that serve to make a correct mix between laughing at the entire world of superheroes, but also giving it the moment to vindicate its own story.So we can ask ourselves, was it worth the risk? Of course, it was worth the risk. It's pure entertainment that leaves no one out of the party, it's a gigantic event that Marvel wins with, not by providing the best MCU movie, but by giving us the movie that we all needed right now, which is to believe again that everything can be possible at Marvel.To think that this is a movie that only uses fandom resources to sustain itself is really wrong. It is a well-made movie that has absolute intelligence embedded in knowing how to handle emotions in equal parts and in respecting itself as a movie that has people behind it who know about cinema and entertainment.It is a well-directed, well-acted film, with a brutal soundtrack, with well-executed sequences and with a villain who is very well occupied, it is not a simple event film to satisfy needs, it is a film that fulfills its role as being in good hands that make it noticeable and without reproaches.For me, it is a result that does not disappoint, it remains firm with the initial proposal of the saga, and knows how to take advantage of certain decisions that Marvel planned lately and that end up being the perfect addition to become one of the most fun and functional crossovers of superhero franchises.A film to watch and enjoy and leave the theater satisfied, simply because Marvel was what it needed to give us, and we were totally grateful to receive it.

Review: As I waited about 3 years since the first confirmation of Deadpool 3, not a day went by when I thought of it being the best thing to come. And now in 2024, it is here and I'm so glad it's everything I wanted it to be. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are the duo I never knew could be so perfect on (and off) screen. Both of them just embrace the role of our favorite characters and delivers something beautiful and magical. With crazy cameos, amazing story and just a ride full of 4th wall breaks, laughter and action sequences, Deadpool and Wolverine is the experience of the decade so far. This is what comic book movie is like and it feels like a gift for all Marvel fans for the dedicated 30+ years of fan following and just completes the circle in the most wholesome way possible!P. S. I was so disappointed with the critics low reviews that I decided to give it a 10 as I legit couldn't anything to pick as a con. It's just a perfect CBM movie even if it's your first marvel movie ever!PROS:CONS:

Review: It's been years since I've laughed so much at a movie. For a while, I completely forgot it was 2024 and felt like I was back in the golden days of 2010. This film is a breath of fresh air, with humor that hits hard and a satirical edge that's both razor-sharp and brilliantly funny.The writing is packed with quotable lines and digs at Disney, Fox, and the entire entertainment industry-each more hilarious than the last. The humor isn't just surface-level; it's clever and self-aware, creating an experience that makes you laugh, think, and appreciate the nuances of satire. It's the kind of comedy that we've been sorely missing, and it's been far too long since we've had a movie that pulls it off this well.In a world where comedy often feels watered down, this film dares to push the boundaries, delivering an experience that's refreshing and undeniably entertaining. We need more movies like this-bold, unapologetically funny, and capable of transporting you to a time when comedies knew how to make a real impact. Without a doubt, it's one of the best films in years.

Review: I've head many different takes on the third 'Deadpool' entry - some enjoyed it, others didn't. A few thought it was merely okay. I guess what you're going to get out of this film is dependent on what you stand on the franchise and superhero films in general.If you're utterly tired of superhero films then this one doesn't offer much that's different - a supervillain wants to destroy the world and our antihero, Deadpool, must (finally!) team up with Wolverine (complete with yellow comic book costume) and save the day.And that's it. There's absolutely nothing majorly new about this film, so you could say it's merely average, unless - like me - it ticks all the boxes you're looking for in a film. Ryan Reyolds and Hugh Jackman are great actors who are perfectly cast for their retrospective roles and they play off each other perfectly. I've always wanted to see Hugh Jackman's Wolverine get the 'proper' outfit on screen and go crazy. I get that here. Personally, I loved the Marvel Cinematic Universe up until 'Phase 4' started, so a film like 'Deadpool & Wolverine' which openly mocks how the franchise has fallen is also very welcome. Finally, the cameos. I'm old enough to recall the superheroes films of the late 90s and early 2000s, so let's just say it was great to see a few 'old friends' on screen again.So I enjoyed it. If I had to offer any criticism, I'd say the opening twenty minutes did feel a little slow compared to the 'main meat' of the film. Plus a few scenes later on could probably have been trimmed. Overall, I'd take out between 10-15 minutes of the runtime to tighten it up. The main gripes I've seen online are that it's not very focused and if you dwell too much on the plot then it all falls apart. Okay, this may be true. So, in order for that not to be a problem - just don't think too much about the story and enjoy the excellent chemistry between the two leads and laugh at all the in-jokes based around the genre.I did. And I loved it.

Review: Anyone calling this the "best movie of 2024" should be banned from this website.In order to even remotely have a chance at understanding this movie you should have watch the Loki series at Disney plus. Otherwise, it is impossible to get a grasp of several concepts displayed here.This is a movie for Marvel nerds, a public that is easy to please. Regular moviegoers are going to have a hard time making any sense of this film.This was a disappointment and a missed opportunity. Marvel keeps abusing the "multiverse" genre and they are failing miserably to produce anything one could possible enjoy. I am not expecting a masterpiece. These are supposed to be films you can casually enjoy but now the stories are lame and too convoluted.This film should have been screened at a Comic Con. The vast majority of moviegoers are just wasting their time and money.

Review: Yeah i knew this would be good. There was zero doubt in my mind that the third deadpool was gonna deliver but it 100% exceeded my expectations. Where do i even begin???Easter eggs, inside jokes, and oddly specific references are the gold that makes these deadpool movies so fun. It's not the sex jokes or the one liners or the slapstick humor in particular, but it's deadpool says something that only certain people will get depending on how much they know. This is what creates the disonance between a fictional movie that only refers to things that happen in the movies world and a fictional movie that acknowledges real world things. Deadpool takes both as well as references from other completely unrelated fictional movies to frame his jokes. That's why these movies work so well.Deadpools character is molded through Ryan Reynolds. Hes learned over the years what to do and what NOT to do with deadpool through trial and error. He knows what the fans wanna see and this movie spoon fed it to us.Pulling in wolverine was a necessity to this films success. Hugh Jackman...the man you are. The fanservice we were given was through the roof for simps, geeks, and every type of fan in between. The two of them together was what i needed.Other films needa take notes, this is how you make an audience happy. Of course not every movie has to have the same goal deadpool & wolverine had, but i know for a fact that Ryan, Hugh, and Dogpool are all swimming in pools of the 1.32 billion dollars its made.

Review: No spoilers here. If you are a fan of Deadpool, see this movie. If you are a fan of Wolverine, see this movie. If you are a fan of movies that poke fun of movies, go see this. This was by far the best way Ryan Reynolds could make up for and help us forget Green Lantern. They went and earned that R rating with a gusto and determination that made for an entertaining, thrill filled ride that left little if any room for improvement. I am glad Disney didn't stifle the raunch and blatant use of the spillage of blood to stick to a formula that proves family friendly. The little kid in me didn't mind one bit. Thanks to the entire cast for such a wonderful summer movie. Make sure to stay through the credits!

Review: I really don't care what "official" reviewers say, they only care about boring god awful movies anyway. This movie is finally a movie that had FUN with it again. Remember fun? Remember when entertainment was actually light hearted and entertaining? Remember when movies weren't over 3 hours long with over 2 hours and 45 minutes of boring talks and fluff? Yeah! I missed that, and this movie truly delivers on its promise. Its just 2 hours of pure zany fun, a great sense of humor and just an overall feast of characters we know and love. I also really enjoyed (for me) newcomer Emma Corrin in this movie and I'm kinda hoping she can do the character of Cassandra in some movies again, because as a character it was nice and solid. An unexpected treat really. I feel this is the best Deadpool movie to date, and its just mad fun seeing him together with Wolverine. Also really hoping they will team up again, Hopefully also with Dafne Keen as Laura X-23 because she was again on fire in this one. Just good stuff, really!

Review: In Deadpool and Wolverine, I praised the story, performances of Raynolds and Jackman, direction, soundtrack, visual and sound effects, emotional weight in Logan's story, entertainment value, action scenes, comedic scenes and humor, breaking the fourth wall parts, and number of characters in the movie. All these were very good and I enjoyed them very much.But what I didn't like in Deadpool and Wolverine is the screenplay, extremely complex and messy plot, and pacing because the plot seriously makes the person who is watching lost and in some scenes, does not know what exactly happened and why it happened.But these flaws do not mean that I didn't enjoy Deadpool and Wolverine. I enjoyed it, and I am looking forward to see what the MCU will carry for Deadpool, Wolverine, and the X-Men in the future. When it comes to the score, I gladly give Deadpool and Wolverine 9 out of 10.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine has some entertaining moments with humour that lands well (except for all the worn-out homoerotic jokes), but falls flat and becomes a victim of its own hype. The narrative leans heavily on the idea that audiences should be in awe of Wolverine's return and his team-up with Deadpool, expecting fans to cheer at every turn.Unfortunately, the film often feels bogged down by its over-reliance on nostalgia, cameos, and especially meta references. Rather than enhancing the storytelling, these elements come across as superficial and often serve as a cheap trick, adding little real depth. The overemphasis on fan service distracts from the core plot-which is already quite shallow-making the movie feel much longer than it needs to be.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" delivers fan service at its finest. Finally, we see Wolverine in the iconic yellow and black outfit we've all been waiting for! Hugh Jackman reprises his role as Wolverine, and we hope he continues to do so until he's 90. The film is packed with cameos, bringing back heroes that were memed to death, each making fun of their own legacy. Chris Evans' role had me dying of laughter, and I had to explain to my daughter that he was part of the Marvel Universe before Captain America. From start to finish, this movie keeps you entertained with its humor and action. Every cameo felt like a well-placed nod to the fans, making the experience even more enjoyable. The chemistry between Deadpool and Wolverine is electric, showcasing their unique dynamics and adding depth to their characters. The plot, filled with unexpected twists and hilarious moments, keeps you engaged throughout.But why was Thor crying?

Review: From the moment the opening credits rolled, I knew the movie featuring Deadpool and Wolverine would be something special. This film exceeded my expectations, delivering an electrifying blend of humor, action, and emotional depth that left me utterly enthralled. As a fan of both characters, I can confidently say that this movie is a triumphant success, deserving of a perfect 10/10.The film brilliantly captures the essence of Deadpool and Wolverine, staying true to their distinct personalities while weaving a compelling narrative that brings them together in a way that feels organic and thrilling. Ryan Reynolds reprises his role as Deadpool with the same irreverent charm and wit that has endeared him to audiences worldwide. His quick one-liners, fourth-wall-breaking antics, and unapologetically outrageous behavior are all on full display, providing a steady stream of laughs throughout the film.Hugh Jackman, returning as Wolverine, brings his trademark intensity and rugged charisma to the role, reminding us why he has been the definitive Logan for nearly two decades. The dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine is electric, with their contrasting personalities creating a delightful and often hilarious juxtaposition. Their interactions are some of the film's highlights, ranging from comical banter to heartfelt moments that showcase the depth of their characters.One of the standout aspects of the movie is its action sequences. The choreography is top-notch, delivering visceral and thrilling combat scenes that highlight both Deadpool's acrobatic agility and Wolverine's brutal strength. The film does not shy away from the graphic violence that fans of the comic books have come to expect, but it balances this with a sense of fun and exhilaration that keeps the tone from becoming too dark. Each fight scene is meticulously crafted, ensuring that every punch, kick, and slash feels impactful and satisfying.The storyline is engaging and well-paced, skillfully blending elements of both characters' lore into a cohesive plot that keeps the audience invested from start to finish. The film explores themes of redemption, friendship, and the struggle to define oneself in a world that constantly tries to box you in. These themes are woven seamlessly into the narrative, adding emotional weight to the film without detracting from its primary focus on entertainment.Supporting characters also shine in their roles, adding depth and richness to the story. The inclusion of familiar faces from the X-Men universe is a treat for longtime fans, and the new characters introduced are compelling and well-developed. The film's villain is particularly noteworthy, presenting a formidable challenge to our heroes and driving the plot forward with a palpable sense of menace.The visual effects are spectacular, seamlessly blending practical effects with CGI to create a visually stunning experience. Whether it's Deadpool's rapid healing factor in action or Wolverine's claws in combat, the effects are convincing and enhance the overall immersion of the film. The cinematography and direction are equally impressive, with dynamic camera work and creative shot compositions that keep the audience engaged and invested in the action.The soundtrack deserves special mention as well, perfectly complementing the film's tone and enhancing the emotional impact of key scenes. From high-energy tracks during action sequences to more somber pieces during reflective moments, the music is expertly curated to match the film's shifting moods.In conclusion, the Deadpool and Wolverine movie is an absolute triumph, a perfect blend of humor, action, and heart that pays homage to its source material while offering something fresh and exciting. As a fan, I couldn't have asked for a better portrayal of these beloved characters. The film's flawless execution and captivating storytelling make it a must-watch, and I wholeheartedly give it a well-deserved 10/10. This movie is a celebration of what makes Deadpool and Wolverine iconic, and it will undoubtedly be remembered as one of the best superhero films of all time.

Review: One of the top 5 movies I've ever seen. I actually have nothing bad to say. It's the most I've ever seen people laugh in a theater, cameos that put Spider-Man: No Way Home to shame, an emotional story better than Deadpool 1 or 2, and fight choreography that rivals John Wick. If you know your Marvel and enough about movies in general, it's impossible to give this anything less than a 9. And it somehow found a way to be even more gory, bloody, and violent.This isn't something I cared about, but the reason why Deadpool & Wolverine only has a 79% Rotten Tomatoes critic score is because Cassandra Nova didn't have the worthy cause as villains such as Thanos or Kilmonger. But don't get me wrong, Emma Corrin was fantastic and Cassandra Nova put more fear into Deadpool than Wolverine's claws went into him.So if you haven't seen Deadpool & Wolverine, make sure your Marvel knowledge is up to date, AND GET YOUR BUTT UP AND PLACE IT IN A MOVIE THEATER.
