Review: I must admit I was a bit nervous going to see this one at the cinema without watching a trusted review first. Yes; that's the current reality of modern Hollywood movies. After many a bait-and-switch and betrayal, I've almost given up and resorted to re-watching old movies.This scepticism worked to my advantage this time. The sensation of utter relief and excitement during the opening scene was incredible. And the movie kept delivering with great pacing, contrasting between deliciously manic highs and and a few necessary breathers in between. I still expected the obligatory scene of misplaced, heavy handed morality concerning whatever this years hottest cultural potato might be, and I might even have been fine with it due to the quality of the rest of the movie. But it never came! A delight from beginning to end. Perfectly balanced, as all things must be, but never has been since End Game.Good job, everyone!

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a masterclass in blending action, humor, and emotion. From the opening scene, it's clear that this film is not holding back on the bloody and gory elements that fans of both characters expect. The fight choreography is intense and brutally satisfying, showcasing Wolverine's raw, animalistic combat style and Deadpool's chaotic, unpredictable approach. The action sequences are relentless and well-executed, leaving the audience on the edge of their seats.But what sets this movie apart from other superhero flicks is its seamless integration of humor. Deadpool's trademark quips and fourth-wall-breaking moments are as sharp and hilarious as ever. Ryan Reynolds embodies the character with such perfection that it's hard to imagine anyone else in the role. His comedic timing is impeccable, and he delivers each line with a mix of sarcasm and charm that keeps the audience laughing throughout. Hugh Jackman's Wolverine serves as the perfect counterbalance, with his gruff demeanor and deadpan reactions providing the ideal foil to Deadpool's antics.The film also doesn't shy away from exploring the emotional depths of its characters. While it never delves too deep into melancholy, there are poignant moments that add a surprising layer of depth. Wolverine's struggle with his past and his relationship with Deadpool bring a sense of vulnerability to the character that's rarely seen. These emotional beats are handled with care, ensuring they resonate without dragging down the film's pace or tone.One of the highlights of "Deadpool and Wolverine" is the plethora of Easter eggs and cameos. Fans of the X-Men franchise will delight in spotting the numerous nods to past films, comics, and even other Marvel properties. These references are woven into the narrative in a way that feels organic and respectful to the source material. The cameos, while abundant, are used effectively and add to the film's overall charm rather than feeling like gratuitous fan service.The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman is undeniable, and their dynamic drives much of the film's appeal. Their banter and camaraderie are infectious, and it's evident that both actors are having a blast in their roles. This infectious energy translates to the screen, making their interactions a joy to watch.Visually, the film is stunning. The special effects are top-notch, bringing the fantastical elements of the X-Men universe to life in vivid detail. The cinematography captures the gritty, visceral nature of the action while also highlighting the more tender, character-driven moments. The score and soundtrack complement the film's tone perfectly, enhancing both the high-octane action scenes and the more introspective moments."Deadpool and Wolverine" also excels in its narrative structure. The plot is well-paced, with a good balance of action, humor, and character development. The story is engaging and keeps the audience invested from start to finish. The screenplay is tightly written, with clever dialogue and a storyline that honors the legacy of the characters while also pushing them in new and interesting directions.This movie is an incredible love letter to the X-Men franchise. It pays homage to the rich history of the characters and their stories while also paving the way for future installments. It's a film that respects its audience, delivering on their expectations while also surprising them with unexpected twists and turns.In conclusion, "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a must-watch for fans of the characters and the X-Men universe. It's a film that delivers on all fronts: action, humor, emotion, and spectacle. The blend of brutal action and sharp comedy makes for an exhilarating viewing experience. It's a film that you'll want to watch again and again, catching new details and Easter eggs with each viewing. "Deadpool and Wolverine" is not just a great superhero movie; it's a great movie, period. I can't wait to watch it again.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine is a cinematic masterpiece that expertly blends the irreverent humor of Deadpool with the brooding intensity of Wolverine. This unexpected pairing results in a film that is both thrilling and hilarious, leaving audiences wanting more.The chemistry between Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman as Wolverine is electric. Their contrasting personalities and styles create a dynamic that is both entertaining and heartwarming. Deadpool's witty banter and self-deprecating humor perfectly complement Wolverine's stoic demeanor and gruff exterior.The film's action sequences are nothing short of spectacular. The choreography is flawless, and the visual effects are stunning. From the high-octane fight scenes to the explosive set pieces, Deadpool & Wolverine delivers on every level. However, what truly sets this film apart is its exceptional writing. The script is filled with clever dialogue, hilarious one-liners, and poignant moments that will leave you laughing, crying, and cheering. The writers have a masterful ability to balance humor with heart, creating a film that is both entertaining and thought-provoking.One of the most impressive aspects of Deadpool & Wolverine is its ability to seamlessly blend genres. It is a superhero film, a buddy comedy, and a heartfelt drama all rolled into one. The film never feels forced or contrived, and each element contributes to the overall narrative.In conclusion, Deadpool & Wolverine is a must-see film for fans of both the characters and the genre. It is a hilarious, action-packed, and emotionally resonant masterpiece that will leave you wanting more. The performances are outstanding, the writing is exceptional, and the chemistry between the two leads is undeniable. This is a film that will be remembered for years to come.

Review: This was the most fun I've have at the movies in a long while, Saw it in IMAX 3D on Sunday at 12:20pm probably the 1st Showtime and it was probably 75% full, and, I'm guessing every Showtime after that was Sold Out, I remember certain movies that at the time I thought would have the Legs to get past the Billion Dollar Mark for different reasons Titanic was a great movie that even though it was over 3hrs long the word of mouth was incredible, it stayed in theatres for months, Avatar was a good movie over 2hrs 30 minutes great word of mouth for it's story and breathtaking visuals and after 2 weeks of breaking box office records there was no slowing it down and now I Deadpool & Wolverine has all those elements, It's an Absolute Cameos dream that will attract everyone but more importantly, It has a mean and lean 2hrs 7 minute runtime making it's earning potential quite possibly the 1st $5 Billion Dollar Movie? Anyways that's to be determined in the next few weeks-months but the Movie was Fantastic. And yes it was a Cameos dream and it helped tremendously my viewing experience that I didn't this beforehand, I had an absolute Blast as did everyone in attendance, The Movie has a during credits Show Reel from past behind the scenes X-Men movies and a Hilarious end credits scene, everything about this movie was spot on, It's a "10" for me hands down.

Review: Sit back, watch and enjoy. This is about as perfect as a movie gets. Had a LOT of good laughs. The acting is awesome, the cameos are brilliant, the special effects are amazing, the humor is hilarious, the references to other pop culture are priceless, it is simply a pleasure from beginning to end. A spectacular achievement in the Deadpool franchise. Please make lots more of these 2 fantastic actors together! I want to see it again immediately, because I'm sure I've missed stuff the first time around. It doesn't fail to deliver. Sometimes I wonder just how they can continue to resurrect the characters again and again, but the multiverse doesn't disappoint.

Review: Amazing to see so many cameos & be able to cheer up."Deadpool & Wolverine" delivers an exhilarating cinematic experience, packed with unexpected cameos and thrilling moments that are sure to make fans cheer. The film's strength lies in its playful nods to the wider superhero universe, creating a sense of shared excitement that's palpable. The blend of humor and action keeps the audience engaged, showcasing the unique chemistry between Deadpool & Wolverine.Critics may have their reservations, but for fans, this movie is a delightful escape that celebrates the spirit of these beloved characters (give us a break!).Sometimes, the joy of seeing familiar faces and enjoying the playful banter is more than enough to make a film memorable. If you're a fan of the franchise, this film is likely to exceed your expectations and provide a refreshing break from the more serious tones of recent superhero movies.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" made me think it could reach another level. The writers are generic and still manage to do something much worse than mediocre. A totally nonsense script with no depth, no purpose and to make matters worse it looks like a typical Marvel movie released in the last few years. The R rating of "Deadpool & Wolverine" is the most "PG-13" I've ever seen, the violence is made to shock 3-year-olds and the obscenity and swearing make the movie look like a Seth Rogen comedy, but the worst and most unfunny one he's ever made. The direction is actually interesting and the framing even offers beauty (sometimes), but these are perhaps the only really positive points of this movie. In the final balance, "Deadpool & Wolverine" represents the decadence of the superhero movie era and especially the decadence of Marvel Studios, it's a shame, I could write a very long text about how bad "Deadpool & Wolverine" is, but to save words, I prefer to end this review here.

Review: What can I say, it was exactly what I wanted to see! This a buddy comedy to it's core well seasoned with porta-potty humor and cartoonish ultra violence that just works. Reynolds and Jackman have an undeniable chemistry and I couldn't stop laughing from beginning to end! If you're a comic book/ movies nerd then you're in for a treat, because there's thousands of easter eggs and cameos that really stick the landing on account of the meta approach the film takes. I'm not giving away any spoilers but to me it all worked really well. Problems with the movie? The story isn't great, but honestly who cares, it does the job and it's tightly written, the cgi in the third act was not great and took me away for a bit, especially regarding the mask of a certain character. But these are minor gripes, go watch it and support Marvel Jesus.

Review: This third entry in the meta heavy Deadpool series follows Wade Wilson as he lives a somewhat normal life with his family and friends. But when Marvel come knocking and offer him an opportunity to join the MCU, his initial excitement fades when he realises they want just him, and not his universe. After violently rejecting their proposal and being banished to a void-like dimension where forgotten cinematic Marvel heroes go to die, he has to rally together some classic heroes to break free and save his friends from extinction.Before going into these films, you need to understand they they are not going to take themselves seriously whatsoever, be full of lewd jokes, break the fourth wall and be utterly rammed with references to not only Marvel, but real life situations. Oscar bait, this is most definitely not. But what this is, it funny, charming, heartwarming and full of awesome action scenes and some amazing cameos. Despite a somewhat underwhelming and annoying antagonist, everything else is on point. I have said it before, but Deadpool is the character Ryan Reynolds was born to play, and Hugh Jackman's gruff and grumpy Wolverine is the perfect juxtopostion to Reynold's cheery and smart mouthed merc. If you are a fan of Deadpool, Marvel or the X-Men and just want to laugh and have fun for 2 hours then I can't recommend this enough.

Review: You can still just leave a random score on a movie that, much like this movie, convinces otherwise sane people to throw good money away and spend over two hours in a theater rather than, oh I dunno, nailing your tongue to a tree? Which I might add would be a better use of time than seeing this overinflated vanity project for the bromance of Hugh and Ryan.It's a struggling storyline that just can't seem to make up its mind on a consistent narrative, takes too long to arrive at anything resembling a point, and no amount of 'oh hey that's so-and-so!', of cameos could save this dumpster fire of a film.Anyone hoping to have a film wrap up a trilogy in this flick is in for a very obnoxious excuse of an attempt, and if you simply must go see this anyway, check your expectations at the cinema door and just use your brain as a door stop and then you might find this remotely interesting and find entertainment value.

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" is X-stastic and bombastic! This film is great fun with fan service aplenty, though a tad overcrowded with cameos crammed into its 2-hour runtime.Seeing Wolverine in his classic comic book costume after so long is a dream come true-he looks absolutely badass!The fight scenes are creatively brutal and visually gorgeous, showcasing the characters in all their glory.Loved the way it tries to tie up as much as superhero movie genre flavour has to offer starting from 2000. Leans heavily on nostalgic elements. Combinig different aspects and bits of references from both comics and superhero movies that came before.This movie feels different and it does not fit into the tiredness that superhero films have added in the last 2-3 years, it offers a well-deserved refreshThe movie leaves the door wide open for so much more and I can't wait to watch these films until I'm 90! :)) pun intendedMy personal opinion, a fun summer movie to watch at the cinema with familly and friends.

Review: Hugh Jackman is the perfect Wolverine. What a fun movie. I like the dialogue. It's not taking itself too seriously. There are tons of fun cameos I didn't expect! You know it's going to be fun with these two, but man... I laughed so hard, that even my stomach was feeling it. And the jokes... be sure this is not Deadpool watered down in the MCU, it's Deadpool at its best. The inevitable bromance is unveiled before our eyes. The story is fine, nothing special, but you feel it, and knowing the past knowledge about these characters and their respective universes makes everything hit the emotions. It's a fan service, but who cares - it's an entertaining fun summer blockbuster that gives you what you've paid for.

Review: So this isn't quite like other Deadpool films. And yet it is. It's violent, gratuitously potty-mouthed, pcked full of in-jokes and it's bloody funny.And yet it felt different somehow. Like there was a*slightly* more serious undercurrent.The plot was daft but worked well enough to support a spectacular ensemble cast with cameos all over the place, subtly (and not so subtle) nods to and digs at various movie tropes and events and lots and lots of snappy one-liners.Plus the cutest ugly dog you'll ever see.If you're easily offended then you may not like it. Ditto if you're after highbrow entertainment. But if you're looking for clever but ultimately mindless laughs (yeah I know it's an oxymoron but you get what I mean I'm sure) then you'll love it.

Review: If you've ever wondered what would happen if you took the wild humor of Deadpool and mixed it with the grizzled charm of Wolverine, then *Deadpool & Wolverine* is the answer to your comic book fever dream. Here's my take on this rollercoaster of a movie:This film is a glorious, action-packed riot that embraces its absurdity with open arms. Hugh Jackman as Wolverine proves yet again that he's the best at what he does, even if what he does isn't very nice. The banter between Jackman and Ryan Reynolds is nothing short of comedic gold, with Reynolds' Deadpool delivering quips faster than Wolverine can pop his claws. The chemistry between these two is electric, and their dynamic is the heartbeat of the film.The plot? Well, it's as chaotic as you'd expect from a Deadpool movie, but that's part of the charm. The film doesn't take itself too seriously, and neither should you. It's a blend of action, humor, and heart that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The dialogue is peppered with enough f-bombs to make a sailor blush, but it's all in good fun. The cameos are plentiful and surprising, making every scene a potential "oh snap" moment.Emma Corrin as Cassandra Nova is a standout villain, bringing a cold-blooded yet sardonic edge to the film. She's a perfect foil for our two heroes, and her presence elevates the stakes. The action sequences are a banquet of madness, especially the "corridor" fight scene (which is actually in a street) - it's a visual and visceral treat.The soundtrack is another highlight, perfectly complementing the film's frenetic energy. The opening scene alone is pure gold, setting the tone for the chaos that follows. And let's not forget the post-credits scene - it's a must-see, packed with hints for future adventures.In summary, *Deadpool & Wolverine* is a bloody, hilarious romp that's sure to please fans of both characters. It's not Shakespeare, but it's a damn good time. So grab your popcorn, suspend your disbelief, and enjoy the ride. And remember, if Wolverine can keep going until he's 90, then there's plenty more fun to be had with these two.

Review: I am a huge Fan of Avengers, X-Men and Deadpool.*Not Marvel's Biggest Triumph UNSATISFIED: I was eagerly anticipating this movie, but it failed to meet my expectations. Instead of a thrilling action film, it turned out to be just another mediocre entry in the genre.FIGHT SCENES were sparse, brief, and uninteresting, relying heavily on gore and violence rather than action. Forced car fight scene between D&W.The excessive use of VULGAR LANGUAGE felt unnecessary and detracted from the overall experience. Forced use of F-Word in every third sentence.PLOT was average at best. Ryan Reynolds' signature fourth-wall breaks, which were a highlight in the prequels, fell flat this time. The comedy, which I hoped would redeem the film, was a dismal 3/10. A staggering 80% of the movie was CGI.LAME VILLAINs: Paradox and Cassandra, were lame and had illogical motive.Additionally, Deadpool's character disappointed me. His SELFISHNESS, using Logan merely to save his friends while disregarding others, and using Nicepool as a shield, was disheartening. He didn't become any Marvel Jesus or Messiah.OVERALL, this film was a major letdown and did not live up to the hype.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine is a high-energy, action-packed film that brings together two of Marvel's most unconventional characters in a thrilling crossover event. Directed by David Leitch, the movie combines the irreverent humor of Deadpool with the brooding intensity of Wolverine, delivering a unique and entertaining experience.The film centers on Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) and Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) as they join forces to tackle a new, formidable threat that endangers the Marvel Universe. The plot intertwines their distinct styles and personalities, creating a dynamic narrative that balances action, humor, and character development. The story is fast-paced and engaging, filled with witty banter, explosive set pieces, and unexpected twists.Ryan Reynolds reprises his role as Deadpool with his trademark charisma and irreverence. His performance is a highlight, delivering sharp one-liners and breaking the fourth wall with his usual flair. Reynolds' chemistry with Hugh Jackman is palpable, making their interactions both entertaining and genuine. Jackman's Wolverine brings a darker, more serious tone, creating a compelling contrast to Deadpool's antics. Their on-screen partnership is both humorous and action-packed, making for a refreshing and enjoyable dynamic.The action sequences in Deadpool & Wolverine are a standout feature, with choreography that showcases the unique fighting styles of both characters. The film's special effects are top-notch, enhancing the intensity of the battles and the visual appeal of the film. The blend of Deadpool's acrobatic combat and Wolverine's brutal force creates exhilarating and well-crafted action scenes that keep the audience engaged.The film's humor is consistent with the Deadpool franchise, incorporating self-referential jokes, pop culture references, and meta-commentary. This humor is balanced with moments of emotional depth and character development, particularly in the interactions between Deadpool and Wolverine. The screenplay provides a good mix of laughs and serious moments, ensuring that the film appeals to a broad audience.Visually, Deadpool & Wolverine is vibrant and stylish, with a cinematographic approach that complements the film's tone. The production design and costume work are impressive, bringing the characters and their world to life with attention to detail. The soundtrack also adds to the film's energy, with a selection of tracks that enhance the action and emotional scenes.However, the film does have some weaknesses. The plot, while engaging, can be predictable at times, and the constant humor may overshadow some of the deeper aspects of the story. Additionally, the reliance on familiar tropes and character dynamics might not offer much new for fans who are familiar with the Deadpool and Wolverine characters from previous films.In conclusion, Deadpool & Wolverine is a successful crossover that combines action, humor, and character-driven storytelling. With strong performances from Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, exciting action sequences, and a balance of comedy and drama, the film delivers an entertaining experience for fans of both characters. While it may not break new ground in terms of narrative, it provides a fun and engaging addition to the Marvel cinematic universe, showcasing the chemistry between its two iconic heroes.

Review: Rating: 9/10Introduction: "Deadpool & Wolverine," a crossover event that fans of both Marvel heroes have long awaited, delivers a spectacular blend of humor, action, and raw emotion. This collaboration brings together two of Marvel's most beloved anti-heroes in a narrative that is as thrilling as it is entertaining.Plot: The story kicks off with a mysterious threat that forces Deadpool and Wolverine to team up, despite their contrasting personalities and methods. The plot is fast-paced, weaving through intense action sequences, unexpected twists, and character-driven moments. The narrative explores themes of redemption, friendship, and the struggle between chaos and order, all while maintaining a balance between humor and seriousness.Character Dynamics:Deadpool (Wade Wilson): As expected, Deadpool steals the show with his irreverent humor, fourth-wall-breaking antics, and unpredictable nature. Ryan Reynolds' portrayal continues to shine, bringing depth to Wade Wilson's struggles beneath the comedic facade. Deadpool's interactions with Wolverine are a highlight, showcasing a mix of respect, annoyance, and a surprising camaraderie.Wolverine (Logan): Hugh Jackman's Wolverine is as gritty and stoic as ever, providing a perfect counterbalance to Deadpool's chaos. Wolverine's hardened exterior and internal battles add gravitas to the story. His reluctant mentorship of Deadpool and the exploration of his own past traumas are handled with nuance, adding layers to his character.Action and Visuals: The action sequences in "Deadpool & Wolverine" are nothing short of spectacular. The choreography is brutal and inventive, leveraging the unique abilities of both characters. The film does not shy away from graphic violence, staying true to the nature of both heroes. The visual effects are top-notch, seamlessly integrating the more fantastical elements into a grounded setting.Humor and Tone: The humor is sharp and plentiful, with Deadpool's quips and meta-commentary providing continuous laughter. The film expertly balances humor with darker, more serious moments, never allowing one aspect to overshadow the other. The tonal shifts are handled with care, ensuring that the emotional beats hit just as hard as the comedic ones.Supporting Cast: The supporting characters are well-developed and add significant value to the story. Cameos from other Marvel characters and new additions to the universe are seamlessly integrated, enhancing the overall narrative without feeling forced. Each character serves a purpose, contributing to the growth and journey of the protagonists.Conclusion: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a triumph, blending the best elements of both characters into a cohesive and highly entertaining story. It's a film that caters to fans of the comics while being accessible to newcomers. The dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine is electric, providing endless entertainment and emotional depth. This crossover event is a must-watch for any Marvel fan, delivering on its promise of chaos, grit, and unparalleled fun.Final Thoughts: The collaboration between Deadpool and Wolverine is a testament to the strength of Marvel's character-driven storytelling. It's a film that not only entertains but also resonates on a deeper level, exploring the complexities of its heroes. Whether you're in it for the action, the humor, or the character development, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is sure to leave a lasting impression.

It felt like it was much more diverse and "blacker" in the first parts. This is understandable, because this part was aimed at much greater audience coverage, because humor was limited by the censorship part.And so, as for me, the film is very good in terms of production, graphics, and ideas. However, as for me, the film is for one time.

Review: The film is of really high quality. It is well-shot, fun, and makes you laugh. The IMAX detail is perfect, but if you haven't seen the previous series, you might find yourself saying, 'What do you mean? What they are talking about??' while watching the film. It almost forces you to watch the earlier movies in the series, and then you'll feel like you need to watch this one again. Of course, since it deals with the main character outside of the previous film series, it also includes the main character's previous films that you need to watch. So it seems like you have a lot of ways to look and research. All in all, if you enjoy dark humor, it's the most entertaining movie you can watch, and I love it.

Review: This movie is something like a beautiful memory from your childhood... Lately all the movies from Mickey Mouse had some agenda they wanted to introduce or more likely indoctrinated on you, but this... This just wants you to have fun.It brings back a lot of characters from different movies (and universes of MC/U), but in a good way. Review: Zero irony. This has intelligent plot, perfect soundtrack, incredible production design, sincere acting, realistic dialogue. It discussed some serious subject matter, like growing old with the uncertainty if what you do matters and consequently if you do matter yourself. Also about living with the consequences of your actions and deciding if your past will define your future. It is the perfect superhero movie - keeping it real in its character themes while going as far as imagination can take it in the action scenes and story. I am honestly surprised to see a good Marvel movie again and I sincerely hope to see more of it in the future.

Review: This movie is a mess.It starts as a brilliant self reverential comedy which is often laugh out loud funny, but requires a degree of knowledge of the Marvel franchise for many of the gags to land (some of which are puerile and some, as noted in the Guardian, homophobic).If you are a fan of puerile, which I guess I am, then you will find the first hour is pretty enjoyable.But that's it. I admit I took a sleep in the next 67 minutes because this movie became excruciatingly boring, repetitive, formulaic and just plain annoying.Why do movies so often outstay their welcome today? This would have been an acceptable 90 minute romp. As it is, though, my take out is bloated, self indulgent pap.Next time get a decent editor.

Review: In the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Deadpool has always been loved by audiences for his humor and rebellious spirit. This time, he is invited by the Time Variance Authority (TVA), but he chooses an unusual path-recruiting a variant of Wolverine. This decision not only surprises but also adds much fun and tension to the film.At the beginning of the film, Deadpool's humor continues to shine, with his self-awareness and teasing of the audience making people laugh. As the plot develops, viewers will see the interaction between him and Wolverine, which is undoubtedly one of the most attractive partnerships in the Marvel Universe. The differences in their personalities create sparks in their collaboration, filled with intense battle scenes and warm moments.During the process of saving the universe, the film is not just a pile of action scenes but also delves into themes of friendship, sacrifice, and responsibility. The relationship between Deadpool and Wolverine deepens, allowing the audience to feel their bond. Especially in moments of life and death, Deadpool's humor contrasts sharply with Wolverine's determination, showcasing their different responses in crises.The special effects and action design are also noteworthy, with smooth and creative battle scenes providing visual enjoyment. Whether it's Deadpool's swordplay or Wolverine's claw strikes, the audience feels a strong sense of impact and urgency. The director cleverly combines humor with action, making the entire film tightly paced and captivating.Overall, this movie is not just a superhero film but a profound exploration of choice and responsibility. Deadpool's choices make us reflect on whether we can bravely follow our hearts when facing significant decisions. Whether you are a Marvel fan or an ordinary viewer, you can find fun and inspiration in this film. Looking forward to more exciting stories like this in the future!

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is the superhero crossover we've all been waiting for, and it does not disappoint. Directed by Shawn Levy, this film masterfully blends the irreverent humor of Deadpool with the gritty, no-nonsense demeanor of Wolverine, creating a unique cinematic experience that stands out in the crowded superhero genre.From the very beginning, the film sets the tone with Deadpool's trademark fourth-wall-breaking antics. Ryan Reynolds, once again, embodies the Merc with a Mouth, delivering rapid-fire quips and outrageous stunts that keep the audience laughing throughout. Hugh Jackman, reprising his role as Wolverine, brings his usual intensity and depth, providing a perfect counterbalance to Deadpool's chaos. The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman is electric, and their banter is both hilarious and heartfelt.The plot centers around an unlikely team-up, as Deadpool and Wolverine are forced to join forces against a common enemy. The film strikes a delicate balance between action, humor, and emotion, offering thrilling fight scenes, clever dialogue, and moments of genuine character development. The action sequences are top-notch, showcasing Wolverine's brutal fighting style alongside Deadpool's unpredictable combat tactics. The choreography is slick, and the special effects are impressive, making every punch, slash, and explosion feel impactful.One of the film's strengths is its ability to embrace its R-rating without feeling gratuitous. The violence is visceral, but it never overshadows the story or characters. Instead, it adds to the film's gritty realism, reminding viewers that these characters exist in a world where the stakes are high, and the consequences are real.While the film is undeniably entertaining, it also takes time to explore deeper themes. Both Deadpool and Wolverine are characters defined by pain and loss, and the film doesn't shy away from these aspects. There are moments of introspection and vulnerability that add layers to their personalities, making them more relatable and compelling.However, the film isn't without its flaws. The pacing occasionally falters, with some scenes feeling slightly drawn out. Additionally, while the villain is menacing, they lack the complexity that would have made them truly memorable. Despite these minor issues, the overall experience is thoroughly enjoyable.In conclusion, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a wild, exhilarating ride that delivers on its promise of high-octane action and gut-busting humor. Fans of both characters will be thrilled by their dynamic partnership, and newcomers to the franchise will find plenty to enjoy as well. It's a film that doesn't take itself too seriously, but still manages to pack an emotional punch. Whether you're here for the laughs, the action, or the characters, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a must-watch.

Furthermore, this saga illustrates the fact that True Heroes may not immediately rush in where most angels fear to tread. Many overwhelming problems will require thoughtful consideration prior to confronting them, during which time period the foolhardy may flame out like so much chaff. However, this big screen offering honors the Traditional Family Values for which its releasing studio is so well known.

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" masterfully juggles dark humor with edgy, controversial jokes that border on tasteless, including sexist quips characteristic of Deadpool's brazen style. His sarcasm-laden and somewhat self-deprecating humor might not be everyone's cup of tea, but it undoubtedly has a dedicated following. This, juxtaposed with Wolverine's raw and uncompromising demeanor, creates a volatile mix where intense fight scenes meet cutting humor. It's also a tribute to the comic book style from which these characters originated. Bold, brash, and full of sly winks - this film doesn't shy away from crossing lines and definitely flirts with controversy. Creators here have opted for a rollercoaster of emotions, rounded out with solid action and a clever take on science fiction.

Absolutely wonderfulDeadpool and Wolverine gets an A.

Review: This film is the latest installment in the Deadpool series and the first in the franchise under Disney. It follows Deadpool, who is feeling down after his recent breakup with girlfriend Vanessa, leaving him searching for a greater purpose and a way to impress her. He finds this purpose when he is kidnapped by the TVA and informed that his timeline is collapsing because his universe's Wolverine has died. This sets Deadpool on a mission to find a replacement Wolverine. Together, with the help of both new and familiar faces, they must defeat a dangerous new foe and save his world before it's torn apart. Overall, due to the fall-out-of-your-chair laughs, Reynold's and Jackman's electric chemistry, badass action, and brilliant meta commentary, I loved this feature, and even though I had a few gripes with it and it's lack of connection to the MCU, this movie was nearly perfect and some of the most fun I've had in the theater, and a great final send off for the Fox universe while also being a highlight for Marvel in its darkest hour.

Review: This movie hit rock bottom of bad taste on so many levels. It's like they threw in every terrible idea they had and hoped something would stick. Spoiler: it didn't.A nonsensical, disconnected, and utterly humorless story. This movie should have been called "Cassandra Nova"; she truly deserved this film all to herself. She was the only character that was genuinely good enough, putting the main characters to shame on so many levels.An anonymous alcoholic Wolverine, totally forced. Who thought this was a good idea? Perhaps he needed a psychologist and an A. A. meeting instead of a movie. Seriously, this portrayal is an insult to the character's legacy.An unbearable Deadpool, why wouldn't he shut up? I couldn't stand hearing his voice anymore. It's like they were trying to make him as obnoxious as possible. Besides, he was completely selfish, and it was disgusting to watch. Was the intention to make us feel repulsed by this character? If so, mission accomplished.Unnecessary sexual jokes, unnecessary swearing, unnecessary characters. Few scenes were good. The dialogue was cringeworthy, and the humor fell flat every single time. And what the hell was that ridiculous dog? Extremely forced scenes, it was hard to watch.To be sincere, I was hoping Cassandra did accomplish what she wanted, she was the only character worth watching. If you liked anything about this movie besides Cassandra, reconsider.

Review: I am Ryan Reynold's age (47), and I felt like this movie was made for my generation. Yes, it's a superhero movie...but it's so much more. It felt like a visit back to the 90s with the music, sense of humor, and distinctly un-PC tone.I have a working knowledge of the Marvel universe (seen most of the movies), but by no means am an expert. I'm sure hundreds of details flew right past me. But that's okay, because this is that rare superhero movie where you can have little to no knowledge of the Marvel universe and still laugh your ass off. It's rare for a movie to sustain the laughs from beginning to end (Hangover did that for me), but this might have come close to topping it. Wife saw the movie the next night and felt the same way.

Review: This was pretty bad. It starts out promising, but as the movie goes on, it goes from one disjointed scene to the next. You don't know where it's going. There is no nice flow. It's like the movie constantly stutters. It hurts the storytelling very much.And then the jokes, one of the main selling points of Deadpool, in this movie they are forced: look at me telling a joke! Yeah, but it wasn't that good, so please stop bragging. And also don't talk to the audience all the time. I find it highly annoying. A couple of times is OK. This is too much.I can't even go deep into the story, because it was all over the place. The basic storyline is very simple, too simple, but as a whole it is a complete chaos. When things happen, why they happen, how they happen, it seems that little thought was put into it. So on top of the bad flow from one scene to the next it's also a lack of logic in and between scenes. This is reinforced by a lot of unnecessary/useless dialogue, which sometimes made the movie drag. Just tedious. The fighting scenes felt gratuitous.I don't understand the high rating this movie has received. Is it my personal taste? I struggled to finish the movie and had a sigh of relief at the end, even though I loved the first two Deadpool movies. This one's an absolute miss in my book. Definitely over-rated.

I know that Disney bought Fox, but it was so annoying hearing them repeat that fact throughout the movie. The fan service was also a bit much. The tension between Wolverine and Deadpool was so pointless because they always stabbed each other and later regenerated. Even though I watched the movie yesterday, I don't remember anything from it, and I will definitely not watch it again. I don't understand the hype behind this movie.

Review: I don't care if my opinion will get thumbs down, it is my honest opinion!So.. let's start with the good things: R rated! Many bloody scenes like you used to it from a Deadpool movie! First Deadpool was almost a masterpiece for the comedy/bloody action/super antihero genre! The second one was decent but not good as the first! I know the personality of Deadpool is comedic and big mouth and all, but in this one, all.. literally ALL the characters making jokes, some are good, the majority are cringe, corny and cheesy! It's like a bad stand up comedy with all the people joking. The whole movie is a cringe comedy. Even the moments when the movie want to be or seems serious or dramatic, it feels cringe because the next second, a cringe cheesy joke lands!The action scenes are haotic with enough brutality and gore/blood but not enough to save the movie from being a corny comedy! There's a lots of cameos unnecessary. It's some kind of Multiverse of Madness.This is the worst Deadpool movie! I repeat: i liked the first, the second was decent, but this one is just...for the masses who want to laugh maniacally at cringe cheesy jokes every 2 minutes! And again, i understand the comedic thing on Deadpool movies, but this one has too much comedy/corny/cringe jokes! It's a bad bloody comedy and lots of you will enjoy it! For me, there was TOO many cringe jokes! That's it! 3 out of 10 stars for the bloody scenes!

Review: An average Shawn Levy film. Even the duo could not save it. There were no great battles, which was disappointing given the mention of X-Men. Despite the great chemistry between Ryan and Hugh, they couldn't save the movie due to its average storyline. Marvel has wasted the potential of both the characters and the actors in this movie. Even the cameos were not as fleshed out as promised by the director in a interview. It seemed like all the cameos were included just for the sake of it, without any real contribution to the film or the storyline. The entire movie felt like mere fan service.Marvel just ruined the Deadpool movies for me.

Review: My experience while watching D&W was seeing a packed audience become restless during any scene that tries to contain story. They continued to be bored at a lot of "jokes" that never landed. It's like everyone waited for the next cameo and a handful of funny parts to show any sort of excitement. Half of the laughing always came from the same five percent of the audience, whereas everyone agreed that seeing the cameos was the bright spots of the mess of a storyline.I didn't hate the movie because, thankfully, there were some fun moments, but they serve to only satisfy you in the moment. Even good parts were underscored with stupidity. Usually this was the case where a funny line or visual gag would happen, but there would be a dumb setup or poor reveal. The Paul Rudd joke was funny, because the line of dialogue, but not the setup. This halfway attempt at comedy permeated all 2 hours. The song selection is all over the place and, even though I personally didn't like many of the songs, they didn't fit with the tone of the movie. Why did they have to ruin good action scenes with terrible songs! At least most everything with Wolverine was entertaining and a few fantastic moments with Hugh Jackman.With villains that are confusingly good, an over complicated yet simple story, scenes that drag on, multiple instances of things not making sense, or characters that aren't needed, and a multitude of other things that I would list as choices I would be ashamed to have written, at the very least we get a better Mad Max movie than Furiosa. The more budget a movie has, the more hype it has, the multitude of writers; you would think it produce something that people would be proud of. I would feel embarrassed to be a part of this movie. I was embarrassed simply watching it unfold. I guess too many cooks can spoil the broth.

Review: I wouldn't normally have gone to see this movie but had a voucher due to expire with no other options, "how bad can it be?" I thought, and the reviews were good. So I settled for "Deadpool and Wolverine" and was pretty soon bored by the inane violence, lame characters and juvenile jokes.If this is the sort of movie that the general population wants to watch then I despair for humanity. The plot made no sense, it seemed they were making it up as they went along and one could hardly engage with (or care about) the characters. The violence was over the top graphic, unnecessarily so, and the language foul and irrelevant.This movie was supposed to be funny? Maybe a chuckle sparsely placed but the overall sentiment was one of boredom.I should have walked out, but stayed in the vain hope that the experience might improve - it didn't. This movie is absolute trash, do not waste your money or time.The one star given (rather than zero) was for the soundtrack, the movies only redeeming quality.

Review: Massive Deadpool fan. Had such high hopes for this. Wasn't bad. But still disappointing. I like the whole the meta and self-parody aspects of the Deadpool films. But this one felt as if it is making fun of itself in a way that the movie actually warranted. Like it was telling us what is actually wrong with the very film that we are watching. Wonder if that was intentional. If it were, there is actually something very brilliant about that. But a part of me suspects that it was totally unintentional, which had the (unwitting, im guessing) effect of making the the whole film feel trivial. However, the cinematography was first rate, the costumes amazing, and every aspect of the production are what you would expect from a first rate Hollywood summer blockbuster. And that should make it definitely worth a a watch, especially in the theater with an audience. I loved watching how people I was with reacted, laughing with - and in some cases at - the whole story.

Review: Marvel's highly anticipated "Deadpool and Wolverine" is finally here, and as we all know, it comes at a bit of a crossroads for the MCU (and the genre as a whole.) While I've never loved the superhero genre overall, there's plenty of films in the genre that I've been entertained by, and certainly some good characters that make up at least some of the comic-book blockbusters that audiences love. That said, I will admit that I have been largely disillusioned by the genre as a whole after "Endgame" and when things started to progress towards focusing solely on multiverse and cameo-related stuff rather than trying to tell any semblance of a compelling or character-driven story. I enjoyed the first two Deadpool films (and saw them both in theaters when they came out) for the most part, and thought their irreverent, fourth-wall-breaking humor felt relatively fresh at the time by poking fun at superhero movie tropes in fresh ways--so, rest assured, I went in hoping to like this. While there are still some funny moments, the film overall feels very tedious and has everything that I don't really like about this genre and franchise in its current state (as in, focusing on multiverse and cameo-related hijinks with no real stakes/consequential plot/character development.) So for me, this was regrettably a big downgrade from the first two Deadpool films, both of which I would rate a 7 or 7.5/10.The film mostly takes place after "Deadpool 2," and the basic underpinnings of the (very thin) plot is that Deadpool is captured by the Time Variance Authority, and has to save his own "timeline" from deteriorating, which, of course, necessitates working with Wolverine. Even though I wasn't a huge fan of the film, I will most certainly admit that chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman can be quite fun--charming even too--in certain scenes. While many of the jokes don't work, there are at least a few that do. But unfortunately, the film falls victim to the same flaws of many of these other recent Marvel films in that there is not much of a plot, or anything remotely resembling compelling dramatic stakes. Given the "multiverse" nature of the story (and the fact that both of its main characters have regenerative healing powers,) nothing seems at risk or able to effectively generate dramatic tension. Instead, the film revels in fan-service, which of course is not expected. Some people will very much enjoy that, but for those of us who don't have everything memorized about the 2000s X-Men movies, your mileage may vary. The film's action is for the most part bland and forgettable in terms of how it's shot (and often repetitive in terms of how it's depicted and executed,) which may partially be because its director, Shawn Levy, doesn't have much of a track record directing action films.While I didn't like this film as much as the previous two Deadpool movies, I recognize that many viewers will enjoy this film for the exact same reasons (over-reliance on cameos, fan service, multiverse stuff) that I wasn't as keen on it. And guess what: that's completely fine. Film is subjective. I realize that legions of comic book fans will love their experience seeing this film in theaters, and it's good that they will enjoy it. I also realize that Marvel--and possibly much of the entire superhero genre as a whole--is increasingly not to my taste, or at least much less so than many of these films were 5 or 10 years ago. That's okay too. My score, in objective terms, is only a 5/10, and I wouldn't recommend it to people who aren't big Marvel fans, but I think anyone reading this review can determine whether they would want to see this film or not--if they haven't made that decision already.

Review: This is a story about mediocre heroes banished to superhero purgatory, oh the irony of that. It perfectly encapsulates what Marvel has become; a washed-up sellout through and through. It's even regularly alluded to in the script itself, like some sort of Freudian slip; that Disney is digging up the dead body of Wolverine to make more money. As if self-deprecating humour can distract from the facts.The multiverse thing is a corporate wet dream where essentially their beloved superhero IP roster can be mixed and matched like a capsule wardrobe to create any crossover they want to extract as much money as they can through box office footfall. Comedy in a "multiverse" is infinitely easier and more convenient to milk than serious films with real scripts and through-lines, where creative faculties are required to create something new. This is a superhero recycling centre disguised as OG Marvel.Yes, this film did have some funny moments, flashes in the pan past the swill of crude toilet humour and sex jokes. But its plot amounts to a load of filler, and not a lot of killer.

Review: I don't mind turning my brain off for a popcorn blockbuster but I can't really enjoy myself if I'm cringing every 2 minutes. Corny reference after corny reference, it doesn't end. There were multiple occasions where after an already dated pop culture reference disguised as a joke was followed up with a pause for the audience to laugh and you could hear a pin drop in the theater. 2 hours of deadpool making quips and jokes and wolverine playing it straight telling him to knock it off with some action in between. The story beats are so poorly executed and the pacing was all over the place. There were no stakes, no tension and honestly it didn't even feel like there was a main character. I get that you're not suppose to go into these movies with stakes in mind but with the absence of good humor, there was nothing for me here.

Review: Let's have a villain, let's throw in a few old heroes, let's add some action, and there you have it, a Marvel movie. The main villain and the story of defeating him were overly simplistic. We don't enjoy Marvel movies anymore. They are trying to make a movie by holding on to the past. I think Marvel should be run by someone more visionary. I don't know if they write the scripts to artificial intelligence, but it was an extremely simple scenario. The multitude of universes, the intertwining of stories, the reflection of America's political environment on player choices and many other things started to get annoying. I don't think I'll ever go to a Marvel movie again.

Review: I enjoyed the original "Deadpool", probably because it was unexpected, and Ryan Reynolds was suitably snarky in the role. The second one was also pretty good, but not as much fun.This one seemed too forced, with too many callbacks to the earlier movies PLUS the callbacks to all of the X-Men movies. This mishmash of semi-silly comments, followed by gory fight scenes followed by more semi-silly comments and more fight scenes got old after the first couple times through it. Maybe for the younger crowd that are fully invested in the MCU genre this worked, but I actually closed my eyes a couple times. Granted, it was on a Friday night after a somewhat trying day at work, but still...!Two things I did enjoy about it, however.1) The 1980's soundtrack used throughout. Maybe the best soundtrack I'd encountered since "Guardians of the Galaxy".2) Ryan Reynold's off-the-wall reference to his "Proposal" movie with Sandra Bullock. Odd, maybe, that I was the about the only person in the theater that laughed at it. Eh, I enjoyed it.So, would I recommend this movie? Maybe to the under 40 crowd who "grew up" on the MCU movies. Beyond that, I'd hold out for streaming at this point.

Review: I saw another review here, titled, "boring". There's a battle, in the final third of the movie, that partly takes place in a bus, fantastic scene.Wolverine is as grumpy and difficult as ever, but one heck of an ally to Wade.What's wrong with the movie:-The plot is thin, the pacing poor, and, aside from the action scenes, it's a fairly boring movie.It all feels a little familiar, and, if you've seen one of the Marvel TV shows, you'll feel at home - a key plot point, and perhaps 25% of the movie, takes place within its setting.

Review: By Ian Chandler - July 31, 2024Deadpool & Wolverine is the MCU's first R-rated film, as it stars Ryan Reynolds as the iconic loudmouth, Deadpool. Joining him is none other than Wolverine, played by Hugh Jackman once again. Though this team-up feels somewhat forced, it should have provided a fun duo bumbling around in a chaotic, extravaganza superhero movie. Unfortunately, the film wastes the opportunities Marvel desperately wanted for several years. The pacing is breezy, the action is frequent, but it is depleted on genuinely funny jokes.To start positive, the editing is snappy and appropriate for the zany titular character. It is quick, occasionally stylish, and compliments the film's goofy vibe. It is easily the film's best attribute, as everything else is surprisingly dull in a franchise typically insistent on creativity. Whereas Deadpool 2's X-Force sequences were the film's hilarious highlight, Deadpool & Wolverine struggles to have a defining moment, let alone one that causes one to even chuckle. It favors repetitive jokes such as nicknaming Deadpool "Marvel Jesus." If this quip wasn't funny the first time, then it will remain unamusing the next twelve times it is said. All but one of the fourth-wall jokes are not fresh or creative enough to make the audience laugh. Even worse are the movie's weak sexual quips. Vulgar jokes aren't for everyone, yes; but that should not be an excuse for the incredibly lazy, unfunny lines from the characters. They are as creative as naughty jokes from an edgy 14-year-old kid. As a result, much of the humor will only get a laugh from middle-schoolers, a demographic too young for Deadpool & Wolverine.Even though the dialogue could have benefited from a rewrite, perhaps the action will help this threequel shine. There are two sequences that are bursting with morbid inventiveness, those being the opening and the one with a Honda Odyssey. The problem is, there are far more than two total action scenes. The majority of these are a repetition of shootings and stabbings with blood spilling everywhere. These uninteresting events go for far too long and lack the imagination needed in a Deadpool movie. The choreography is hard to compliment or criticize, as the otherwise good editing fails to showcase it. There are frequent cuts and motions that make it occasionally difficult to follow the bombastic conflicts on screen. If one is looking for a fun, R-rated action movie, pick any of the four John Wick films.The plot, unsurprisingly, is another tasteless ingredient in Deadpool & Wolverine. Of course, if one went to see this movie for an engaging narrative, that's on them; Deadpool is iconic for many things, the story is not one of them. It wouldn't be hard to argue that the tale was written in a week; but it is hard to focus on the flawed story because the more important errors found in the latest MCU offering. If the charismatic stars and zany editing were removed, there would be close to nothing able to redeem this frustrating miss of a huge opportunity. The studio did this crossover dirty.Deadpool & Wolverine - 53/100Deadpool & Wolverine has a neat production and mostly appropriate editing, but it fails at humor, ambition, its plot, and a sufficient supply of creativity.

Review: First of all, it was great seeing Hugh and Ryan back on screen as Wolverine and Deadpool. And it was even more awesome to have Wolverine finally in his iconic suit (as shown in the poster and trailer). They really know how to bring the characters to life. But that's about it. Without spoiling the movie, even though it's only a little over 2 hours, it was long and drawn out, and suffered the same problems that most of the recent MCU movies had (using the multiverse storyline for lazy writing, random fan service, and low quality rushed production). Even the Logan director said the same thing. The pointless intro itself unnecessarily took a lot of time. Again without spoiling, as expected there are a number of familiar faces, and it was actually very exciting to see those familiar faces, but it's really disappointing what they did with them. They could have done so much more with them, and they could have used a lot of the random/drawn-out time to do that. I'm not sure why there are so many raving reviews here to be honest? I was actually shocked the theatre was basically half empty right after release. Normally Marvel movies are packed and difficult to get a seat for a while. It also seemed most of the audience didn't enjoy it either except for maybe 2 or 3 people who giggled at everything. I do really hope they eventually end this multiverse storyline, especially now that they have Deadpool and X-Men under the Disney-Marvel umbrella, and start focusing on the core story with the dedicated cast. This movie is more of a standalone movie and doesn't really tie into the bigger story. Honestly, I wouldn't recommend wasting money seeing it in the theatre and instead wait for it to come to Disney+.

Review: I do not know enough about the Deadpool franchise to describe the story overall. I watched this movie thinking it would be a good action movie. It was not, mainly because it lacked a story.The main problem with the movie, Deadpool and Wolverine is that the story does not start until near the end of the movie. In between are these long overdone action sequences with slow moving camera shots that then switch to real time with bodies flying everywhere. It goes on and on until the next joke from Ryan Reynolds, Deadpool. Then another joke about sexuality. Then another joke before another slow-moving long action scene. Then another long action sequence of slow motion camera filming. Then more jokes from Deadpool in another long dialogue sequence. Not only did the action become tired to watch on screen, but the jokes seemed to be forced dialogue trying to keep viewer interest with humor because there was no story to be found.The movie did not keep me interested. There were some jokes which is why I was able to stay awake, but that was it. It was one long movie of action sequences and comedy joke dialogues from Deadpool. I was able to stay awake long enough to get to the end.

Review: It relied too heavily on CGI and endless conversations in one room, failing to develop a captivating storyline.The rushed and uninspiring conclusion left much to be desired. Additionally, the constant call outs to external references only served to further detract from the overall quality of the film.The lack of depth in character development and the reliance on flashy special effects made for a disappointing viewing experience.It felt as though the filmmakers prioritized style over substance, resulting in a lackluster and forgettable film.It fell short of expectations and failed to leave a lasting impression on audiences.It was a waste of time.

Review: This was my first Deadpool movie - and the absolute last! I went to see this because of Wolverine and ended up truly embarrassed that he had to be subjected to such a childish and idiotic co-character.Never will I waste my time nor my money watching anything that has Deadpool in it ever again. I tried to walk out of it, but the person I went with was steady snickering at all of the flamboyant and sarcastic lines of Deadpool. Truth be told, he is a bit childish as well, so it doesn't surprise me that he liked it.I guess if childish is your thing, you'll likely enjoy this movie. Personally, I thought it was beneath the character of Wolverine to co-star in a movie with this poor-excuse of a Superhero!

Review: For starters, I don't love the Deadpool movies but I have enjoyed the first two as I thought they were solid fun superhero movies with some clever moments. Deadpool & Wolverine has some good moments but honestly, compared to the previous movies, the quality has kind of dropped.Deadpool and Wolverine clearly is fan-service which isn't a bad thing because fan-service can create good crowd-pleasers. This movie does carry good chemistry and energy between one another that creates a fun action movie with good uses of thrills and stunt work and solid performances from the entire cast members. It was nice to see Deadpool and Wolverine going head-to-head and teaming together.Unfortunately, this is the kind of fan-service that is pretty rough on it's edges. Because as a whole, i's writing and style is pretty much the same standard superhero movie structure. Filled with typical tropes as the usual and concepts that are a bit messy. Shawn Levy's direction was dull and the camerawork and production, at times feel a bit cheap. Including rough dialogue moments and other characters that are dull and unlikeable to care.On it's humor, compared to its previous movies, the humor didn't work for me as I personally think it has gotten a bit worse with the humor feeling like it's about references rather being creative or people thinking curse words are the best jokes ever. That kind of non-serious humor that thinks breaking the fourth wall, throwing over-used jabs, and tone that thinks it's being clever but it falls flat. Coming from the man who made Free Guy and other trash films, it's not shocker the quality of it's humor and tone has dragged.At the end, I suppose this movie just didn't work for me but for fans, this is a good entertainment.

Review: Multiverse? Again? Seriously?Disney SUKS!I had high hopes for the latest Deadpool movie, but unfortunately, it was a major disappointment. They completely ruined the entire concept that made Deadpool so beloved in the first place.Firstly, the humor felt forced and out of place, lacking the sharp wit and cleverness we've come to expect. The storyline was a mess, filled with plot holes and unnecessary subplots that added nothing to the overall experience.Moreover, the character development was practically non-existent. Deadpool, who was once a complex and engaging character, felt flat and uninspired. The supporting characters were equally disappointing, with none of them leaving a memorable impression.The action sequences, which should have been a highlight, were poorly executed and lacked the excitement and creativity that made the previous movies stand out. It felt like the filmmakers were trying too hard to replicate past successes without understanding what made them work in the first place.Overall, this movie failed to capture the essence of Deadpool and left me feeling let down. It's a shame to see such a beloved franchise take such a downward turn. Save your time and money - this one is not worth it.

Review: I loved Deadpool. Funny, violent, dark, good (for a comic book film) story, bit of jeopardy, kind of sweet, edgy, engaging love story.I even liked Deadpool 2. Funny, still quite dark, okayish story (for a comic book film), no real jeopardy, not much in the way of emotional content, violence a bit OTT.And now this one. Deadpool and wolverine are both fantastic as usual. That's the good stuff.There are some laughs but all feels a bit forced.There is no story to talk about (usual multiverse nonsense which even though this movie is trying to make fun of it, it becomes just is dull as every other marvel movie doing it now).Far too many in jokes, cameos, easter eggs, and knowingly talking to the camera nonsense (probably because there was no plot as such, and they had to pad it out).So many repetitive, slow motion fights. The first one or two it's quite good, by the 14th or 15th is just boring. Why does every sequel think we'll just take what people liked about the original and do more of it until it fills up the entire movie and leaves literally nothing else. That will work, won't it? No.Terrible villains, usual over reliance on digital effects. Has anyone in Hollywood actually seen movies like The Raid to show how actual fight scenes can work and leave you speechless. Actually even the original Blade was pretty good for fight scenes. Here, it really is just a comic book come to life and while that's not always a bad thing, it's just getting a bit dull.The good news is, it's still a little sick (in a good way) still very funny in places and who doesn't love Hugh Jackman as wolverine. It's a shame they couldn't rein it in a bit and make something worthy of the two main characters. And it's not as bad as Thor: Love and thunder 😁🤣 although comes dangerously close for similar reasons (Thor's goats = deadpool's dog....funny once).And please Marvel bin all this multiverse nonsense...it's so so bad. And worse, it's incredibly boring.Of course since this movie is going to make a zillion dollars we will get more and more of this till we all die🤣

Review: I'm surprised of the box office success this film earned in it's first week.I'm sure after the bad mouth of word the movie will flop soon in ticket sales.This was so bad and nothing worked.Sadly we live in an age where anyone who wears a superhero suit makes box office success.The jokes are bad the cgi effects are nothing we never saw before and the performances are average and the story is a joke and most boring.So how many times the world must be saved so that they will stop torture us with new marvel beep films.At least the earlier marvel films were something new in the theaters and a few of them were enjoyable but as years pass by we got bored of the same and the same thing all over again.I can't argue the first deadpool films were kind of a good time but this film is not a real deadpool film and it's another mess up with this idiotic multiverse universe story which destroyed for good marvels' phase IV edition of films.

Review: I didn't like this movie one bit though I loved the Deadpool and X-Men and Wolverine movies.Why? This movie doesn't have any interesting, engaging story.They just pile on more and more Super heroes and more and more Mayhem. But what for?Of course, it's about saving the world, as usual. But never has that been less interesting than here.And after the first fight scene, which made me and everybody in the theater laugh, quite soon I and most people around me didn't laugh anymore.Such a shame.There would have been so many possibilities, but all wasted.Instead you're expected to enjoy mayhem for it's own sake.Boring.No fun.

Review: I've never written a review before, but this movie made me do it. What on earth is this film supposed to be? They're trying to squeeze so many characters in one movie which is devastating and for what? How can anyone sit through 2 hours of this mumbo jumbo? It's by far the silliest movie ever made. I absolutely love Logan-he's one of my all-time favorite characters, but this film is just a confusing mess. The story goes nowhere, the characters don't make any sense, and by the end, you're left scratching your head, thinking, "What did I just watch?" This is, without a doubt, the worst movie I've ever seen. This movie is a collection of flashy heros with no substance, but it adds up to nothing.

Review: I love Deadpool, and Ryan Reynolds seems like a great guy, so I really wanted to love this movie. But I didn't.In my opinion... There was almost no story, the script seemed like it was written by a teenager (and not a very talented one at that), the F word was used in almost every other sentence (taking away any impact or comedy value). The gore had been turned up to 11 for, as far as I could tell, no justifiable reason. Stabbing someone in the junk wasn't funny the first time they did it, so it sure wasnt funny the fourth time.Deadpool has never minded killing people, but I feel the outright and brutal slaughter or people just doing their jobs was a bit out of character. But maybe I'm wrong on that.I'm trying not to give any spoilers, but to be fair I don't think there's much of a plot to spoil, just cameos.I'm not sure how so many people are giving it such high ratings. I honestly wanted to love it. But if it had been any other random 'super' movie, I'd likely have walked out. I only stayed because it was deadpool.I think they probably spent all their time and money getting the cast together, costumes made, digital FX teams together and then thought at the last moment "f"""! We need a script still! ...nah, they'll never notice with all the pew pew bang bang going on!".So to sum up; no real story, way too much swearing and way too much gore for no justifiable reason.But that seems to just be my opinion.

Review: I liked the Deadpool films and the Wolverine films. And I don't find Ryan Reynolds too irritating. However, this film. This film feels like it was conceived and written by an MCU fan, who drank far too much caffeine and eat far too much laxative- and this film was the result.Reynolds just does Reynolds, so the snarky 4th wall stuff is exciting acted and predictable. Hugh Jackman seems, conversely, to take things far too seriously, so the juxtaposition of the two really grates.The ret in f the film is just a mess of ideas and vague storylines. The CGi is decent, but the script, partly because Reynolds eats it, is entirely forgettable. The one decent highlight is Emma Corrin as the baddy, she deserves her own shot at a film.The film was a mildly diverting 2 hours out of the rain.

Review: Nothing in common with the first 2 Deadpools which not only had a logical and catchy storyline but were also hilarious due to clever dark humor.I am a fan of Deadpool and was super excited to see this release.Deadpool vs Wolverine has lots of cliched scenes, poor repetitive lines and more than 70% of unnecessary violent scenes. I get it, the producer had to fill in the time with something. Lots of references about genitalias. It's funny until it's not. I could no longer find the dark humor but the superficial and actually pretty bad jokes. There's a fine line between dark humor and stupidity and Deadpool vs Wolverine could not find it.What I liked? The soundrack, graphics and the first 15 minutes.

Review: Again, Marvel did the thing. An overpowered villain(bald Jean Grey) who kept the protagonists alive although she obliterated everyone but just tossed the two around halfheartedly. When she was fighting with Deadpool and Wolverine the protection of the plot was thicker than Kevin Feige's head who is the responsible for both rise and now demise of the franchise. This kind of villain behaviour did not make sense with Wanda in Doctor Strange 2 and it certainly did not make sense here.Speaking of Doctor Strange, if one can portal between universes with a sling-ring then why the hell Wanda was trying to steal America's powers? I guess this was another dumb writing that we witnessed.Jokes were fine-ish. I loved 55% of them. Rest of them were cringy and not funny at all. And that's all just there. Laughs and Cameos. That's also presenting the fact that the writer only knows how to write comedy films. Not human-centric storytelling with complex character study. The characters who actually working towards personal goals. Yes, it was personal for Deadpool up until the end. Then Marvel had to push their infamous "big cgi fight button" and everything suddenly was about cringy overused "the end of the world" stuff, thus, the film got worsened.Dear, god, Marvel really still baiting on fan-favourite cameos. Those are good to see in the articles/posts in FANDOM WEBSITES/BLOGS. Not in multimillion-dollar projects. Wake the f up.I haven't watched any Marvel thing after Guardians 3 but I think this is THE last Marvel product that I consumed. Perhaps I will catch on the certain films(I highly doubt) once they hit online but I don't think I wanna pay to get disappointed anymore.

Review: To be fair, this movie was probably never going to completely work for me, as I am not a big fan of the other two Deadpool movies. But I went in open-minded, and the trailers they released were good trailers.Unfortunately, Deadpool & Wolverine doubles down on all things that makes me dislike both the MCU and other Deadpool movies. From the MCU, it has throw away, cardboard cutout villains, an awful and jumbled plot, and an absurd and borderline offensive amount of fan service. From the Deadpool films, it has very one-note "Can he say that???" type of humor.This movie pretends to be bold by having Deadpool bravely poke fun at Disney. But the jokes are ultimately very inoffensive to Disney, and obviously corporate approved. It has a scene where they make fun of the multiverse, and yet the whole plot revolves the multiverse, which is a total cop out.The villain is about as simple and boring as they get in the MCU. She's also weirdly overpowered, making me wonder why she didn't just snap her fingers, killing everyone. The plot mechanics are incredibly dull, and it relies way too heavily on fan service. Almost no jokes are told, just references that are lightly humorous. And the references and endless cameos really get old quick. They are there to manipulate viewers into focusing on nostalgia, so we forget that the script is absolutely awful and generic.Deadpool & Wolverine makes me extremely sad that we will no longer get any more films in the original X-Men canon. I now appreciate Logan and even The New Mutants all that much more. Because this really ain't it. RIP X-Men.

Review: The anticipation of having Wolberine and Deadpool in one movie kick started the excitement when the movie started. But it turned out to a big disappointed.This movie is easily the worst I've seen this year, and I watch at least five movies a week. If you enjoy Ryan Reynolds delivering sarcastic, lame attempts at humor in response to every line from Wolverine and the other characters, alongside a weak script and boring action scenes, then this might be your kind of film. Personally, I couldn't stand the blasphemous remark of him calling himself Marvel Jesus. If a movie has to stoop that low to get a reaction, it's a sign that something is seriously wrong.Not worth the HYPE AT ALL. And am a big fan of their previous films.

Review: This high rating shows that taste and appreciation for movie has dropped to a near idiotic level. This movie was hot garbage lol. Hugh Jackman was GREAT - hasn't lost a step but everything else SUCKED except for one GREAT, jaw dropping and totally unexpected cameo that made the movie for me. Ryan was annoying, and not funny at all. The formula was tired, the script was BARE bones thin... I really found this a waste of time. Just a bunch of LOUD, mindless violence. Not one single joke was funny - every joke was a homo-erotic joke and really immature at that. There's more bad than good here. I honestly feel jackman was wasted as was Monica. LAMO why was she even IN this movie - Wade's whole REASON for going on this adventure was ridiculous and that ending is probably the sloppiest writing I've seen in ages. It took 4 GUYS to write this mess?The ONLY thing enjoyable about this movie was the nods to fox's films and other older Marvel properties. I have no use for the MCU even though I've enjoyed some of the films - but I will always have time to rewatch the x-men series and this movie proved WHICH was the 'better' universe, sorry MCU.

Review: Not very often a movie comes across that is so selfabsord that it actually tells you that it is too. Ryan Reynolds succeeds most behind a mask, whether that be the thin veneer of his personality or the depth of the characters he performs.Success has followed him and Hugh Jackmans return for Logan a clever pairing of essentially two immortals, becomes as repetitive as a Ryan Reynolds monologue.After 20min the movie is a long repeat of the same action, the same one liners and the same dead pool of writing.It's no wonder they are promoting this movie everywhere, because any pause to reflect and Marvel at what they've made and they might just realise it's crap.

Review: You take an entire Series of excellent Marvel Universe Films (a Single Iron Man film earns the studio $1B), plus all the decades of "comic books", mash them all together, hose them down, then pass them through a leaf shredder; then write a script from that mess that only "Gen Z" (and maybe a very few 5th-graders) can make sense of; then pass this through movie theaters and call it entertainment? Really? ... NOT!!!!Marvel itself spent the last few years killing off nearly all of the Original Avengers and X-Men because they wanted to be 'stylish' -- and we end up with this tripe!They killed Iron Man. His movies merely earned the Studio billions.They kind-of turned Thor into a fatso with a beer belly, then into a girl.Then they took the Hulk from a raging unstoppable wrecking crew, and turned him into an effeminate combination of The Hulk & Dr. Banner.They killed off Captain America by turning him into an old man. Then all of a sudden Cap passes his Shield to another guy -- as if that's where his power came from!Then they killed off Scarlett Johansen completely to the consternation of every girlwatcher out there. Those guys need to await Gal Godot's next Wonder Woman film!So, the Studios, collectively, take all of their really big-buck earners, and just kill them all off -- really smart idea, there, Studio-Guys! Did you all flunk grade school too?Although, it's a different story if the actors no longer wanted to play those parts. I heard Ms. Johanson say: (after some on-set horseply) "See, this is what it's like working with these guys for 12 years!".But then we're left with films like this? Really? This is all you've got? Studio guys need to all be fired, then have them try to sell peanuts or pencils on the street.I gave the film five stars mostly for Hugh Jackman's performance.
