Review: How this movie was made: @Disney HQ: what cow are we milking today? Deadpool? Ok, ask our Guy in the home for delinquent youth to have them write the screenplay. And they would, and cheaper!Normally there are filler episodes in a series when the money ran out. But why o why make a filler movie? And then spend an insane amount of money to have all actors fight each other. Because it would look silly to have them sit around?Why would an immortal go fight other immortals? Because Pain is Fun? Says who?In Loki there were some good episodes, a few... This movie however recycled some of the most boring parts near the end where they got stuck in the mess they created. In fact Loki was often so bad I left my house in the absence of a movie theatre to walk out of. (I'm back.) Another thingy; it's possible to have the actors protest against the Multiverse madness, but not in a movie that is so uninspired that they need several universe to gather crumbs in, to put a trail to the end credits. Moldy crumbs like an ugly dog, or the stupidest mask in the history of super Heroes? Oh its on purpose?Hugh Jackman should play Dirty Harry, not ruin a Deadpool film. Wolverine please leave the scene.... The whole movie is a mix of watching a VHS of an old birthday party, and a bunch of ten years old kids who just saw king Kong, running around and following suit in behaving like monkeys. And some deranged adults who just saw a slasher movie slashing each other with real knives. Such Fun... No, ultra violence is not funny! No, foul language isn't either. Unless it serves a purpose. When did Disney hire these bloodthirsty scumbags? Why? There are plenty of boring movies everywhere. STOP WRITING BAD SCENARIOS, use books! They are already written, they are great and many and gathering dust.

Review: I am writing to express my dissatisfaction with the recent Marvel movie, which I believe falls far short of the high standards we have come to expect from Marvel Studios. As a long-time fan of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), I feel compelled to share my thoughts on the direction in which the franchise appears to be heading. First and foremost, I must address the issue of the overwhelmingly positive ratings this movie has received. It seems to me that many of these ratings are likely paid promotions rather than genuine audience feedback. In my honest opinion, this movie does not deserve the praise it is getting. A more accurate rating would be one star, reflecting the lackluster quality of the film. The plot was uninspired, the character development was shallow, and the overall experience was disappointing. It is disheartening to see a beloved franchise like Marvel producing content that feels more like a cash grab than a labor of love. Marvel, once known for its captivating storytelling and complex characters, seems to be losing its touch. The latest movie is a far cry from the earlier MCU films that captured the imagination of audiences worldwide. It appears that Marvel is now churning out movies with back-to-back subpar stories, relying heavily on the brand's name rather than delivering quality content. The unique charm and creativity that used to define Marvel movies are becoming increasingly rare, replaced by formulaic plots and predictable narratives. In this particular film, I found the storyline to be weak and unengaging. The characters, once richly developed and multi-dimensional, felt flat and one-dimensional. There was a noticeable lack of effort in the writing, with dialogue that was often clichéd and uninspired. The visual effects, while technically impressive, could not compensate for the lack of a compelling story. As a fan, it is disappointing to see Marvel, a studio that has set such high standards in the past, produce a movie that feels so devoid of creativity and innovation. Furthermore, it seems that Marvel is prioritizing quantity over quality. The rapid release of movies with little regard for storytelling and character development is concerning. This approach not only dilutes the brand but also risks alienating long-time fans who have supported the MCU from the beginning. Marvel's strength has always been its ability to balance epic action with deep, emotional storytelling. Unfortunately, this balance seems to be slipping away in favor of flashy visuals and superficial plots. For those considering watching this movie, I would advise caution. If you have a lot of money and time to spare, you might still find some entertainment value in it. However, for those who appreciate thoughtful storytelling and well-developed characters, this movie may be a disappointment. It is a shame to see Marvel, once a powerhouse of creativity and innovation, resort to such uninspired content. In conclusion, I believe that Marvel needs to take a step back and reevaluate its approach. The studio must return to its roots and focus on delivering compelling stories with well-developed characters. It is not enough to rely on brand recognition and special effects; the heart of Marvel's success has always been its storytelling. As a fan, I hope to see Marvel regain its former glory and continue to produce movies that captivate and inspire audiences around the world. Thank you for taking the time to read my thoughts. I hope that my feedback can contribute to a constructive conversation about the future of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Review: The movie was disappointing and of low quality. It's difficult for me to understand how the demands of the younger generation have shifted so drastically. The film lacked a coherent story, meaningful message, or purpose. It seems to cater to a generation raised on unrealistic expectations, driven by video games, superpowers, and violence.I'm not suggesting that the past was inherently better-every era has its own strengths and weaknesses. However, it's concerning to see how this generation seems disconnected from reality, growing up with diminished values, less education, and a greater tolerance for violence. Perhaps we, as a society, are partly to blame for this shift.I can't help but worry about the future. Will the next generation be even more immersed in violence and fantasy, abandoning education altogether? In a world where books have been replaced by movies, it's crucial that films guide the younger generation toward a better future, rather than simply offering mindless entertainment filled with violence.

Review: What a huge disappointment, with that high rating and 2 good prequels i though this going to be the same or even better, i was very thirsty for a good marvel movie after 5 years of rubbish but only what i saw was a disaster.Lets take it from the beginning, after end game it was so obvious that marvel ended the era and as a consequence they need to rebuild the world they made and it seems they choice multi-verse idea to do that, it is easy, interesting and catchy but my problem with marvel new structure that it is incomprehensible, what are the rules that controls the multiverse? In reality that is the multiverse in first place? Even after loki and all other movies that touched on multiverse, the structure still doesn't seems to be clear, it seems like marvel can do anything, logically or illogically it doesn't matter, because we still have no idea about the new world(new rules), kill that charter than take him back again redo it whatever they want, they even recover characters from 20 years old movies!! Like in some point that is not a twists and shock for audience it just a huge mess, and that is not the only problem with deadpool and wolverine story, it was so obvious that there is no main event it is just stuffing, i want to avoid spoilers so i won't mention anything, by the way the "void" is a complete joke lol.To be honest i enjoyed the first one hours, the comedy part of the movie was good as expected from deadpool but in the end it is an action movie, the movie completely failed to get me attracted to the main story or main plots, at some point i was really fighting sleep.

Review: Did this movie have a deep plot, no. Did it have lots of funny jokes, action and a seemingly fun adventure, yes. This movie was funny. It was fun to see Deadpool on screen with Wolverine. Hugh Jackman is an amazing actor and has done a ton of movies. He is allowed to play a character without much substance, even if it is Wolverine.The only thing I will say critical is that Disney should look at movies like "Men in Black". It's a movie that gets away with being adult toned but also teen friendly. It tells a clear and concise story without all the glitz and glam. I think movies today rely too much on visuals, familiar faces, and how much they cram into a movie in the time allotted (thus neglecting a clear plot). Other than that Deadpool and Wolverine was a good movie. I will watch it again.

Review: Now that I have come to terms with and am less annoyed by Ryan Reynolds' whole Ace-Ventura-Lite-with-abs persona, I was able to enjoy some pretty hilarious dance routines and nicely timed line deliveries, and quite frankly some pretty great visual presentations, my favourite being the villain's robot skull lair.Emma Corrin gives an impressively cold turn as the quite well conceived evil foe.The problem with this film is that you think you're getting a separate entity from the usual MCU, with its endless boring, excessively complicated expositional lore jargon and drawn out dramatic monologues, and tendency to switch between outright slapstick to stark stare into the distance teary misery... So, parts of this film are like a nuclear hit of caffeine, then others are like a tranquilizer dart that could take down an angry lion.

Review: I went to this movie on the basis of some good reviews and the enthusiasm of my Son who I went with. It was mostly a young audience and it seemed to be well received or at least got a number of laughs or chuckles. I didn't want to give it a 'god-awful' 1 or 2 rating as the film had some good actors and was a piece of work to make no doubt.BUT, endless killing, even though 'artistically' staged and part of movie phantasy, was too much for me. I think it desensitizes people to violence. Moreover, the story line was implausible, not that Marvel cares much about that. Also, tiresome, the constant use of the "F" word was tiresome.Lastly, the director and writers didn't seem to know how to end this sorry spectacle. I kept thinking the movie was over and was ready to bolt out of there, but then another scene would get tacked on and then another. My take on this film may reflect my age and the fact that I've seen many great movies in the 70's and beyond. A Samurai film has some intense fights but they are more often integral to a good story and, done well, are amazing to watch.

Review: If this was a glorified 60' TV special, it might 've been something, but as a 200 mill. Movie it's a mediocre (at best) film with no story and one or two good moments, but nowhere near as charming as the previous two entries. At least the previous two had some style, heart and especially the second had some good cinematography, but this is just bad. Honestly, I didn't expect more from director of Free Guy. Only Hugh Jackman brings his A-game and it's just sad to see him dragged into this only to see him in the yellow suit. I guess, if you are a moron who likes to clap in a movie theater this movie is for you. You'll get to clap and say "I know this" a lot.I like fun and chill movies and I don't expect every comic book movie to The Dark Knight or Logan, but I expect it to be at least decent and enjoyable. The opening credits are my favorite part but after that I was mostly bored with a few chuckles here and there. This not a theater experience, this is an "I'll watch it on my phone" experience. If you saw the leaks on the internet then congratulations, that's the "best" the movie has to offer. But, hey, if you love this movie, congratulations! It has already made tons of money and I'm sure the studio won't understand the wrong message and make more of this cheap crap... And people get angry at Scorsese for spitting facts. This truly is Disneyland, in the sense that you'll see many people cosplaying as characters you like but without substance.

Review: If you're wondering what this movie is like, then just imagine it in your head. Think of Deadpool 1 and 2, then close your eyes, imagine a scene that has violence, gore, and taboo humour that would make any 13-year-old boy laugh... then do that for 2 hours straight, and you've got yourself Deadpool & Wolverine. Oh, and cameos... you need cameos. Thank God that Ryan and Hugh have saved a dying Marvel franchise and Disney's integrity through unoriginal scripting, predictable scenes, and more villain foes who seem to experience a drop of roughly 60 IQ in the last fight scene. Well, at least the franchise died on its sword. There's integrity in that.

Review: I must confess a fondness for the first two Deadpool instalments. They were, undeniably, a breath of fresh air in the superhero genre. However, this latest offering is a perplexing departure from the formula.The crux of the issue lies in Deadpool himself. The character, once a complex anti-hero grappling with mortality and loss, has been reduced to a grating caricature. His incessant chatter, while previously endearing, now feels like a relentless assault on the senses. The Wolverine character, too, is a shadow of his former self. His transformation from brooding anti-hero to reluctant sidekick is jarring and unexplained.The plot is a haphazard concoction of tired tropes and forced humour. The villain, Cassandra, is a one-dimensional antagonist whose motivations are as clear as mud. The constant barrage of self-referential jokes and product placements feels more like a desperate attempt to fill screen time than genuine wit. The multiverse concept, once a promising avenue for exploration, is squandered on predictable twists and turns.The film's saving graces are few and far between. The cameos are enjoyable, and the canine companion offers a welcome moment of respite. Yet, these are mere distractions from the film's fundamental flaws. The action sequences, typically a Marvel strong point, are lacklustre and repetitive. The overall tone is jarringly inconsistent, veering wildly between juvenile humour and attempted seriousness.In conclusion, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a disappointing misfire. It squanders the potential of its beloved characters, offering little in the way of compelling narrative or character development. The film's reliance on cheap laughs and forced cameos is a disservice to the franchise. It's a film that promises much but delivers little, leaving one to wonder what might have been.

Review: This review comes from someone who is admittedly not a religious follower of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Still, I decided to watch this film because I knew Deadpool was the quirky anti-hero, and that Hugh Jackman did a good Wolverine. I wasn't expecting much going into this movie, but even so I was disapointed.First of all I just did not not connect with any of the characters. All of Deadpool's friends seem to harken back to previous installments that I did not watch.It felt like the two protagonists nothing at steak either. Sure the their home universe was being unraveled or whatever, but because there was a multiverse, they could just go to a new one.Deadpool is invincible and Wolverine is regenerative. They had some clashes with eachother, but it was always obvious that they would come out OK.The story was a mess. It just felt all over the place. I think the multiverse setting is really getting tired in these Marvel movies (and Deadpool even jokes about it in this movie too). After Deadpool found a cooperative version of Wolverine, I didn't really understand why he had to go to the void and team of with some of the superhero has-beens.And even the actions scenes, which one would expect to be bombastic in a superhero movie, felt a bit uninspired. There were a few too many instances of impaling or otherwise injuring somebody's genitals for it to remain funny for me. On the topic of the movie's humour, I thought it was cringey. I get that the writers are trying to portray Deadpool as an edgy character with his explicit humour, but it wore thin on me. With every new quip about cocaine or homosexual acts, they became less shocking.Overall I didn't think this movie had any redeeming qualities. Even adamantium Wolverine seemed weak and cripled by alcohol addiction. The overreliance on cameos in this movie had me feeling completely lost at times. I would not recommend this movie to anyone.

Review: For those who consider themselves responsible adults and decent parents:I made a mistake of taking two teenager Marvel fans to see this movie. I heard it was very successful at the box office. I am not an MCU expert by any means. With my level of Marvel expertise, I can say that the first Iron Man with Robert Downey Jr. And Gwyneth Paltrow was a nice movie.This movie, on the other hand, was not just bad. It was shockingly bad. No character development. No plot development. What you get is the endless and pointless in-jokes for the sake of filling up time, lots of F-Bombs and blood and gore that doesn't serve any purpose.An hour into the movie, I realized that nothing was happening in terms of the plot. I would have left the movie theater if it weren't for the boys watching.Then I saw these fighting scenes between the Wolverine and Deadpool and the one with many Deadpools and I thought that this movie is celebrating blood and gore for no reason. There is violence for the sake of violence that doesn't serve any particular purpose of the genre.As I watched these drawn-out scenes, I paid attention to the public reaction in the movie theater. While some claim that this was humor, you wouldn't hear anybody laughing during those scenes.This movie is an example of what's wrong with our culture in the recent years. We give movies R rating for the curse words and glorify violence. There are movies that tell a compelling story where violence is part of it. This one - it's a celebration of violence for no good reason. If you took the blood and gore away and cut the movie down in length by 50-75%, you would still walk away with the same essential understanding of a dumbed-down overly simplistic plot.I asked the boys what they liked about the movie when the ordeal was over. They knew about Marvel movies a lot more than I did. They referred to the in-jokes. So, really, are you prepared to sit for 2 hours watching a movie where nothing is happening in terms of plot twists and just listen to the in-jokes?Please give me back the 2 hours of my life.I am deeply disappointed that this tasteless parody of a film could be so successful at the box office. If this is the epitome of all the comic-book character movie-making, if this is where the evolution has taken us, then it's a really sad world we live in.Remember the movie called Idiocracy? Well, in some ways, we are past that level of hopelessness.

Review: Hugh Jackman just ruined his Wolverine legacy all because Reynold's ego needed to ride on an actual actor's laurels.A bunch of characters who just regenerate when they get hurt equals no suspense or concern for anyone -- you might as well just play a video game.I would give Reynolds kudos for recycling if it pertained to refuse and not the jokes in this film -- but it does champion the phrase 'there is nothing new under the sun'.In summation, this film was Reynolds just mugging for the camera and silently but very obviously shouting, look at me! Review: After watching this, I don't think this movie has what it takes to save the MCU. It was actually surprisingly disappointing, and this is coming from someone who actually liked Deadpool 1 and 2, with 1 being the best to me.The movie lacks good pacing. I constantly got bored because the movie was all over the place. I kept wanting to look at my phone. This movie seems to care more about fanservice and cameos rather than telling an actual good cohesive narrative. As a result, this movie lacks the heart of Deadpool 1 and 2, especially 1. Deadpool 1 narrative was actually surprisingly good and well paced, and it actually knew how to be serious and emotional when it needed to be serious and emotional. I lowkey got a little choked up from the rain scene where Deadpool was hesitant to show his new face to his girlfriend for the first time but couldn't do it. But as for Deadpool and Wolverine? Just too much cringe jokes and bad chaotic pacing for me to take any the small "serious" scenes serious. This barely feels like an actual movie to me, feels like a bunch of skits loosely put together for a movie. Maybe I'm old-school, but extreme fanservice, constant nods, and cameos were not enough to please me. I need an actual well-structured story with good pacing.So does the comedy itself enough to make up for the lack of story and pacing? Not really! The comedy fell flat for me for the most part. Deadpool 1 and 2 were much funnier. Sorry, but I found most the jokes just cringe or corny. My theatre was mostly silent. There was a few actual funny moments, but it wasn't nearly enough overall.The action was just okay! There was no real stand-out fight scenes. The action was EXTREMELY CGI heavy and just didn't look that great. Deadpool 1 looked SO MUCH BETTER! Deadpool 1 had shocking low CGI for a modern superhero movie now that I think about it, and it looked amazing.I really wanted to like this movie but sorry I gotta be honest. I highly doubt this is quality enough to save the MCU, it's one of those movies everyone will forget in a month or so. This movie NEEDED A LOT of work! I should've known, since third movies are very rarely good. I really think it's time to drop this tired multi-verse nonsense.Deadpool OG was like a surprisingly good romantic comedy disguised as a superhero action movie. Deadpool 2 was just classic action Deadpool. Deadpool 3 was just fanservice above everything.My ratings for all Deadpool moviesDeadpool- 9/10 Deadpool 2- 8/10 Deadpool 3- 4/10.

Review: I loved all the actors, and their performances were excellent as expected. Plus the show had some really great one liners! Like one in the beginning when Deadpool said there are 206 bones in the human body, 207 when watching Polly Ann." It was funny but the audience expects more. As for profanity some was o.k. And appropriate for the situation, but most seemed gratuitous and almost like filler. However, all this aside the whole move seemed like an " exercise in ADHD cinema". Nope, I'm done with anything Marvel. The franchise has evolved into an effort to rehash old characters with unnecessary dialogue, swearing, ridiculous storylines to grab a few dollars from the ADHD crowd.

Review: I love the Deadpool and X Men movies and was really looking forward to this, but I was disappointed. Just far too many gags. Sometimes less is more. The Merc with the mouth's gags in the Deadpool movies hit the spot, but Logan is a serious, dark, angry and moody character and comedy and gags don't suit a movie with Wolverine. There are a stack or cameos with a few that really surprised me. Cassandra Nova is a great protaganist, but it was all a bit too much Mad Maxy for me. I am sure many purists will like the homages paid and I am sure it will sail past a billion dollars, but I can't help thinking it was a missed opportunity. Both the stars play with gusto and it's great to see Jackman back doing what he does best, but it doesn't save the movie for me and I'm gutted about it.

Review: What's with all these multiverse stories? As soon as they resort to multiple universes it no longer feels like anything matters. Nothing is final.When two immortal characters fight over nothing when they can't be hurt. It means nothing. And repeating it certainly doesn't help.The acting was good, and I really enjoyed seeing Wolverine again, but the story was lame.I'm not sure if it was just in my theatre, but the volume range was way too high. The dialog was typical movie volume, but as soon as a song played it literally was twice as loud. Ear splitting. I could see about a third of the audience cover their ears.

Review: Deadpool and wolverine together looked like a forced mashup, the story line was weak and the movie had too many characters to do justice to them. This movie needed a good trimming, but i guess there wont be enough left to sell it in theatres then.Deadpools' lines were great as always, they were really well thought out and funny.Wolverine wasn't given enough space to do anything, it projects a forced undertone.MCU really need a visionary leader to trim it's work, it has the good stuff but the mixed stuff leaves a bad taste in mouth.This was the first MCU movie in which i didn't stayed for the post credit scene.Stan Lee's work is being missed.

Review: I LOVED the first Deadpool movie and although the second movie wasn't quite as good as the first it was a definitely decent sequel, so I was really excited to watch this one. Sadly it was a massive let down. The movie without giving away any storyline (well to be fair, there isn't much of a storyline anyway), is really just a couple of hours of cheap cameos and jokes about movies. There are a few funny moments but it overall just didn't have the same originality as the first two. I was bored and yawning before the halfway mark which says a lot. It is such a shame as it had potential but I wouldn't recommend.

Review: Why all the gay sex humor? Especially since that population is so very small in the real world. I understand my triggers very well and the propagandized programming directed towards the unwitting m-asses in this movie was pretty cringe. I'm a single mother raising an emotionally and spiritually STRONG man that knows thy self and SELF. Anyways, I'm not a fan of the Marvel movies. True art has higher dimensions of meaning like HBO's West World Series, Free Guy, the Matrix, the Leftovers... There was zero dimension of higher meaning in Deadpool & Wolverine.

Review: In Marvel's world without consequences and a plethora of superheroes who die or live by the directors whim it was not surprising that wolverine will be back in some form despite his convincing death in Logan. This is exactly the reason why the audience gets superhero fatigue because this is world where your actions have no consequence and people can be brought back to life because the prepubescent western audience shed a tear for their much beloved hero. Ryan as deadpool is sublime as always and sometime you wonder if it is Ryan or deadpool behind the mask and Logan looks and acts the part but the problem lies in the story which is just another pathetic cash grab on a largely prepubescent minded audience. The jokes work but the story plods along and there is little to look forward to except when these two cool actors say their lines. Not recommended and the tedious story will make you want to leave but hey you paid for the ticket so you would rather suffer through the mind numbing storyline. No no and no. Marvel should stop bringing superheroes back to life just for a cash grab!

Review: I love Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, and I love the other two Deadpool movies a lot. I was so looking forward to this movie. For me it was impossible to be interested in the plot of the movie because there were too many 4th wall breaks, and it was too foolish (like floating skull Deadpool.)They lost what made the other Deadpool movies so great. Almost everything Deadpool said was a 4th wall break. It's like he isn't even in the movie, so you aren't invested in anything he does. The plot that is there is so weak that it seems like an afterthought. Worth a watch for the few good scenes in it, but don't go expecting a real movie/plot.

Review: I feel like I'm in the minority here, but I have to admit that I didn't like the film.If "Logan" was a gala farewell, "Deadpool and Wolverine" would be the post-credits party that no one asked for. You know that moment when you're already in your pajamas, ready to go to bed, but everyone decides that the night isn't over yet? Well, that's what happened to our favorite wolverine. "Logan" gave us an epic conclusion, where we saw our hero take his last breath and the surviving mutants finally escape to freedom. A dignified, emotional and final farewell.Then, out of nowhere, they decided to bring back Wolverine, like that friend who comes back from an exchange trip with a suitcase full of useless trinkets. No need, guys, really. And to make matters worse, these Time Guardians - who are actually more annoying than that bald villan - stayed there, interfering in everything, trying to keep the timeline in place, trying to resurrect what was already dead and done. Their attempt to keep the universe alive felt like trying to inflate a balloon that's already popped-unnecessary and doomed to fail. It's kind of ridiculous, honestly. Result? The film experience went down the drain. Who wants to see Wolverine deal with temporal bureaucracy? Tell me! It's almost as if they took the perfect ending of "Logan" and decided to edit it, like that uncle who always thinks he can improve his grandmother's recipe and only manages to ruin the dish.The film's story was weak overall. Weak villan as well.Anyways, i am just going to delete this from my mind.

Review: The movie seems like a movie that just needed to be made in order to bring Marvel back on track after Endgame. But the result is disappointing. Deadpool was finer on his own and perhaps better off with another movie including him properly in the MCU. This movie takes excuse on the multiverse and creates a mixup of whatever, whenever, wherever. As long as we team up Deadpool with Wolverine to make some money. Lacks a meaningful plot (Deadpool-wise). Constantly shoring pun's about MCU Disney Fox etc. Bringing forgotten characters back to life for no reason at all. What's the point? The movie shows the desperation that Marvel has fallen into after climaxing with Endgame. Better leave Deadpool alone.

Review: The storyline was so uninspired that my boyfriend, a die-hard Deadpool fan, fell asleep through 80% of the film. Despite the attempt at humor, the jokes were predictable and failed to deliver any real laughs. This movie stands out as one of the worst superhero films I've ever encountered, making it a regrettable use of 2 hours and 27 minutes, not to mention the $30 ticket price. The high IMDb ratings are baffling and make me question whether they reflect genuine quality or are skewed by fan enthusiasm. As a dedicated X-Men fan, it's deeply disappointing to see such a beloved franchise return to the big screen in such a lackluster and underwhelming fashion. If you're expecting a film that honors the legacy of the X-Men or delivers a compelling superhero experience, I'd strongly advise tempering your expectations.

Review: Good old Walt Disney would not survive if he were around today. He built Disney and the Disney name to have value when it comes to the family. In 1984 when Disney launched Touchstone Pictures to release the Tom Hanks film Splash, they didn't want to release it under the Disney heading because it had nudity and some foul language. After that there were a string of R rated films. Sure Deadpool is an R rated character that did well under Fox, but would Walt approve of this film, who knows. Now don't get me wrong, I already knew what this was all about as I had seen the first two films as well. I honestly thought they were okay, and I knew what this was going to be too. But when I see children in the audience, because it's Marvel, and I don't see any care for what we used to call morales, it makes me sad. And yes that is where I put poor Walt, because the Morales of his studio has went down too. If you enjoy the film that's fine, everyone has an opinion, this just happened to be mine.

Review: The plot is thin, extremely constructed, artificial and unnecessarily confusing and pointless.Multiverse here, timelines there, a universe is slowly dying because Logan died (?), so a crazy guy wants to destroy this universe quickly and painlessly with a machine like Thanos, so they bring Wolverine from another Earth to prevent that, then a crazy chick comes along who also wants to destroy the universe. The writers were crazy there.Extremely much blabla, 99% of the jokes refer to other films in the Marvel/Avengers/X-Men universe or take aim at Fox/Disney.The gags are exclusively for insiders, and at the same time at a fifth-grader level. I couldn't laugh at them.After a short time it becomes brutally exhausting.There isn't even that much action.The action that is there is a bit bloody, a bit of splatter, but overall completely unspectacular and boring.By far the worst Deadpool part, and Wolverine anyway. Deadpool has now arrived where the others have already arrived: in the Marvel uniform.A shame.

Review: You can usually tell when a superhero movie is going to be garbage by the creative team, the studio, the trailer, etc. I was primed and ready for this one a month ago. But after seeing it, I wish Jackman would've stayed retired.There is nothing in this movie other than the cameos and a yellow Wolverine costume. I went in expecting a real movie, so maybe that's on me. The first two Deadpool movies were irreverent and silly, but they weren't soulless. This movie is soulless. There is no story, there is no heart. The trailers played literally 99% of the 'character-introspection' that exists in the movie.If you're curious going in as to what's eating at Wolverine from the trailers, rest assured you will be disappointed. It's nothing other than run-of-the-mill lip service used to distract a bad guy. What's the Vanessa-hook for Wade this time around? There's about 10 seconds of screentime devoted to that, and, yes, it is that poorly thought-out and pointless.I've avoided most of the worst superhero movies in theaters. I did see Batman Forever in the movies as a kid, I saw X-Men Origins: Wolverine, and I saw Green Lantern. This movie is on that level. It's funnier, but it's that caliber of filmmaking. The action scenes aren't even that good, which is weird.Let me reiterate something...this is a 2-hr Easter Egg, it is not a movie. If you want to watch a movie, watch something else. If you like watching Mystery Science Theater 3000-level spoofs/meta-commentary, you'd honestly be better off watching that. If the thought of "Comic Book Shop Fanboy Talk: The Movie" gets your pants tight, you're in luck. That is all this movie is.

Review: Deadpool and Wolverine, an anticipated mash-up of two beloved Marvel characters, has proven to be a colossal disappointment. From start to finish, this movie is a painfully drawn-out exercise in futility that leaves audiences yearning for their lost time.Firstly, let's address the plot - or the glaring lack thereof. The narrative is a chaotic jumble, an incoherent mess that fails to provide any semblance of direction or purpose. It felt as if the writers simply threw together random scenes, hoping the sheer presence of the titular characters would suffice. Spoiler alert: it doesn't.The humor, which should have been a saving grace given Deadpool's reputation, falls disastrously flat. The jokes are stale and forced, lacking the sharp wit and cleverness that made Deadpool's previous outings enjoyable. Instead of laughing, I found myself cringing at the awkward attempts at humor that consistently missed their mark.The film's pacing is another major flaw. It drags endlessly, turning what should have been an action-packed, engaging experience into a tedious slog. Scenes linger unnecessarily, stretching out moments that add nothing to the story - if you can even call it that.To say I want my time back is an understatement. Deadpool and Wolverine is a prime example of wasted potential. With two iconic characters at their disposal, the filmmakers somehow managed to deliver a forgettable, lackluster experience that fails on almost every level. Save yourself the agony and skip this train wreck. Your time is far too precious to waste on such a disastrous attempt at filmmaking.

Review: That about sums up the sheer manic trip of this movie. While Deadpool 1 is the story of, "am I good enough to be a husband" and 2, "am I good enough to be a dad", 3 asks "am I good enough to be an Avenger."Judging by the quality drop, yes. I write quality drop because the sets are generic, the fights are obviously prerecorded without a script and boring to watch, and the plot is...people journeying out of a computer generated zone...This seems to be the trend of Marvel Disney: green screens, exposition dumps, disconnected fight scene, then rinse and repeat until enough frames are shot to equal a movie. The jokes are "meh" and it could be because we've seen this two times before but it was mostly because there wasn't much going on to make into something funny.These recent Marvel films suffer from the inability to keep a story flowing. They lack rhythm. Sure, someone plugs plot details into a plot generator and out pops this mess.With that said, Hugh and Ryan do a fantastic job acting. The best parts of this film are the love letter to Fox, and what they contributed to the franchise. Sure it wasn't always the greatest, but a lot of people did put hard work into them.We had to learn what NOT to do somewhere, and it appears Disney has yet to learn NOT to substitute the flow of a plot and story, for the convenience of Corporate Systems of governance.It kind of sucks, but at least Deadpool 2 had the best character to ever grace Mutant Comic movies; that is Domino.

Review: This movie was like a rollercoaster, but without the tracks. It just kind of...went. You know? Deadpool and Wolverine together, that should be gold, right? But this thing felt like they tossed 'em in a blender with a bunch of random stuff and hit puree. There's no real story, just a bunch of scenes stapled together with hope. I mean, Deadpool's funny and Wolverine is cool, but they just felt like two dudes hanging out, cracking jokes with no real reason to be there. It's like they replaced a script with a wish list of cameos. Don't get me wrong, seeing (insert random cameo) was a kick, but it didn't make up for the fact that I had no idea what was going on. Basically, it was like watching a really expensive, overproduced home video. Lots of flashy stuff, but no real heart or soul.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a highly anticipated crossover that ultimately fails to deliver on its promise. The film attempts to combine the irreverent humor of Deadpool with the gritty intensity of Wolverine, but the result is a disjointed mess that falls short of both characters' previous outings.The plot of "Deadpool & Wolverine" is one of its biggest weaknesses. It feels hastily thrown together, lacking the coherence and engaging storyline that fans have come to expect from both franchises. The narrative jumps from one contrived scenario to another, with little regard for character development or logical progression. This lack of a solid plot foundation makes it difficult for viewers to become invested in the story or care about the characters' fates.The humor, a defining feature of Deadpool's character, is another area where the film falters. While the previous Deadpool movies were celebrated for their sharp wit and clever meta-commentary, "Deadpool & Wolverine" relies heavily on silly, lowbrow jokes that often fall flat. The humor feels forced and out of place, detracting from the overall tone of the movie. Instead of the clever, self-aware comedy that fans love, we get an overabundance of juvenile gags that wear thin quickly.In comparison to the previous films, "Deadpool & Wolverine" lacks the polish and attention to detail that made its predecessors stand out. The character interactions, which should have been a highlight given the strong personalities of both Deadpool and Wolverine, are awkward and uninspired. The film fails to capitalize on the potential for witty banter and meaningful exchanges between the two iconic characters, leaving viewers disappointed.The action sequences, while visually impressive at times, do little to salvage the film. They often feel like a series of disconnected set pieces rather than an integral part of the story. The lack of a compelling plot and meaningful character arcs makes it hard to care about the outcome of these battles, reducing their impact.Overall, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a missed opportunity. It struggles with a weak plot, relies on humor that doesn't hit the mark, and falls short of the standards set by the previous films. Fans of Deadpool and Wolverine may find moments of enjoyment, but as a whole, the film fails to live up to its potential.

Review: Although it's not the only problem with this movie, the double combo punch of time travel and multiverse nonsense destroyed my interest in this movie and Marvel in general. Time travel has been overused for years. Yes, some stories were interesting but it is a fantasy which has become more of a crutch. And we now have the multiverse thing added in. It was fun for a while with sliders but, like time travel, it's become a cheap trick. The MCU now uses both time travel and multiverse elements is a very messy way.So I haven't been that interested in DP2 due to the time travel aspect. And DP&W, along with Marvel in general, with the combination of time travel and multiverses has become nonsensical. There wasn't much else of interest in DP&W either. I am OK with gore when it fits in the plot. But there is so much in this movie which was clearly there just for spectacle. And most of the dialog and jokes were not interesting nor funny.In the end, this movie was actually depressing. I could have done or watched something which was actually interesting or fun. Instead, I forced myself to finish this piece of crap. I haven't found the MCU interesting since Infinity War. I am done with the MCU.

Review: After each Deapool movie, I wind up thinking "Where can they go from here?" There's something about the formula with this character (aka Ryan Reynolds breaking the fourth wall while making vulgar jokes and grotesquely killing people) that guarantees diminishing returns. Every time Wade Wilson shows up, the stakes feel lower and I care a little less. The story almost seems beside the point now; everybody is too busy making jokes and explaining plotlines to tell a real story. That said, I did laugh a bunch. If you tell enough jokes, some of them are bound to land. It is basically Spider-man: No Way Home but with dick jokes and exploding heads. But for all our wondering about what would happen when the MCU and Fox merged, the answer seems to be that you get the best and worst of both. And that means we're still stuck with multiverse movies that spend all their time explaining things and then undoing the things they just explained. Plus, look at this cameo from someone who used to be in our stories! Hugh Jackman takes it seriously and the suit looks great, but that alone doesn't justify a two hour runtime even if you make sarcastic quips about the runtime throughout the movie.

Review: Deadpool & Wolverine (2024) promised to be an explosive addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), uniting two of Marvel's most beloved and notorious anti-heroes. However, despite the high expectations and tantalizing elements, the movie fell short in several critical areas, leaving fans with mixed feelings.Plot OverviewThe central plot revolves around Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) and Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) teaming up to save Deadpool's universe from being obliterated by a formidable new villain, Mr. Paradox, and his devastating weapon, the Time Ripper. Mr. Paradox is on a mission to "snip off" dying universes, and Deadpool's universe is next on his list. The story had the potential to be a gripping tale of heroism and sacrifice, but ultimately, the execution lacked the necessary impact.Main Characters and PerformancesVillains and AntagonistsSupporting Characters and CameosThe movie features a slew of cameos from notable Marvel characters, including Elektra, Gambit, Blade, X-23, and Johnny Storm. While these appearances were meant to excite fans, they felt more like superficial additions rather than integral parts of the story. Each cameo was brief and lacked meaningful interaction with the main plot, which could have added layers to the narrative.Action and HumorThe movie excels in delivering high-octane action sequences and humor. The banter between Deadpool and Wolverine provides many laughs, staying true to Deadpool's unique style. The fight scenes are well-choreographed, showcasing the characters' abilities and teamwork. However, these elements alone were not enough to carry the movie.Plot Execution and StorytellingThe film's main storyline - the mission to save Deadpool's universe - promised a significant impact on the MCU. Yet, the resolution of the plot felt anticlimactic. Despite their efforts, Deadpool and Wolverine's actions resulted in minimal change, with only one universe being saved and no substantial alterations to the overarching MCU narrative. This lack of significant consequence undermines the movie's stakes, leaving viewers with a sense of missed opportunity.Deadpool & Wolverine (2024) is a film that delivers on humor and action but falls short in storytelling and character development. The inclusion of numerous cameos and nostalgic elements like Wolverine's yellow suit provides momentary excitement but fails to contribute meaningfully to the plot. The film's central mission to save Deadpool's universe lacks the depth and impact needed to feel consequential within the larger MCU. As a result, fans are left with a movie that, while entertaining in parts, ultimately does not fulfill its potential to "save the MCU."While Deadpool's humor and Wolverine's nostalgia hit the right notes, the movie needed more substantial plot developments and deeper character explorations to truly resonate with audiences.

Review: The first two deadpool movies were stand-alone fun and hijinx. This was sold as being the same but in fact was an MCU movie with all the requirement you be a Lore expert in thirty odd movies and months worth of average to mid TV series.It's so concerned with being a metatextual goodbye to films we've forgotten about that it forgot to be a film. To be clear, I'm the kind of Nerd who laughed at Liefield's Shoes. I'm that dork they make the references for. But the entire film is references, baskets of Easter Eggs being poured over you until you're numb.I didn't want another MCU movie.MCU movies are work these days. Exhausting work that even nerds like me feelime a chore.I stopped reading the comics owing to the need to know decades of convoluted backstory.I lost interest in the MCU after Endgame Part 1 because I realised there were never going to be stakes again. And now it also need a decade of convoluted backstory to understand.I went into Deadpool 3 hoping for a refreshing stand-alone super hero story that capped the trilogy. Instead I got another exhausting franchise meta narrative that killed its own characters to shove itself into the MCU mold.Rant over, go see the next episode in Marvel, Tony Stark is Doctor Doom in a bad suit now and we're all supposed to care.

Review: With the incredible potential of combining two iconic MARVEL characters, played by the great Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, one would expect an exceptional movie.Unfortunately, despite the star power, the film falls short. The storytelling was lackluster, and the writing failed to deliver the punch that i hoped for (infinity war style) . The overuse of the multiverse concept struck again, which,made the plot feel convoluted and overdone. To top it off, the ending was so uninspired that it felt like a twist you'd expect from a budget-bin DVD. It's a real disappointment considering the talent involved.A missed opportunity, to proporly introducing the X-men to the MCU to say the least.....

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" had the potential to be a blockbuster, bringing together two of the most beloved and iconic characters from the Marvel Universe. However, the film feels like a missed opportunity, coming across as disconnected and poorly written. While there are moments that may appeal to hardcore fans, the movie, on the whole, struggles to find its footing, leaving casual viewers feeling unsatisfied.Wolverine, on the other hand, is portrayed in a way that feels disconnected from the character's previous iterations. The brooding, conflicted hero is replaced by a version of Wolverine that feels more like a supporting character than a co-lead. The dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine, which could have been a highlight of the film, lacks the chemistry and depth needed to make their interactions meaningful. Instead, their relationship feels superficial, with the film relying on cheap thrills and action sequences rather than meaningful character development.Dialogue and HumorOne of the most disappointing aspects of "Deadpool and Wolverine" is the dialogue. The film is riddled with cheap, one-liner jokes that lack the cleverness and wit that fans have come to expect from Deadpool. The humor often feels forced, as if the writers were trying too hard to replicate the success of the previous Deadpool films without truly understanding what made those films work.Wolverine's dialogue, too, suffers from a lack of substance. His character is known for his terse, no-nonsense approach, but in this film, his lines are often reduced to generic tough-guy clichés. The dialogue fails to capture the essence of who these characters are, making their interactions feel hollow and unengaging.Direction and PacingThe direction of "Deadpool and Wolverine" contributes to the overall sense of disconnection in the film. The pacing is uneven, with scenes that drag on too long interspersed with abrupt action sequences that feel out of place. The film struggles to find a rhythm, leaving viewers unsure of what tone it is trying to achieve. Is it a dark, gritty superhero drama or a lighthearted, comedic romp? The film never seems to make up its mind, resulting in a jarring viewing experience.Catering to Hardcore FansWhile "Deadpool and Wolverine" may not work for the average moviegoer, it does have moments that will likely appeal to hardcore fans. The film is peppered with Easter eggs, references, and callbacks to the comics that only the most dedicated fans will appreciate. However, even these moments feel like a crutch, as if the film is leaning on fan service to compensate for its lack of substance. For those who are deeply invested in the Marvel Universe, these nods to the source material may provide some enjoyment, but for others, they do little to enhance the overall experience.ConclusionIn conclusion, "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a film that falls short of its potential. The disjointed plot, lackluster character development, and cheap dialogue make it a disappointing addition to the Marvel franchise. While hardcore fans may find some enjoyment in the film's references and Easter eggs, casual viewers are likely to walk away feeling underwhelmed. This movie is a testament to the fact that even with beloved characters, a film needs a strong story, well-crafted dialogue, and thoughtful direction to truly succeed.

Review: "Deadpool and Wolverine" attempts to blend the irreverent charm of Deadpool with the brooding intensity of Wolverine, but ultimately falls flat with its reliance on cheap action and humor. While the idea of pairing these iconic characters promises an exciting ride, the execution leaves much to be desired.One of the most glaring issues is the film's CGI. Despite the high stakes and explosive action scenes, the special effects feel disappointingly low-budget. From poorly rendered explosions to unconvincing character animations, the visual spectacle is marred by a sense of cheapness that detracts from the immersion. The scenes that should have been awe-inspiring instead come off as lackluster, failing to live up to the standards set by previous superhero films.The gore, a staple in both characters' narratives, is equally uninspired and tasteless. Rather than adding to the intensity or emotional weight of the story, it feels gratuitous and poorly executed.The humor, which is supposed to be one of Deadpool's strong suits, falls into a similar trap. The film is saturated with cheap jokes, with about 90% relying on sexual innuendos and crass humor. While Deadpool is known for his irreverence, the over-reliance on this type of comedy quickly grows tiresome. Instead of clever wit or genuinely funny moments, viewers are bombarded with lowbrow humor that fails to elicit more than a few chuckles.In summary, "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a disappointing entry in the superhero genre. With its cheap CGI, uninspired gore, and overwhelmingly sexual humor, the film struggles to find a balance between action and comedy, leaving fans longing for the days when these characters were handled with more care and creativity.

Especially after bringing on Jackman, who has done a lot of great work.There is no storyline worth explained whatsoever, it is all made up to get a far out excuse to bring on cameos. Sure, we get a few laughs on the way, but the pace is destroyed by an excessive amount of too long, boring fights in slowmotion. Yes, we know you can't die, so stabbing each other is about as interesting as seeing two brothers hit each other on the shoulder.Sorry, I normally like Renolds and Wolverine is a favoruite character of mine, but Marvel should have stopped after Endgame..

Review: I see lots of people giving this a 10.They have to be industry people trying to prop up the score.This was not a 10.It's probably more a 1 but I've given it a generous 2 because there were a few laughs .Other than the few laughs there was little else .When I heard they were bringing Wolverine into the franchise I really hoped for something special .What we got was a mess .No story to speak of .Far too many characters and cameos .The script could have been written by schoolchildren.Actually schoolchildren probably would have done a better job.The fact that this movie will do well at the box office Means they'll do another one using the same formula.And on and on it will go until people actually call this stuff out for what it is . Crap!I really enjoyed the first Deadpool movie .The second one was ok, not as good as the first but they tried .This one just beggars belief .What were they thinking ?Just Bad Bad Bad !

Review: I enjoyed Deadpool 1 and 2, but like with many Hollywood sequels, the appeal seems to diminish over time. Deadpool 3 feels more like an MCU movie with Deadpool as the main narrator. I found the random introduction of what I think are MCU characters both confusing and pointless. In my opinion, the franchise should have ended after Deadpool 2. As a person that is not educated on the comic book culture, I was lost. I just hope they won't produce more content that could dilute the quality of the first two movies. If you're a fan of modern comics, you'll probably enjoy the movie, but if not, it might not be worth the money.

Review: Let me preface this my saying I have never seen a Disney Marvel movie that I enjoyed.I didn't mind the first 2 Deadpool movies, and I had low expectations for this one knowing that this one, unlike the other two, would be made by Disney.I did find the jokes funny, but the lack of plot and character development had be bored. Meanwhile the people sitting next to me seemed to be having the time of their life, so maybe this movie just wasn't for me.I found the aesthetics ugly. None of the characters were attractive, despite the actors not being bad looking in real life. The backgrounds were ugly too. Too mechanical looking and too orange.The villain, as in all Disney movies, was an emotionaless Brit who spoke with a complete lack of intonation. (Is it even politically correct to continuously portray Brits as boring prudes? It's 2024. We're supposed to be passed stereotyping like this).Anyway, that aside. If someone asked me to summarize the plot of this movie, I couldn't do it. Some sort of fixing a world, time device thing? I had no conclusion to anticipate. It was just like every other Marvel movie, no real beginning, a bunch of CGI violence, and an end but this time with the witty jokes of Ryan Reynolds.A lot of gay insuations from Deadpool towards Wolverine that never went anywhere. If you're going to go that route in the dialogue, I expect some action. A make out scene between Deapool and Wolverine definitely would've made this movie more original and more entertaining.All in all, if you like movies that are just mindless fighting with no plot and witty jokes, you'll probably like this.If you like movies that have substance in the way of a plot and with characters whose emotions you can feel/connect with, this movie is not for you.All in all, this movie was mid.

Review: Out of my appreciation for Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds I gave this 5 stars. Both have created iconic characters of Deadpool and Wolverine. I can't imagine any other actors playing these roles. Deadpool is one of the funniest, original superhero movies I've seen. Wolverine is iconic. So I have enjoyed these two incredible entertainers for 25 years. But this movie is a like a knock off toy of your favorite character you buy at the dollar store. What a total freaking mess. The jokes are non-stop and non-funny. I didn't actually laugh genuinely once. I wanted to laugh so bad I found myself laughing at jokes that, after thinking about, weren't actually funny. The story is manic and aimless. The scenery is boring. The dialogue is pointless. The villain is a Gen Z kid. The fight scenes are non-sensical as neither character can actually die. This movie is low to no stakes. The only ending I was actually waiting for was the actual ending, as in I couldn't wait for it to be over. It's hard to believe this but on a Friday night in a packed movie theater on opening weekend the energy was very low. People kept waiting and waiting for something more substantive but it never came. So I left 30 minutes before it was over. Out of respect for these two incredible actors who have given us so much fun over the years. But this is a joke of a movie, and unfortunately, the joke is on us.

Review: Wow, I don't know where to begin. I guess first off, I am not a huge fan of these multi-verse movies. Seems like everyone is doing them nowadays and it's getting really old really fast.Next, this is by far the worst one of the three movies. I rated both movies before this a 10 out of 10. They were hilarious, raunchy, crude, it was a really fun good time. This one does have a lot of that, but some of the jokes fell flat to me.Then weird things such as the line "boys are so silly" by the overpowered girl boss just didn't sit well with me. Those are the types of things that have been failing for Disney, I would've thought Ryan Reynolds would've asked that line to be cut.Anyway, I am so glad I did not pay a dime to watch this.4/10 by far the worst one of the three.

Review: Yes, this movie is for only fans of the franchise and are able to understand everything, from the plot to the Easter eggs.The movie is aimed to their fandom and doesn't care for the rest of the audience.I'm just a person who likes movies, and I like them...but this is a convoluted mess that goes from boring and complicated to action packed scenes so convoluted that my eyes were tired... I don't think it's for kids because of all the gore, although the humor is as silly and infantile as it can be.If you are a Marvel fan you are going to love it.If you are watching it because...kids...I'm sorry for you.

Review: Ryan Reynolds has been trying to ruin Marvel for quite some time. I'm glad Stan Lee is not around to see this. At this point Ryan is just beating the heck out of an already dying horse. It's just weird.The Marvel universe is based on the great comic book heroes that Stan Lee created. For the most part, morally sound individuals who try to do the right things and help others. Reynolds has been intentionally endeavoring to belittle and demean the whole universe and all its characters. He seems oblivious to the fact that Stan Lee's morally sound heroes have consistently been tremendous role models, especially for young people. He seems fixated on perverting the whole thing. Or he just doesn't care. Either way, it's weird.

Review: The movie Deadpool and Wolverine is a very boring movie. The plot in general can get confusing if you don't understand one part or pay attention completely. The plot is self is not an interesting plot and is kind of dull. It has a good amount of action throughout the move and a lot of comedy, but the action is mainly between wolverine and deadpool which becomes repetitive and gets boring quickly. The comedy is there like any other deadpool movie. Near the end of the movie it becomes better with the action scenes becoming more interesting. But overall m, In my opinion there are better deadpool movies that have better action scenes and a better plot than this movie.

Review: If you love Ryan Reynolds you'll love this as it's purely and simply the Ryan Reynolds show. It becomes so irritating after the first 30 minutes.It's just him, throughout, being sarcastic to everything that moves and the constant references to movie Companies gets sooooooo boring, we don't care about Fox and Disney and whatever has gone on there.The storyline is random and apart from the main theme I didn't have a clue what was going on.Hugh Jackoff just looked old and bored, it was another Dallas moment bringing him back to life.The only redeeming feature for me was the music, and without that it would have been even more meh.The Madonna bit at the end was worth waiting for.The special effects are good but it's just Reynolds, he grinded on me so much as just never shuts up.If it's raining and you've got nothing better to do then watch this.

Review: Legitimate question here, did artificial intelligence actually write this movie? Its a legitimate question because the shallowness, idiocy and perplexingly nonsensical jokes could not possibly have been written by people who just got done with a rather lengthy strike in Hollywood. In fact they sound like jokes from a script that someone has been sitting on for quite a while considering the gap between Deadpool 2, and this third installment. No offense, but if this is modern comedy in an action fantasy film, please place it back in the oven or grab as its not done yet. Only the most dedicated mouth breathing casual audience could possibly find anything entertaining in a film where half the jokes are bad computer animated fight sequences with lame 80's (and unfortunately newer) pop songs playing in the background. How groundbreaking, since apparently if you did this in a little movie called "Suicide Squad" (both if we're honest) people think its kind of garbage. Not unlike Paul Rudd's career, Ryan Reynolds has seen his heyday pass him by as well, since his claim to fame is "those deadpool movies and insurance commercials," what a legacy Ryan. Yet, here he is the one cracking a joke at Paul Rudd's equally dead franchise i.e. Antman. How brave. Worse than the overwritten dialogue is probably the odd dichotomy of having to both pretend Wade's deadpool actually cares about anything between all the offensively unintelligent jokes at I suppose whatever the AI algorithm came up- like this gem:"You know what? You're a ******* joke. No wonder the Avengers didn't take you or the X-Men, and they'll take ******* anyone. I mean, you are a ridiculous, immature, half-wit moron. I have never met a sadder, more attention-starved jabbering little ***** in my entire life, and that says a lot because I've been alive for more than two hundred ******* years! And I'll tell you, that bald chick was right about one thing: you will never save the world. You couldn't even save a relationship with a ******* stripper! Mother******, I wish I could say you'll die alone, but it's one of God's best jokes that you can't die! Except that's on all of us! You got nothing to say, mouth?"This enormously out-of-touch speech is the most overwritten, pretentious, fourth wall breaking trash I've ever heard or read in my life. These characters have so little actual growth, that they have to invent some lame speech for Logan to present to Deadpool, even when he has little reason to know any details of Wade's life, or his accomplishments prior to this film (almost like they forgot to mention those two other movies or something). Here-in lies the problem with a movie where two of the main characters have to be blank slates in order for the script-writers to do anything. Cameos galore cannot save a movie where the two main characters learn nothing about each other, babble insane lines that don't even rationalize their own behavior since we are only aware of them from previous franchises, which the writers are relying on so they don't have to do any actual heavy-lifting. All the 70 year old Wesley Snipers in the world can't save your dumb buddy cop film with cheesy one-liners, cartoon violence computer animation, and disgusting tonal dissonance whenever some lame song that plays at Walmart all day comes on as if it means anything at all.You can say I "don't like fun," but I've seen these movies, they've been coming out for years and they have no other direction to take except for maybe self-parody. There were so many lame jokes about Disney and Fox that only some corporate suit knowledgeable about rights issues, licenses, marketing and IP's could have suggested them to the AI. Cowboy films also became their own walking parody, so much so that an Italian director ended up making some of the best Cowboy films ever made (and the cheesiest too). The fact that people are still slow to understand the idea of "Sphaghetti super hero film" as long as it has someone recognizable in it, tells you a lot about our current generation of movie-goers and their expectations. The bar is pretty low, but luckily the collective memory of goldfish isn't dictated by how many of them are in one fish-tank. Over 20 years ago, X-men was popular because it was doing something different, that was when comic book sales weren't completely on life-support like they are now. Yes, its sad, but they had it coming, and like-wise so do movies starring 70 year old "Blades" spouting the same terrible lines he made infamous so long ago that I forgot they were even remaking Blade. If you do not take time to humanize these characters, develop good stories for them (like Logan) and rely on parody, you will end up stepping into the same quicksand Marvel slipped into. The adoration and money comes from bamboozled fans from somewhere, but I doubt even they are capable of currently connecting the dots when it comes to the generally insufferable tone these movies are going for now.

Review: If I have to be honest, it started great, it kept pace for a while, then cliches start raining along with cut body parts and sex jokes. For two hours we had fun, a lot of laugh, dirty jokes and ugly dogs. Then I was satisfied it ended and it was no more of that film. Fun moments, sad moments, new faces, something was missing. I can't complain it was boring, it was just one idea less than I expected it would be. I don't know why some moments were missing, the ones shown in the trailer, but anyway it's worth it watching for the Deadpool fans. Just please avoid the seats near people with popcorn at the cinema.

Review: I think one of the things that made the previous two Deadpool movies a success was that they had to be inventive because of the restrictions on licencing and to some degree budget.However now Deadpool is fully in the Marvel stables, and they have unlimited access to characters and budget, inventiveness has gone out the window. All you're left with a poorly written film which is bloated with pointless cameos, Easter eggs and substandard special effects. If seeing other MCU characters turn up for 30 seconds makes a good movie in your opinion then you'll probably love it. But it felt like fanfiction written by a 13 year old for the majority of the duration.The part where the film shines is the interactions between Deadpool and Wolverine, but the actual plot is ridiculous, there is no real sense of peril and the resolution is neither interesting or satisfying. The movie also felt about 40 minutes too long. Have never been bored in a Deadpool film before, but I was last night.It's a real shame as the Deadpool films have always been so left field and entertaining but this just felt packed with typical Marvel bloat, pomp and a lack of any real jeopardy.Sincerely hope that there is no Deadpool 4 and am shocked to find myself writing that.

Review: Don't get me wrong, Wolverine I love, Ryan Reynolds I'll watch every day if the week. But this is nothing more than pantomime. I cannot understand the 10 ratings - someone said industry ratings prolong the film up. It's weak, and didn't need to be made. I can't say the plot was weak, it wasn't meant to be strong. The 4th wall is there for a reason - we get drawn in to watching something, a story being told. We watch to be immersed in the story. The gore is beyond cringe and given recent events touched a nerve - give it context and it's fine but mindless and over the top. Not needed. I left wishing it had been as good as I'd been told.

Review: So let's see: what constitutes a good movie?Good action scenes? Check.Good editing & directing? Yeah sure why not, check.Enough superhero copyrights to shove cameos of half the superheroes ever made just coz we can? Check.More copyright for popular songs to shove more nostalgia to the "colorful" mix? Check.Good story? Nah! It's 2024, who needs that any more?!!Important disclaimer here: I never was a fan of Deadpool, I came here for Wolverine. If u saw the movie I think you'll understand my disappointmentWolverine here is no more than a side kick at best. I wouldn't be surprised if I knew that his whole script reached Hugh Jackman on a bunch of sticky notes or something. There's no character depth, no relatable motives, rare scenes of good acting, just a couple max . I really hope the money was good Mr Hugh coz I'm relentlessly failing to understand the reasons why you might have thought this is a story worth telling! I mean you ended Wolverine on a legendary high note with "Logan", this one is so sadly underwhelming! Even that simple title is so hilariously misleading it should've been something like "Deadpool(s) & Co" or maybe "Deadpoolers' wet dream" or something. Even the SciFi aspect of it is as expected from Marvel so outlandishly un-relatable entirely based on that multiverse hoax they're fond of, might as well do a story on flat earth!The overarching message of the production team all around the movie was "We're the company that created so many other stuff you loved earlier, that has to be enough for you guys to like whatever BS we throw at you, right?" You can see that message in the amount of out of context cameos, the Easter eggs, the soundtracks of other movies jammed in out of mood scenes, even in the closing credits, they just shove other movies' bloopers and BTSs that till now I fail to fathom their relevance. My god, if it wasn't for the spoilers I would have mentioned some character cameos that I wouldn't even care to mention in a joke! You'll know her when you see her.Call me old school but I believe a good story is a 1, add some good acting to it then it becomes a 10, good directing gets you to 100, throw some good production money that's a 1000, but if you have no story you end up with just zeros. After all, the movie business, at its core definition is just a glorified art of storytelling, right?

Review: With the overall positive reviews and promise of being Marvel's only superhero movie of 2024, I hoped I'd enjoy it. I also like the wolverine character and found some enjoyment from Deadpool in the past. Particularly in the first Deadpool movie. However in spite of some of the jokes being funny, I overall was not very entertained. I'd say a big reason for this is that there felt like there were even fewer real stakes for the superhero characters than normal. Both could regenerate. And everything else was so hammed up as part of comedy, that there didn't seem to be a lot of care for me in any of the character. Not only did they not seem to be real or in serious danger, but they didn't seem to analogous to something or someone that mattered to me either.The easter eggs were relentless in a bad way. They did the multiverse thing again. And it really seems to make it so anyone who dies feels like they were just a video game character losing one life rather than losing the entire game. The only one that I thought did the multiverse idea particularly well was Sony with the Spider-man and the Everything Everywhere all at once movie. I think this is because the stories were a bit more ambitious, original and cartoonish in style, and they made each interaction of each universe unique enough to each matter to the viewer and feel indispensable from one universe to another.This movie will not age like fine wine even if you enjoy it now. You probably won't enjoy it much in 10+ years. The 4th wall breaks are part of the style and identity of Deadpool. But perhaps they should have been relegated to one movie or at least had a few more of Deadpool's established original friends be part of his journey in this movie. That way there could be some more stakes for them rather than for others.

Review: I fell asleep twice during the Deadpool & Wolverine movie. It's not funny, quite boring, and ultimately feels useless. The plot drags on without any real direction, and the humor falls flat, failing to capture the essence that made Deadpool's earlier films enjoyable. Wolverine's character feels underutilized and out of place, adding nothing substantial to the story. You can exhange Wolverine with any other hero and the story will be exactly same. The action sequences are uninspired, and the dialogue lacks the sharp wit expected from a Deadpool film. I'm truly surprised by the positive comments I've read about this movie. It's disappointing, especially given the potential of these iconic characters. Definitely not worth the hype or the time.

Review: Deadpool. It's like watching the Naked Gun movies killing Leslie Nielson's career all over again, except this time with Hugh Jackman in DeadPool. The thing with Hugh Jackman, though, is that he is the white Denzel Washington, and no matter what he does or how it's done, he will create movie magic. He's just that great an actor. Not even Ryan Reynolds's curious foray into the dark side of movie magic can diminish him, but boy, did he try. In this movie, Ryan brought back some great cameos onto the screen (no spoilers here) that seemed to expose a not-so-cynical side to him. He seems to have a positive leadership vein and a seemingly cumbersome drive to advocate for others. This may be how he became so successful with Boost Mobile, his leadership, his compassion, and his promotion of others. However, Ryan has a dark side to his comedy that he apparently thinks about a lot and he has developed this entire Deadpool franchise around it. But I do not believe that is who he is, and I am pretty sure Blake tells him that regularly. He's not that dark, angry, cynical guy from which this Deadpool character was carved. The movie's whole premise is that he wants to be beloved and accepted into the Marvel Universe.Ryan Reynolds is a natural comedian with a God-given talent for comedic timing on the level of Carol Burnett, Harvey Korman, Lyle Waggoner, and Tim Conway, all wrapped in one. Maybe that's a little generous, but I do like Ryan. But unlike in his business ventures, in the movie realm, he doesn't seem to listen to the other voices in the room or to focus groups. Someone undoubtedly said to him, enough with the stabbing and the blood. It's boring. It's not even juvenile. It's something from a deep, dark place in him that he wants to put in our faces, along with imagery of sexual trains and bulging pockets, if you know what I mean. It's pointless. It's not funny to youngsters either. The only funny part for youngsters is that I, as a parent, would take them, my kids, to a movie displaying such images. For such a talented comedian, it's baffling that he is stuck on these galling images.If Ryan Reynolds chooses to use his talents to create Deadpool sequels in the likes of the Naked Gun series, it would be welcome in my home. Even the Naked Gun sequels had sexual innuendos and comedic physical comedy bits parodying this sexual act and that sexual act. One that comes to mind is when Detective Drebber was on top of the wheelchair scientist ala 69, and they went careening down the stairs. But it's all about how it's done. It was a funny scene that went from bit to bit and just got more outrageous as it went on. In this movie, Ryan has his hand stabbing one guy in his buttock from behind and the other hand stabbing another guy into his genitals, and then he rocks back and forth. It was all overdone, with nearly a minute of watching that. And that's 5 minutes (or more) into this scene, with all the stabbing and blood flying around. It's just ridiculous. Don't waste your time. It seems as though Ryan Reynolds has surrounded himself with yes men when he was making this movie to the point that no one could even tell him that enough is enough with the stabbing and the blood. Maybe the yes-men thing works in building a business, but maybe not so much in movie making-just a thought.

Review: "Deadpool & Wolverine" had the potential to be a thrilling blend of action and humor, but unfortunately, the creators opted to rely heavily on excessive swear words and blasphemy, which detracts from the overall experience. The overuse of this crude language doesn't add depth or wit to the dialogue; instead, it feels like a cheap attempt to shock or entertain. This choice reflects more on the creators and those who enjoy such content than on the actual quality of the film. The movie falls into the same category as many Hollywood productions that prioritize profit over substance, catering to fans without moral values and good taste. It's disheartening to see talented actors and iconic characters reduced to this level, where the focus is more on pandering to a particular audience than delivering a film with genuine creativity or depth. This film could have easily delivered the same action-packed excitement and humor without resorting to such dribble, making the reliance on shock value all the more disappointing.

Review: As a big fan of Deadpool, and Reynold's interpretation of the character, it pains me to say that all Disney pulled off was a generic corporate-safe version of Deadpool. Really disappointed. By all means, the movie isn't terrible: great acting, great fight scenes, good gore, good production values... However, the writing feel flat due to what I assume was Corporate influence. After all, this IS a Deadpool movie without funny jokes nor any edginess. This is the safest R-Rated movie Disney could've done. The blandest thing made just for Reddit audiences... I don't believe I am actually saying this, but can we have 20th Century FOX back?Looking here on IMDB, I've seen people complain about IGN's 7 out of 10 review. Well, IGN was too generous.
