Review: If you are looking for fan service, Deadpool and Wolverine delivers. Please do not think this is Endgame level Marvel because unfortunately, it is not. Marvel put violent characters in a movie and said go for it. Great action (minus one scene near the end where Hugh Jackman or his stunt double must have just had enough and was clearly just going through the motions).The plot is just really, really, really bad. I can't type anymore as I'm thinking about lowering my score. This will definitely break records because fans want this but Russo brothers still are the kings of Marvel. Go and see it for the fan service but do not go in looking for some kind of direction for the Marvel universe, just have fun with it. If I could describe it, it is like driving through a brand new car wash, with the windows down.

Review: I don't write many user reviews, as so many others do this just fine.But I cant seem to figure out, why this has so many 9 and 10 star scores ?There is even a mention about the "bald female actor" which describe her acting in this movie as bad ?I mean, she is litterally the best actor in this crew..And the story felt lazy written.Normally, I'm easy to entertain, and not very critical in my viewing. But I was kinda bored through this.I guess I should've seen it coming, from the last years promotion and endless spoilers.And the trailer on YouTube apparently made it to guinness book of records.I wouldn't be surprised if they also payed for the 10 star reviews in here ..In comparison , I was entertained much better in Thor: Love and Thunder , and even the Captain Marvel movies, was not this bad either.If you asked me, this should've been skipped, for a total reboot of the cinematic universe.I guess, maybe, if you are a die hard deadpool fan, this movie is kinda.. mediocre.. = 5 stars.

The point they've reached is that the story really is the least of it and as Ryan Reynolds would say, each one is a long trailer for the next and so on.The best, the end credits with behind the scenes of the death Fox's films and the cameos of course.

Review: I liked this movie. I liked this movie a lot. The cameos, the Wolverine, jokes, action, villain was ok. But many aspects were very great. But just not for a supposedly epic marvel comic book movie.Deadpool and Deadpool 2, in my very novice IMDb amateur opinion, were phenomenal comic book or superhero movies! Case in point cable and juggernaut! I still can't speak enough of how epic those two films were. But this Wolverine and Deadpool movie, even with all the pizazz, could not quite measure up to those movies. I think the reason it couldn't was due to the far fetched script. It was just too out there.But seeing Wolverine and Deadpool together on the screen was great. However, I need more than a team up to make a movie a success.Lastly, why does Ryan have to make so many jokes about men? Are the comics like that? Anyways, great comedic movie. Enjoy!

Review: TL;DR: turn off your brain for 2 hours & pretend to be entertained.I actually believed they would've pulled off somewhat of a masterpiece. But this was 2 hours of shameless, pitiful fan pandering with little to no focus to everything else that should matter to a so-called super-action flick. Story and combat.It falls short on both. Plot is lame as hell, with the uber-predictable "save your universe from extinction at the hands of Skeletal Bald 5-foot Chick villain of the week at the 11th hour".And when the narrative isn't blatantly sucking off Wolverine, it just serves a never-ending Exposition train & lame telegraphed one-liners about how bad Marvel has been doing, taken directly from Instagram comments of random people with 0 posts and private profiles.The fight scenes are below par with far too much focus on close-quarters combat, which is probably due to their ages - Ryan is almost 50 and Hugh is nearing 60.And the cameos. Well, I don't know Ryan's history with everyone else but the return of Wesley Snipes as Blade, considering the bad history between the 2, seems like a Pity Job designed to humiliate the man now that Wesley is in the movie that Ryan is in charge of, instead of the other way around. Making him smile like an idiot donkey at the end was far too obvious.After all we all know how fake-nice guy Ryan treats those he doesn't like, made apparent by showing the famous Avengers 2012 action shot that gets cut off abruptly just before it shows Black Widow - Ryan's real-life ex who he heavily resented because she's a successful independent woman and he's an extremely insecure little man. Hence why he married a nobody after her, so he can be the star of the family.Quite ironic seeing how it's fairly obvious Ryan's star is fading fast. Nothing he's done outside Deadpool in the last 10 years is ever mentioned. Which is perfectly reflected in DP3. A stale, unfunny nostalgia act. And if this is what it takes to gross over 1 billion at the box office in 2024...cinema is well and truly doomed.Ryan's fragile ego might as well have left in the Captain Marvel & She-Hulk cameos because it's not like they would've made the movie any worse than it actually is. He managed that all on his own. I'm glad Marvel/Disney put their foot down and stonewalled him on releasing the bonus footage he wanted to show off to please his ego. Know your place, little man.

Review: Subjectively, I understand the title as "Fun enough, but too meta". However, that's for everybody to decide for themselves.I accidentally paid for this movie twice. I selected a wrong day the first time around and before I noticed my mistake, the movie was already over. So, it doesn't really matter what I think, I've already voted for this thing with my wallet.First of all, kudos to everyone involved, especially Bob Chapek (this wouldn't be greenlit without him). I know it wasn't easy to get all these people and IPs together.Humor: Three times the same gets old. It's like Jack Sparrow - he's fun but his jokes get stale after a few movies. I loved H. J. and R. R. play against each other though.Immersion / 4th wall: There's no 4th wall, no immersion. Hence, there's ironically no breaking of the 4th wall.Characters: There are no characters, only actors. Hence, you are never really concerned for their safety. Nobody died during the production to my knowledge so there was no need to be concerned.Plot: The same thing as above. This isn't the usual story movie, this is a commentary about the current state of things in Disney and Hollywood. You could watch a Doomcock video just as well. On that note, the whole project was a nod to the HiSHE video for Logan.Soundtrack: None, if I remember correctly. Just a random collection of pop songs, as usual.In the end, it's all about what you want from this. Does it deserve 8+? For me, absolutely not.

Review: Try to ignore much of the bad reviews, it is readily apparent many of them have never read a Deadpool comic, and are strictly comparing Deadpool 3 to Deadpool 1 and 2. Yes there is a lot of 4th wall breaking, and there may or may not be a plot, depending upon how you see it, and there is an abundance of cameos. But, news flash, that is how Deadpool is. To those who take the time to look outside of the films, and to comic book fans, pick up a Deadpool comic. He is in every universe. Personally I enjoy when he teamed up with Tom Sawyer, the times when he changes history, or when he killed every MARVEL character, (at least a few dozen times).The point is, don't look for plot in Deadpool. He was driven insane, and I am saddened and amazed that Reynolds hasn't been able to show the multiple voices in his head yet, (there are at least two aside from his usual personality portrayed in the films), and having multiple 'pools is par for the course of accurate portrayal of the character. This is a film written by Deadpool fans, for Deadpool fans, and for people to learn more about the character. The film was fantastic.

Review: The first 2 movies in this trilogy had a great collection of misfits including ones without super powers such as Dopinder, Peter, the blind lady and the bar man, plus some comical super powers such as "luck" which set these movies apart from the typical Marvel movies.Sadly what we have here is very close to a typical Marvel movie. They should have just called it "The Wolverine (and Deadpool)". Sure we have Ryan Reynolds addressing the audience directly, taking jabs at Fox and Disney etc, but with so little of the team from the first 2 movies we just have Ryan Reynolds gushing over Hugh Jackman for nearly 2 hours with your typical X-men style plot. Ryan is supposed to annoy only the characters in the movie, not the viewers too.There are enjoyable moments in the movie, but I was hoping for Deadpool 3, not Wolverine 10 and the whole experience seems a sellout.

Review: Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) is living an empty life after breaking up with Vanessa. The Time Variance Authority captures him and Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen) intends to destroy his universe. He escapes and recruits the worst Wolverine (Hugh Jackman).The Multiverse strikes again. My first impression is that none of this matters. There is an infinite number of everything and there is no stakes in any of this. As the movie goes on, I find some fun in Deadpool pulling references and not treating the multiverse so seriously. Then comes all the old movie versions and it's fun nostalgia. I started hoping that Deadpool would end the multiverse. If I have a vote, that's the next movie. Feige could be the big bad and Deadpool could burn down Marvel headquarters. After that, they would have to restart the MCU.
